CANADA
Ottawa, November 12, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the voucher which you forwarded, in favour of the Bureau of Labour, Winnipeg, covering the cost of the inspection of the boiler at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, to the amount of $8.00, and also a voucher covering the cost of inspection of a boiler at Berens River.

Cheque in payment of the fees charged for the inspection of the boiler at Fort Alexander is being sent to the Bureau of Labour, Winnipeg.

I am returning herewith the account for the inspection of the boiler at Berens River. I would point out that the Department is not responsible for the inspection of the boiler at this point. The Bureau of Labour should look to the authorities of the Oblate Order in Winnipeg for payment of this account and you should advise them accordingly. I may say that this Department has not recognized the establishment of a residential school at Berens River.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E. McPherson, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
EX'D.

Ottawa, November 17, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The enclosed account, covering the cost of material purchased by the Principal of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School in erecting a cottage for the men, has been rendered to the Department by Rev. Father Pleurde.

It may be found possible to provide the funds for payment of the material from the current year's appropriation, in the special building programme. I would request, if you are satisfied this material has been supplied and that the prices charged are fair and just, that you will attach the accounts to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. I would appreciate if you would give this matter your early attention.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

his consideration, and has decided that the
question of installing this power line should
remain in abeyance until next Spring.

Ottawa, November 25, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to previous correspondence, regarding the installation of a power line, to supply current to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, I now have to inform you that the Minister, after giving this matter his consideration, has decided that the question of installing this power line should remain in abeyance until next Spring.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
Pine Falls, Man.,
November 14th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

Re Pump repairs.

In laying a new water line, I had to see that the pump would work properly. Here are the different problems I had to deal with immediately:

1- The pump itself was out of order.
2- It was unnecessarily elevated, thus necessitating more power to draw the water.
3- The base on which it was standing was not firm.
4- There was an undue draught of air around it, exposing it often to frost during winter.
5- There was only a single floor over the pneumatic water tanks, which often were freezing during winter.

I had the pump properly repaired by the shops of the Manitoba Paper Co., at Pine Falls. I had the pump lowered and set on a firm cement base. I had a wall built at some reasonable distance, and insulation done over the pneumatic tanks.

Enclosed please find vouchers covering the labour done on the work, to wit:

Repairs on the pump. Paid. $17.05
Work to set the pump properly $59.00

$76.05

The school has supplied free the following:

800 ft. Insulating Board $.52 $41.60

2 yds. Gravel $2.00 $4.00

From the Manitoba Paper Co., Pine Falls:
26 ft. 4" 4 Ply Rubber Belting $8.80
for Pump $125.45

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE

WINNIPEG, MAN. November 26th, 1936.

Attention of Mr. Sutherland

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing copy of a letter received from the Rev. Father Brachet, Principal of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, setting forth certain expenses incurred in connection with repairs to the pump and work in re-setting the pump on a more satisfactory foundation.

There is no question as to the fact that the pump needed to be repaired and you will perhaps recall the unsatisfactory setting of the pump when you visited the school some two or three years ago. The basement underneath the engine room was not dug sufficiently deep before the pump was installed and it was necessary to get the pump on a level with the pressure tanks, which were installed in a proper basement some two years ago.

I feel that the expense has been kept quite reasonable and would recommend that Voucher No. 303, which I am forwarding under separate cover, be paid.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Re Water Line.

I beg to submit the enclosed vouchers to the Department for payment of the laying of the Water Line, to wit:

Labour. Paid by the Principal.

$57.74

$408.04

We consider that we have reduced the cost of laying the water line to a minimum. The same work exactly cost in 1919 for wages only, I am told, the sum of $1,700.00. Still we had to crib 20 ft. more than in 1919 for earth on the bank of the river, which earth is now loose and needed to be held back from falling, whereas at that time the earth was solid and no crib was necessary. The cost was thus raised $10.00 per ft. for 20 ft., which is the ordinary cost of cribbing per foot.

We had to put all the men insured by the Compensation Board, for in places they were 18 ft. underground. Some accidents might also have happened in the water.

There are many items which were willingly paid by the school.

We are quite proud and thankful that we were successful in finishing the task properly.

Sincerely yours,

WINNIPEG, MAN., November 26th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Department Letter 125-1-5 dated August 20th, I now enclose herewith copy of a letter received from Rev. Father Brachet, Principal of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

We expected to repair the water line by digging down at the school and with pressure forcing the pipe through the bank into the river. Unfortunately, there were too many rocks and it became necessary to lay the pipe by digging from the school out into the river beyond freezing point. I think the Department will understand that this entailed a great amount of work. I need only refer to the expense in connection with the water line at the Kenora School which expense, I understand, reached approximately $2500. The work at Fort Alexander was practically the same and I am convinced that the Principal has kept the cost as low as possible and that the work will prove satisfactory. I trust the Department will see fit to pay this added expense.

Under separate cover, I am forwarding Vouchers Nos. 301 and 302 in connection with the above matter.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

Re Gallery Foundation. Urgent.

When you came here last summer I had you notice that the Girls' Gallery foundation had partly fallen away. Since then it crumbled about completely, nearly causing bodily harm. The gallery itself and also the solarium built above by the Department were exposed to sink down at once. There was no time to lose in repairing it. While a competent foreman, Mr. Peter Desrochers, was here, I thought it necessary and urgent to proceed with work at once with two masons, whom I am employing at the school.

Enclosed please find the accounts of the work, to wit:

Labor. November 7th $86.00
" 14th $93.65

Material. Bought from Granoffsky Bros., Pine Falls, Man., & payable to him $179.65

Everything is now safe with the gallery & solarium. The gallery has been repaired where it was broken.

The school has supplied gratis:
10 bus. Lime $.65 $6.50
3 yds. Sand 2.00 $6.00

I will also install some gutters on the solarium to protect the gallery and foundations.

I trust you will have the Department understand the urgent necessity of this work and have the payment made of the sums of $179.65 and $43.05.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Re Electric Plant.

I am sorry to state that our switchboard is in bad order. The ammeter does not work, so we cannot know if electricity is brought to the batteries or not. The rheostat coils, having some plates burned, others poorly insulated, let some fire escape and flame up along the wall. Thus we can hardly recharge the nice set of batteries, which have been supplied by the Department.

I had an electrician from the Manitoba Paper Co., of Pine Falls, come and examine the Switchboard. Later on two men from the Dickson Electric Co., of Winnipeg, Mr. W. P. Smith, Manager, and an expert, came on my request to visit the batteries, which they had supplied. Soon afterwards two men from the Canadian General Electric Co., of Winnipeg, came also on my request to see the generator and switchboard, which they have supplied in 1925.

The suggestions I gathered from those experienced men is that the ammeter should be fixed by a competent man of Winnipeg; also that the burned plates should be replaced by a company, which would recast similar ones, and that the others would be properly rehauled and isolated. Thus with a lowered cost the switchboard should work properly until such time as the Department would see the way to authorize the contemplated transmission line from Pine Falls.

It is rather hard to state the possible cost of this expenditure; but, as much as can be gathered, it should not amount to over $50.00, possibly less.

As this work is something delicate and important, I wish to leave it to the responsibility of the Department. I would only point out that it is very pressing.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Dear Sirs:

With regard to 56 cells, ICG-11 Delco Ironclad batteries purchased for Fort Alexander Indian School, we wish to advise that this installation has been inspected and the following noted:

On December 10th, the writer accompanied by Mr. P.C. Armstrong representing Exide Batteries of Canada Limited, and Mr. J.A. Smith, our service manager, proceeded to Fort Alexander School for the purpose of making a thorough examination of the condition of the batteries. Unfortunately we found that a few days previous the switch panel had broken down, the battery charging resistor had become broken, the ammeter was not in operation and the batteries were in a discharged condition. We made an examination of the batteries and they appeared to be, apart from the discharged condition, normal. There was nothing that we could determine from observations made that would indicate that the batteries were defective and that with proper care and attention they should not give the service for which they were recommended. Due to the discharged condition of the batteries, we were unable to make the regular tests and therefore we were unable to determine to what extent the batteries had been in a semi-discharged condition as the fact that the charge was not going into the batteries was entirely unknown to the party in charge of the equipment.

We remained on the job from approximately 3 o'clock P.M. until about 10 P.M., allowing a short interval for dinner. We succeeded in temporarily repairing the battery charging resistor on the plant and also temporarily repairing the ammeter and although the lighting plant end of the installation was apart from our affairs, we were able to assist the man in charge in obtaining a better working knowledge of their present
system and at the same time we left instructions with him for the proper care of the batteries.

As mentioned above, we were unable to determine to what extent in the past these batteries were allowed to become discharged away below normal. Therefore to offset a sulphated condition and the possibility of a low capacity, we left full instructions for a method of correction which would remove sulphation and increase the capacity. We have further requested that they forward a report as soon as the various charges have been given the battery and when we have received this report, we will communicate with you further.

The above visit to the Fort Alexander Indian School is the third call which has been made and these calls were due to complaints which you have on record but in all cases we have found that the charging rates were inadequate to keep the battery in condition. However, we believe Father Brachet who is in charge at present, will see that instructions regarding this equipment are carried out and that the equipment will be preserved to the best of their ability. The young man in charge of the plant appears to be very conscientious and willing to co-operate in every way in regard to the proper care and attention of their lighting system.

We will communicate with you further when we have received the report from the operator in charge.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re Urgent Repairs.

At your visit here with Dr. McGill last summer you have noticed that the school was in bad order. Since that time it seems that matters became still worse, for the plaster began to fall in places - once some fell on one pupil's head - and where big holes were opened on the walls, noticed that the rooms became about unfit to be inhabited, when there was a strong wind striking the sides. We could not pass the winter with pieces of plaster endangering the pupils and with cold rooms exposing them to pneumonia. In the same time it was too late to ask and wait for due authorization from the Department. Considering that, as Principal, I have the responsibility of the pupils' health, I have done the most pressing work, leaving the rest until we obtain the authorization to replaster, as has been asked in next year's estimates.

These urgent repairs on walls & ceilings amount to $672.80.

In the same time we had still to install toilets in the ex-laundry, now the girls' nice recreation room. The work amounts to $66.00.

These are the last returns I dare send to the Department, for I consider that we have received good help, which is immensely appreciated.

A considerable amount of work remains to be done.

1- The school being as an ice house at times during the winter, we have to re-adjust the external doors & frames, specially those leading to the fire-escapes, as well as the inside windows & stops, and the storm shades.

A storm door with refrigging or stirs are needed in the boiler room, where water pipes froze last winter.

Insulation has to be done over the dormitories, and in the boys' dormitories radiators will be added, as it is so high and exposed to the north wind.

2- Some toilets leaking, some plumbing has to be refixed and fixtures replaced.

3- Some chimney ventilators being fire-hazards have to be refixed.

All this necessary work means a large expenditure, but I am ready to have it done only with the school funds, provided the above accounts are accepted.

I do not wish the Department to have to pay high hospital bills in Pine Falls for pupils who would have been exposed to sickness. Prevention is better than cure.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

A.G. Hamilton, Inspector,
Winnipeg.

The fire escapes were unlocked. The fire hose appeared in good condition, but carelessly hung over a pipe. Brackets should be supplied and the hose properly folded. I would recommend that four axes be provided and placed in suitable locations, these to be used only in case of fire. Fire extinguishers are located on each floor. In winter, a night watchman is on duty and his time is checked by means of a clock. The school is a fire hazard and every precaution should be taken to prevent one.

The new laundry is well built and well equipped, except that more power is required to operate the machinery. If the Hydro power is not installed next year, a 10 H.P. engine should be supplied. The dryer is installed upstairs above the laundry and, when fitted with new coils, will prove very satisfactory.

The lighting plant is not giving good service. The engine is very old and expensive to operate. The switchboard really should be replaced, but with some repairs, we can perhaps get through the winter. I hope next year we can have the Hydro power installed; if this is not done, we must be prepared to install a new lighting plant and supply a larger engine for the laundry.

This school should also be supplied with a frigidaire. Due to the location, it is necessary to keep a supply of meat and other perishable food on hand and it is difficult to prevent waste under present conditions. There is suitable space for the installation in the dairy and I hope funds will be provided.

With reference to the lighting plant, you were authorized by official letter of the 31st ultimo to arrange for the repairs required to the switchboard.

Your recommendation that a frigidaire be supplied is noted. Owing to lack of funds, it is not possible to favourably consider supplying this equipment at the present time. Certain funds are provided for this school in our Appropriation for next year, and if this item is allowed, it may be possible to supply the frigidaire.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

This will acknowledge your letter of April 2nd regarding the chlorinating system at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School and I should be glad to discuss this with you the first opportunity.

I do not concur in your opinion that the chlorinating installation is necessitated by mill operations, nor that the Company is responsible in any way for the upkeep or cost. Some years ago I offered to send our man down to the Mission periodically to make an inspection of the plant purely as a matter of voluntary assistance to the Mission authorities; apparently for quite a long time the plant was not used and was permitted to get out of repair so that there was no object in continuing this practice. However, if it is going to be of any assistance to the Mission authorities, I should be glad to send a man down periodically to inspect the equipment and give the Mission people any advice we can with regard to proper maintenance and operation. We would, however, assume no responsibility in connection with either the Chlorox or repairs.

I shall be glad to discuss this at any time with Father Brachet and make arrangements as to the best time for such inspection.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I received a letter some time ago from the Rev. Father Brachet stating it cost approximately $75. to purchase the Chlorox required to keep the water fit to drink at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. He pointed out that this expense and the upkeep of the chlorinator is a direct result of pollution of the river by the Manitoba Paper Co. Ltd. and in his opinion, they should pay this expense. I have had repeated complaints from the Indians in this respect. They claim the river water has been made unfit to drink and feel the mill authorities should provide wells.

Recently I wrote Mr. C. C. Irvine concerning the water situation and attached is a copy of his reply, and the Department will note the stand taken.

The existing condition can only be attributed to mill operations and my opinion is that both the school and Indians should be compensated by making it possible for them to obtain suitable drinking water.

The Department no doubt has correspondence regarding this matter as I am of the opinion the paper mill supplied the chlorinator now in use. If such is the case, they apparently at that time felt some responsibility. I would appreciate being advised under what arrangement the chlorinator was placed in the school and what agreement, if any, was made concerning operating costs.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton
The Secretary, Inspector of Indian Agencies
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Indian Affairs. (RG 1G, Volume 6265, file 579-5, part 7)
Ottawa, February 1, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received a communication from the Manitoba Paper Company Ltd., Pine Falls, relative to the chlorinating plant at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. They state that inspection has been made of this plant from time to time by their Chief Engineer and Chief Chemist and that it developed, at the time of the last inspection, which was on the 7th ultimo, that the school had been out of chlorine since about November 10th, last.

In this connection I have to say that an arrangement was made some time ago with the Company that when the supply of chlorine on hand reached a certain point, the School Authorities would advise them, and a further supply would be furnished. It is necessary, if this chlorinating plant is to be operated properly, that you co-operate with the Company in order to receive proper advice on how to handle the plant. The water from the Winnipeg River is grossly polluted, and, as the Department went to a great deal of expense to install the system, and as the Paper Company undertook to have their Engineer make periodic inspection and assist you in keeping the plant in order, it is expected that you will co-operate with them to the fullest extent. It would appear that this system is being operated with a great deal of carelessness and neglect. It is of the utmost importance to the health of the pupils that this chlorinating plant be kept in proper order and in constant use. I shall be pleased to have a report from you in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

'Sgd.' T. R. L. MacInnes.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am just back from a visit to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. The Principal took occasion of my visit to point out that he had no boat of any kind to use for his recruiting. As you know, the river divides the Reserve in two and about one-half of the Indians live on the East side of the river whilst the school is built on the West side of it.

He would willingly buy and pay for a large rowboat if the Department would supply a Johnson Outboard Motor. A 4-horsepower motor would be about the right size.

In view of the fact that the Principal has not asked for nor received any grant for recruiting, it occurred to me that you may be willing to supply him with this motor in lieu of a grant for recruiting.

Dear Sir,

Under separate cover I am forwarding a voucher in favour of the Rev. Father Brachet, amounting to $329.96.

I would point out, at the beginning that this amount is over and above our recommendation, which I am forwarding under separate cover and will total more than the $1400.00 allowed for this school. I realize that Father had no authority for this expenditure but I can assure the Department that the material was needed and the work performed has been well done.

Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter 125-1-5, dated July 16th, and to say that, as requested, I have visited the Pt. Alexander Indian Residential School and find that the $1400.00 allowed will hardly meet the expenses in connection with the work that should be carried out.

The roof of the boiler room leaks and unless this is repaired immediately the plaster inside will be entirely destroyed. This would cost approximately $110.00.

It has recently been discovered by the Health authorities that the disposal of the sewage from the school does not pass through a septic tank. It flows into a cement basin and from there runs into the lake. The outlet to the lake is not many feet from the present intake which supplies water to the school. A septic tank should be installed and it is estimated this would cost approximately $565.00.

A number of the beds have been used for many years and are past repair and six new ones are required. Many of the mattresses must be destroyed, and the Sisters have made up the coverings necessary for 32 new mattresses. The filling for these will cost approximately $90.00.

Although we did considerable repair work to the plaster on the walls of the school last year, there is still about 1000 yds., to be done. If it were possible to do the worst parts, probably 250 yards, we could get along for another year. This would cost $325.00.

The boys' play room has not been painted for many years and is very dark and gloomy. This room should be painted as well as the corridor leading to it. The laundry erected last year has never been painted inside and, as a large amount of the material used in the construction was old material, this should also be painted. The labour and paint in connection with this work would cost approximately $350.00.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
If it is imperative to keep within the $1400.00, I would suggest that the plastering be left over although I am sure before another summer patches of it will have fallen off the wall. The principal is anxious to complete a large part of this work before school opens and I would appreciate having the necessary authority, if possible, by wire.

The labour, with the exception of that of Mr. Desrosiers and his assistant, will all be performed by the Indians. Mr. Desrosiers is the man who built the laundry last year and is a first class builder.

Yours very truly,

Re Fire protection.

Yesterday, on the approach of winter fires, we inspected our fire equipment and we found that 2 of the Pyrene Extinguishers could not operate, having been corroded by the liquid, and they are absolutely useless. Dear Sir:-

Re Urgent repairs on Ice House.

Last year when I came here as Principal I found in July that there was no more ice left in the Ice House. This year we have some left yet, owing to great care taken in surrounding all the ice with new shavings; however, we have been unable to keep meat throughout summer, on account of defective ventilation and of the lack of a cooling room. I find it absolutely necessary to keep all meats in very good condition, especially now that we are to start a preventorium. We would have to put a better insulation all through the inside, a new ventilation, two cooling rooms, and possibly a new foundation. The work has to be done now that the weather is cold and before frost begins. Mr. Desrochers, who supervises the building of the preventorium is equipped to do the work and he has the experience that will enable him to put satisfactory work. If we do not repair the Ice House now, we would have to wait another full year and consequently to be without any cooling convenience for meat, butter, etc..

Here is an estimate of cost of repairing satisfactorily the present Ice House:

OTTAWA.

My dear Doctor McGill:

You are sufficiently conversant with the situation at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential school to dispense me from going into details concerning the electric plant which is now in use. I might say, however, as a matter of record that the electric light and energy are now supplied by a Diesel engine; of course this kind of power necessitates a very large number of batteries. This engine is very old and I am informed that it will soon have to be replaced. The same, of course, must be said of the batteries as they were installed a few years ago and that, as you know, batteries have a very short life, even under the very best management and care.

Would not the best solution of this power and light problem be the building of a power line from Pine Falls to the school? This project was approved by the Department two years ago and was not proceeded with because it was found that the Manitoba Pulp and Paper Company which operates the Pine Falls Mill had not the right to sell electric energy to outside customers. This state of affairs is now eliminated because the Manitoba Power Company is building a line, at least so I am informed, from Great Falls to within two miles of the town of Pine Falls. This line could easily be projected as far as the school. The school then would have a permanent and safe source of electric power. This is all the more necessary since the building of the Preventorium in conjunction and under the direction of the Indian Fort Alexander school. You know how little dependable are the small power units in our schools. It would be most unfortunate if the patients who will be confined to the Preventorium were to suffer through the lack of sufficient electric energy both for power and light.

I submit this case to your consideration knowing that you will favorably act upon it if it is at all possible to do so.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, requesting that arrangements be made for the erection of a power line from Pine Falls to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

You will remember discussing this matter with me when you recently visited the Department and, at that time, I suggested that you interview the President of the Winnipeg Electric Company, with a view to ascertaining if some arrangement could be made for the erection of a power line to Fort Alexander.

When you have had an opportunity to interview him I would appreciate if you would write me again.

Dear Sir:-

Re Circular 150-65 (502-606) Febr.10,1938.

I beg to refer to the circular of the Director regarding fire prevention, in which it is stated that any Principal who is not satisfied with the fire escape and fire prevention facilities should report immediately to the Department.

Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
Pine Falls, Man.,
October 25th 1938.

Dear Sir:-

Re Hot Water Boiler.

I beg to let you know that on the 8th inst. our Hot Water Boiler burst through the action of rust. We have soldered it with Smooth on Iron Cement without success. We then had an experienced man come twice from the Pine Falls Garage to braze it with acetylene; but it leaks elsewhere. All the front section would have to be taken out and replaced; but I am afraid that the six sections are in the same state, for the coil pipes which were connected from the hot water storage tank with the ordinary heating furnace were leaking last winter and we had to disconnect them.

It is a Guernsey Cottage Boiler we have from the Guernsey Foundry Co., Robert A. Stewart, Chief Inspector of the Bureau of Labor, 332 Legislative Bldg., Phone No. 840 252, who was here yesterday is of the opinion that it would not be safe to try and repair this old boiler, that any way these Guernsey Boilers do not last long. He mentioned to Rev. Sister Superior another kind of boiler which would be better suitable.

We are quite handicapped at present for the question of hot water, which is daily needed for dishes and baths. We would sincerely appreciate if you would kindly communicate with the Department by telegram in order to obtain the authorization to have another boiler bought. The Guernsey Foundry Co. would let you know what kind of boiler we have, and Mr. Stewart would mention the type of boiler which he thinks would be better fit and last longer.

I am sure you will do your best to help us in our difficulty. I have bought already at our own expense a big water cooling tank for our 15 H.P. Engine, also a gasoline tank for the same engine, and a little tank for the kitchen range; but all the expenditure of repairs I have had in the school for the last two years I am unable to bear the cost of a hot water boiler.

Hoping to receive a word from you soon,

I remain, dear Sir,
A.G. Hamilton, Inspector, Wpeg.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

As requested by you the following is a report on your water pump.

The pump as you know is in bad repair and will have to be sent to a machine shop for a general overhauling, which in my opinion does not justify the cost, as it is really an obsolete piece of machinery and is worn out.

I would recommend that you install a gasoline driven pump of 500 gallons per hour capacity which would be ample for your normal water supply, but would recommend a 1000 gallon per hour capacity pump for fire protection. This can be supplied equipped with automatic pressure stop but would have to be started by hand or could be equipped fully automatic. This type of pump is very economical to operate and will give perfect satisfaction with a minimum amount of attention. I am writing to Crane & Co. to send you descriptions and prices on the above.

In regard to your lighting plant engine, I am going to make every effort to send you a competent man to advise you on its condition as this is out of my line of work.

Taking into consideration the condition of your equipment, you would be well advised to install the gasoline operated pump and take the load off your Delco Batteries.

Your Chlorox Water Treatment apparatus is operating satisfactory, and as you know I am only too willing to go down at any time to examine it and make any adjustments necessary.

Yours very truly,

VCH/EH

When we started farming here in Alberta, in 1913, our seed was rather "green" in regard to many conditions we had to meet. As a result our first crop was very smutty, at least one-fifth being lost. Sometime later we heard of Formaldehyde and its application to seed grain. That result of our first trial was practically free of smut, greatly to our delight.

Our method for treating was very crude—a barrel of water with "dope" in it, a few gunny sacks into which we put the seed, and then these were suspended in the barrel for a few minutes. We used a common cotton box. Very crude, but we did not care as long as we were sure of a crop free from smut. In the course of a few years we made a doping contrivance which enabled us to work far faster and just as effectively.

We learned that seed which should be treated every spring, if only mixed up again springing in treating the seed the following fall, would become smutty. This we have actually demonstrated by dividing the seed into treated and untreated lots. The treated lot gave a clean harvest and the latter ran to about 50% smut.

We have been investigating into trying several other smut control devices, and while some of them eliminated the smut, there were so many objectionable features in handling them that we could hardly fail to fall on Formaldehyde every time.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 125-1-5 dated November 2nd, I wish to report that I have again discussed the question of erecting a transmission line from Pine Falls to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School with Father Brachet and others, and it is doubtful if the expense of this work can be reduced, in view of the advanced cost of material.

Father Brachet states that it is the opinion of the Rev. Father Provencher that under the circumstances, it would be inadvisable at the present time to request the expenditure of such a large sum and, as an alternative which he believes would be just as satisfactory and probably even less expensive than simply paying for the light, he suggests installing a unit similar to the one installed at Sandy Bay, at approximately $1500.00. Father Provencher points out that, in their experience, a plant of this nature would cost less to operate than charges per month for electricity from a Hydro power line.

The present lighting plant is a very old type, making it expensive to operate, and exceedingly expensive to buy repairs for. The dynamo and switchboard are in very poor condition. It is possible that the batteries may last another few months. The engine is badly worn and, as pointed out above, expensive to operate in view of the fact that it consumes a large amount of gasoline.

I am convinced that the most economical solution to our problem at this point would be to supply the school with a lighting plant as suggested by the Rev. Father Provencher.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re lighting plant.

You are aware that for many years past we have sent to the Department repeated requests for a new lighting plant, owing to the fact that our very old engine, which was started with a torch, could not be depended upon any more, as many pieces in it were completely worn out and new ones would have cost excessively, that the switchboard was ruined and that the generator was only partly charging.

Since the school is situated only six miles from Pine Falls, it had always been our aim to try and obtain a transmission line connected with the Manitoba Power Co. of Great Falls. However, it became evident last fall that the Department could not stand such an expenditure. In the same time experience from other schools where Diesel Engines are used showed that these engines operate at a lower cost.

In answer to our request for a new lighting unit, in your letter of November 25th, 1939 - 202-11 A.R.C. - 79 advised us as follows:

"no provision was made for a new electric lighting plant for this school in the current year's appropriation it is not possible to favourably consider supplying this at the present time. However, when preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1940-1941 an endeavour will be made to provide the amount you recommend."

Such was the letter you received from the Department. Still our old lighting plant could not stand the test of time, and when we received during the holidays a new set of batteries from the Department, we thought it was time to get a new lighting plant, so as not to be short of light and power during winter, and after giving advice to the Department through Rev. Father Pleurde, our Provincial Rev. Fauteux, O.M.I., purchased from Mumford Medland Ltd., Ipswich, 10 H.P. Lister Diesel Engine, with 6 K.W. Generator Switchboard, for the sum of $947.00, which some Brothers installed free of charge.

The unit is giving full satisfaction. It costs less per hour to operate, whereas the old one was consuming more.

We hope the Department will understand that we cannot wait until next fall, but must find the way in due time to endorse what could not be put off any more.

Yours,

[Signature]

J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

REPORT FOR MONTH OF OCTOBER, 1941.

VISITING RESERVES

On our visit to the Residential School, Father Brachet informed us that a few days before we arrived there he had a very bad fire which started in the laundry room of the school. He informed us that he had the children, the Sisters and all the staff carrying water and assisting in putting the fire out. I cannot understand how they managed to put the fire out and save the school, for the fire started on the ground floor and spread through the building to the roof.

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.
Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Fort Alexander Residential School visited on October 22, 1941.

A fire recently occurred between the laundry and bakery. It took several hours of hard fighting by all the pupils and staff to save the school. The laundry roof and walls were badly damaged. The Principal started repair work at once and the work was almost completed when I was there. The expense involved will probably reach $300.00. The fire extinguishers were all emptied and refills have been purchased. I am convinced the school was saved from total destruction only by hard fighting well directed by the Principal.

The kitchen floor is cement. The kitchen work is heavy and the Sisters are on their feet from early morning until late at night, and this type of floor makes the work very hard and trying. I would recommend that the floor be covered with battleship linoleum, and the cost as given by Eaton's for the linoleum and cement is $142.25, f.o.b. Pine Falls. If possible, this should be granted.

Dear Sir:

I acknowledge your letter 125-1-5 dated November 26th regarding the fire which occurred at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

I inspected this school on October 22 and submitted my report on November 8. I now quote from that report as follows:

"A fire recently occurred between the laundry and bakery. It took several hours of hard fighting by all pupils and staff to save the school. The laundry roof and walls were badly damaged. The principal started repair work at once and the work was almost completed when I was there. The expense involved will probably reach $300.00. The fire extinguishers were all emptied and refills have been purchased. I am convinced the school was saved from total destruction only by hard fighting well directed by the principal."

On November 5 Mr. E. McPherson submitted his monthly report and made reference to the school fire as follows:

"On our visit to the Residential School, Father Brachet informed us that a few days before we arrived there he had a very bad fire which started in the laundry room of the school. He informed us that he had the children, the Sisters and all the staff carrying water and assisting in putting the fire out. I cannot understand how they managed to put the fire out and save the school, for the fire started on the ground floor and spread through the building to the roof."

As stated in my report, the repairs were almost completed at the time of my visit, but undoubtedly involved considerable expense both in material and labor. The walls of the laundry were badly burned, as also was the roof, and after looking over the damage carefully I wondered how the fire was brought under control. Father Brachet stated that fortunately there was no wind; otherwise I fear the school would have been destroyed.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

Re 125-1-5

In reply to your inquiry of the 26th inst. regarding the cause of fire which occurred between the bakery and the laundry on October 7th at 1:35 p.m., I beg to say that apparently it was due to a pipe which passed through the wall of the bakery, connecting the oven to the chimney in the laundry. This pipe, it is true, was surrounded in the wall by 1½ ft. square of bricks, and these bricks on examination after the fire did not appear to be loosened. However, the pipe, which became quite heated at times, may have heated or burnt the surrounding bricks to the point of setting fire to some dust or spider's web above. Any way the fire made its way very rapidly through the wall upwards, setting all the top of the laundry in smoke and flames, which we took two hours to extinguish. Besides the united effort of all the staff and senior pupils, what saved the school itself from burning to ashes, was a rubber hose, which we use for the boys and girls' skating rink.

One linen fire hose in the laundry downstairs gave no service, for it was pierced in spots, being too old. When Mr. Hamilton came, I suggested that he should kindly ask the Department to supply us with 50 ft. of Linen Mill Fire Hose, Dia. inside 1¾". I do not know if he mentioned this need of ours in his report. Up to date, however, we did not receive any hose. I wish you would kindly obtain it for us.

Now to prevent a recurrence of the fire in the same spot, we have built in the wall a square of strongly cemented bricks of about 2½ ft. square with a circular opening of one foot, so that the oven pipe cannot possibly touch or heat anywhere. This opening of one foot in diameter serves as a ventilator as well, as the bakery is quite hot at times.

In the same time we have set and repaired the oven, so there can be no danger coming from it, whether the staff is there or not.

Trusting this is the information you desire,

I remain, dear Sir,

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

R. A. Hoey, Supt.
Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

I have your memorandum of the 3rd instant, File No. 125-1-5, quoting an extract from a report received from the Principal of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, explaining the cause of the fire which occurred in the school building in October last. It would seem that we were somewhat fortunate in that the fire did not do more damage than it did.

Dear Sir,

It is becoming quite a task to find suitable employees to work for our residential schools. When a good one can be hired, who will not likely be called for military service, it is wise, I think, to give him and his family the minimum comfort, in order to interest him to his work and make him stay.

One of our employees left us late last fall and we found a sickly, but willing man with a family of six children, who shall be joined by another one soon. Our former employee was alone with his wife, and the little cottage they were living in here, was plenty large enough for them. The cottage is far from being spacious enough for this larger family, and our new man was ready to leave unless we would build an addition immediately this spring.

I thought the best and only policy was, with the permission of our Provincial, to purchase at once the necessary material for an addition and to build it ourselves as soon as possible. We have consequently bought from The Russo Lumber Co., Ltd., St. Boniface, Man., some building material to the amount of $411.60, and we are going to start digging a cellar and foundation likely this week. Later there will be few other items to buy yet, such as paint.

We would far rather wait for the due authorization from the Department for such improvements, but you realize that it is generally a slow and uncertain process. Even if the permission is granted, before the material is bought by the Department, winter often close by.

I presume it is the intention of the Department to keep our schools running as efficiently as possible during these trying times. It is the reason of our decision regarding the addition for our employee's house.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal.

Ottawa, June 11, 1942.

Dear Father Brachet:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 10, in which you discuss the urgent need of a building suitable for living quarters for the farming instructor employed at your school.

I was greatly disturbed to note that you had already bought from the Cusson Lumber Company, Limited, of St. Boniface, building material at a cost of $411.80. No provision was made in the estimates of this year for the construction of a home for a farming instructor at the Fort Alexander School, and consequently it will not be possible for us to make this payment.

Under existing regulations - and these regulations have been in force for a number of years - no official of the Department and no principal of an Indian residential school can commit the Government to an expenditure unless authorized to do so from the head office. In the case of an emergency, certain field officials are allowed to incur expenditures not to exceed $25.00 in any given case. If we had in this year's estimates sufficient funds to meet this particular expenditure, we have no assurance whatever that the expenditure itself would be recognized by the office of the Minister or by the audit office.

I am anxious that you should inspect and consider the suitability of the buildings on the Fort Alexander Reserve purchased by the Government about a year ago. If these buildings are suitable for the purpose-

Reverend J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
Pine Falls, Manitoba.
purpose you have in mind, they might be placed at the disposal of the farming instructor, without rent, on the understanding that he might give a certain amount of nominal direction to the Indians in their farming operations. It is just possible, also, that if the storage space was taken over, this man might act as ration distributor.

I am sending forward a copy of this letter to Inspector Hamilton, in the hope that he will find it convenient to discuss this matter with you at an early date. Regardless of the suitability of these buildings, however, you simply cannot proceed with the construction of a farming instructor's home in connection with the school unless you are prepared to pay the cost of this building from school funds.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Before answering your letter of the 11th inst., I waited to have occasion to discuss the matter with Rev. Father Plourde and with Mr. Hamilton, Inspector. I saw Father Plourde; as for Mr. Hamilton, he was away when I called at his office.

First of all I wish to thank you for putting at our disposal the buildings recently purchased from the Hudson's Bay Co. at Fort Alexander. These buildings are one mile away from the school. They might be useful, should one young employee we have wish to be married. As we have no other building available, the H.B.C. buildings could then be used temporarily. The question now of interest is a small bungalow which I built in 1936 on my arrival, and to which we want to set an addition. This addition was not necessary, when a family consisted only of two. Now that there is a family of eight, it is certainly too small. The reason I wrote you about our plans was not really to try and bind the Department, but to inform you of my efforts to better the school and buildings year after year, as our means permit and as circumstances oblige us.

Father Plourde told me he had written you also about this question.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Selkirk, Man., July 10, 1942

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 15th, File 125-1-5, relative to repairs to the Fort Alexander Residential School.

I have interviewed Father Brachet and he informed me that he did not ask the Department to pay for the building material for the farming instructor's house at the Fort Alexander Residential School. However, if the Department is prepared to allow them a few hundred dollars to assist them in this matter, he said it would be greatly appreciated. I inquired if there was any other repair work that required to be done at the School and he said that there was nothing that he knew of. I did not inform him that there was $300.00 available for repairs to this school.

In regard to the Department's buildings at the old Hudson's Bay Post, he informed me that they might be able to use them and that he would advise me regarding this at a later date. The school now has two farm instructors, one a single man and the other a married man with a family of eight. The Father informs me that the single man is talking of getting married and if he does they will want to take over our buildings. I would suggest that we hold the $300.00 for repairing our own buildings for they will certainly need repairs if they are to be used.

Very truly yours,

E. Macpherson,
Indian Agent.

EX'D.

Dear Sir,

Re 125-1-5.

On my return from a trip down east I found on my desk your letter of the 4th inst.

Regarding the use of 10 gallons of Floor Enamel white, I beg to state that it is destined to be put on floors and walls exposed to be wet. We would not need this floor enamel, if we could obtain White of Zinc, from which we would make a similar composition. But this White of Zinc is unobtainable today.

We ask for white enamel as we intend to put in it the necessary shade of colour.

The Purchasing Branch would need only to mark Floor Enamel, white, and the paint company would readily understand, as it is thus marked in catalogues.

I would have wished to meet you while I attended the convention of the Oblate Commission at Ottawa, but this convention ended on a Saturday, and I could not wait to stay till the following Monday.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal.

Dear Sir,

Re: Electric Light Plant Battery.

Last fall I have informed you that our Electric Light Plant Battery was about exhausted and that I was waiting for a representative from the Globelite Batteries Ltd. to come and inspect the plant. I had also Mr. Roey informed through Father Plourde of Ottawa.

The enclosed report in duplicate from the Manager of the Globelite Batteries Ltd., Winnipeg, after the inspection of its Superintendent, states that a replacement is immediately required, and that the proper size we need is their

56 cell Type WEI, ampere hour capacity of 450, which they quote at $712.25 f.o.b. Winnipeg. (Special price)

The Superintendent told us here that, considering the load, the battery set has lasted longer than could be expected, that it would be a waste to purchase the same type of battery, that they have many orders ahead and it would likely take about two months to have the battery set ready.

This matter being of urgent need, I would ask you to kindly bring it at once to the attention of the Department so that they may press the Globelite Batteries Ltd. to supply us as soon as possible with the type of Battery required.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal.

E. McPherson, Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
PINE FALLS P.O., Manitoba.

Attention: Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal

Dear Reverend Brachet:

Inspection made a few days ago by our Superintendent, Mr. Stuart, now confi-
rmed that replacement of your present Electric Light Plant battery is immediately requi-
red in order to enable you to continue efficient operation of your Electric Light Plant.

You, no doubt, are aware that your present battery is too small for your electri-
cal requirements, which has necessitated recharging too frequently. This has reduced
the life of the battery considerably. After all, the life of any battery is measured
in cycles, that is the number of times it is charged and discharged (one complete charge
and discharge constitutes a cycle). Further, the average life of an Electric Light Plant
battery is 600 cycles.

Although you did not receive the service in life years claimed for your present batter-
ies, nevertheless we feel satisfied that the battery has completed its rated number of
cycles, and therefore the guarantee becomes void. However, in your particular case,
we are quite prepared to deviate from our usual policy and taking into consideration the
shorter life obtained with this battery, we would like to offer some compensation by
placing your present battery with one of proper size, namely our 56 cell Type H/L,
having an ampere-hour capacity of 450. As an adjustment, we are pleased to quote you
a net price of $712.85, F.O.B. Winnipeg, on this recommended size. (Regular price $930)

Further, should our offer be accepted, the old battery will automatically become
your property and the return of same is requested. We will bear return freight charges.

Trusting that you will find our offer satisfactory cooperation and service at all times, we are,

Yours,

GLOBELITE

Mar

WESTERN CANADA

February 23, 1945.

Dear Sir,

Re Diesel Engine.

As I informed you some time ago, our Diesel Engine refused any more service on December 14th. We obtained from the Manitoba Paper Co., Pine Falls, the service of their specialist in Diesel Engines. He stated that a complete overhaul was necessary. So on December 28th we shipped the engine to Mumford, Medland, Limited, Winnipeg, from whom it was purchased.

We would have liked to ship it sooner, but our men with many others hired at high wages were busy day and night digging through frozen ground from 8 to 12 feet deep in order to reach the water pipe, which suddenly went out of order. We found out that with the heavy and continuous rains of last year the bank had slided imperceptibly, with the aid of storms which raised the river level 4 ft., the waves carrying much earth away, and the pipes had broken at some joints.

We do not intend to present to the Department the accounts for this heavy expenditure incurred at a time when the cold was biting and men all busy at their winter occupations. But we enclose in quadruplicate the account covering the repairs on the Diesel Engine, the amount being £149.13. - There are other side accounts which I have paid myself and which I shall not present.

Had we foreseen such expenditure we would have communicated with the Department, but this was a case of emergency, and the Engine produces our light and operates the water pump, without any substitute (except a 3 H.P. Engine, which may be set for pumping, but which was not in order at the time, parts having been ordered three months before and having not been obtained yet).

Yours truly,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal.

H. McPherson, Indian Agent.

February 23, 1945.

Re: Diesel Engine.

Dear Sir:

As I informed you some time ago, our Diesel Engine refused any more service on December 14th. We obtained from the Manitoba Paper Co., Pine Falls, the service of their specialist in Diesel Engines. He stated that a complete overhaul was necessary. So on December 28th we shipped the engine to Mumford, Medland, Limited, Winnipeg, from whom it was purchased.

We would have liked to ship it sooner, but our men with many others hired at high wages were busy day and night digging through frozen ground from 8 to 12 feet deep in order to reach the water pipe, which suddenly went out of order. We found out that with the heavy and continuous rains of last year the bank had slided imperceptibly, with the aid of storms which raised the river level 4 ft., the waves carrying much earth away, and the pipes had broken at some joints.

We do not intend to present to the Department the accounts for this heavy expenditure incurred at a time when the cold was biting and men all busy at their winter occupations. But we enclose in quadruplicate the account covering the repairs on the Diesel Engine, the amount being $149.15.- There are other side accounts which I have paid myself and which I shall not present.

Had we foreseen such expenditure we would have communicated with the Department, but this was a case of emergency, and the Engine produces our light and operates the water pump, without any substitute (except a 3 H.P. Engine, which may be set for pumping, but which was not in order at the time, parts having been ordered three months before and having not been obtained yet).

Yours truly,

(sgd.) Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

E. McPherson, Indian Agent.
Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
Pine Falls P.O., Man.

Extract from letter from Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, 538 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, Man., dated October 30, 1945.

Fort Alexander Residential School

The dormitories are on the top floor. In case of fire the children must use the inside stairways or slip out onto balconies and descend by sliding down a pole. One pole must be 18' long and for little children to grasp this and step out into space is unsatisfactory. Some children are afraid; then too some drop too quickly and in case of a fire might easily be hurt when landing. I also noticed that the poles, although perhaps secure, wobble and give the appearance of being insecure. I would definitely recommend that the poles be removed and that stairways or some other type of fire escape be erected. This is an old school where, if a fire got started, I doubt if it could be checked; therefore the best and safest fire escapes are required. The fire hose appear in good condition and extinguishers and axes are kept at convenient points throughout the building.
Ottawa, 9th November, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to his inspection of Fort Alexander Residential School, Inspector Hamilton writes as follows:

"The dormitories are on the top floor. In case of fire the children must use the inside stairways or slip out onto balconies and descend by sliding down a pole. One pole must be 18' long and for little children to grasp this and step out into space is unsatisfactory. Some children are afraid; then too some drop too quickly and in case of a fire might easily be hurt when landing. I also noticed that the poles, although perhaps secure, wobble and give the appearance of being insecure. I would definitely recommend that the poles be removed and that stairways or some other type of fire escape be erected. This is an old school where, if a fire got started, I doubt if it could be checked; therefore the best and safest fire escapes are required. The fire hose appear in good condition and extinguishers and axes are kept at convenient points throughout the building."

At the present time it is not possible to make elaborate changes in the fire escape provided at the Fort Alexander School. Possibly you could arrange to have the poles made more secure. I presume that the pupils practice fire drill regularly and if so, past experience shows that if this is done the pupils usually become accustomed to pole type of fire escape.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Ft. Alexander Res. School,
Pine Falls, Manitoba.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, enclosing Fire Inspection Report on the Fort Alexander Residential School.

With reference to page 2 of the report, the following matters should be brought to the attention of the Principal, with a view to having the school staff take the necessary action:

1. Clean, remove and keep oil and grease from accumulating around gasoline motor in laundry.

2. Boiler room door and frame to be covered with metal on the boiler room side and made self-closing.

3. Both doors and frames from boiler room next to laundry to be metal clad on the boiler room side. Said doors to be tight-fitting and self-closing.

4. It is also recommended that regular fire drill be held once a month, having regard to the weather.

As stated in the report, we have a pole type of fire escape on this building. We are not prepared to make any change at the present time. The children should be carefully drilled regarding the method of using the fire escape.

The following recommendation, made by the Inspector,

...... should be
should be considered further:

There being no fire stops or cut-offs between the second and third floors, it is recommended that a fire resistive partition be constructed, equipped with a fire resistive door and frame, either at the bottom or top of the stairways - second floor to third floor. Doors to be self-closing. If glazed, same to be of wire glass in metal frames.

You might let me know what expenditure would be involved in carrying out the above recommendation.

Dear Sir,

I am at last forwarding to you the vouchers which I promised you and which cover the emergency work we had to do on the pipe line and on the sewers on account of another bad land slide between the shop and the Winnipeg River.

The first triplicate vouchers concern the water pipe line, which had broken, and which we had to dig at a great depth and with a very large opening, so as to leave it uncovered all summer. We intend to put on the water pipe line only some moss, which we shall go and gather in the bush this fall at our own expense. Some snow fences will help some safe covering. Being thus lightly covered the pipes should not break any more.

The second triplicate vouchers cover work done on the sewers, which bust on account of the slide. We do not include the cost of cement, gravel and sand.

Father M. Lavigne, provincial, had called some officials to come and inspect the trouble and take the direction of the work. But as none came and as there was danger of typhoid fever, we had to proceed with the work. Brother P. Lefaille helped us much with his experience.

Dear Sir,

Re 125-1-5 W T 1 Ottawa Aug. 8/46.

With reference to the suggestions given by Mr. Neary regarding the Fire Inspection Report, I beg to submit the following observations:

1. Oil and grease around gasoline motor in laundry.
   This motor, being very old, throws oil around, and we have to wait till all the washing is done to clean the oil and grease.

2. Boiler room door and frame to be covered with metal on the boiler room side, and made self-closing.
   If the Department can secure for us some thick metal, together with the door lock, we will be ready to install them.

3. Both doors and frames from boiler room next to laundry to be metal clad on the boiler room side. Said doors to be tight fitting and self-closing.
   If the Department can procure some thick metal, and locks, for both doors, we will install them.

4. Fire drill once a month. We have drills oftener.

Fire-resistive partitions as cut-offs between the second and third floor.
   These partitions, to my estimation, would render the staircases much darker, and could not be so very effective in a frame building, where fires generally go up between the walls from one story to the other in no time.

The main object to consider is the safe and speedy evacuation of pupils in case of fire.
   Our present system of fire escape is not adequate.
   Mr. Hamilton, Inspector, wrote last fall to the Department, but Mr. Phelan stated that no changes could be made.
   The Fire Commissioner also noted the inadequacy in his report, but again no change can be made at the present time.
   This pole system during the night in bad weather would not be safe especially one pole that is so high, going from the dormitory to the ground (through 2 stories).
   I would not be in favour of wooden stair cases outside, as in winter they would be icy and slippery.
   The best system would be a chute escape of the type that they have in some day schools of Winnipeg. This system is safe and speedy, especially for smaller children.
   I wish we could obtain at least one chute escape to replace the long pipe, of which the children are afraid.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal

MEMORANDUM

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
Pine Falls, Manitoba.

With reference to your marginal notation of June 4th on a memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs dated May 30th last, in which the desire is expressed to have a cylindrical steel chute fire escape erected at the above school to replace a pole type fire escape, you are advised as follows:

Since our letter of October 3rd, 1946, quoting an estimated sum of $800.00 for supply and installation of a cylindrical chute type of fire escape, the cost of materials and labour have so risen as to make this type of construction uneconomical.

A modern straight slide escape, provided space permits, or standard steel fire escape would provide adequate exit accommodation with access to the ground and either type can be recommended.

As the Indian Affairs record plans and drawings available in this office do not clearly indicate storey heights, window openings, and distance above floors of same, it will be necessary, in order to comply with the requirements of the National Building Code regarding exits and fire escapes, that measurements be obtained on the site by an officer from Winnipeg.

We are therefore requesting Mr. Gow to make arrangements to obtain the necessary data for our information.

The Indian Affairs Branch should be advised of the action we are taking, and that with the existing condition of the construction industry, there can be no assurance that Mr. Gow will be able to obtain tenders for the work.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6266, file 579-5, part 9)
July 24, 1947.

Memorandum

Ref: Fort Alexander Indian Residential School - Pine Falls, Manitoba.

Further to our memorandum of June 18, we are now in receipt of plans of the above school prepared from measurements taken on the site by Mr. W.H. Wallace with Mr. Persooge of Mr. Gow's staff.

From the Indian Affairs record drawings available in this office, we were under the impression that the building was a brick structure, and accordingly recommended metal fire escapes. From the information now to hand, the school is of frame construction on masonry foundations, and four pole type fire escapes are shown on the building, two on the rear wall and one each on end walls.

Under these circumstances, an outside enclosed stairway of wood frame construction, leading to the ground and having exit doors equipped with panic bolts would provide cover from the elements and prevent entry from the outside by unauthorized persons. This type of fire escape serving a wood frame building complies with the requirements of the National Building Code for structures of this nature and height.

Two fire escapes of this type should replace the two pole type escapes on the rear wall of the school. The two end pole escapes are somewhat more difficult to replace and would necessitate alterations to enclosed verandah and stairs to main floor open verandahs.

Some difficulty has been experienced in the past in getting contractors to quote a reasonable price for the erection of iron fire escapes at outlying schools. Similar difficulty should not be encountered in a wood frame escape and the cost should be considerably reduced. Our estimate of the cost of two wood frame enclosed stairs is in the neighborhood of $2,500.00 and an additional $1,000.00 to replace end pole escapes, a total of $3,500.00. As a comparison the estimated cost of two iron fire escapes on the rear wall is $4,000.00.

If the above proposal meets with approval, we shall be pleased to proceed with the preparation of drawings and specifications as soon thereafter as staff can be assigned.

T.S. Melo
Chief Engineer

Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,

It is since March 1st, 1926, that we have tried time and again to obtain electricity from the Hydro Commission. RE: Power Transmission Line,
Fort Alexander I.R. Pine Falls.

This report deals with the proposed Power Transmission Line and pending installation of same by Winnipeg Electric Co., at an early date for Fort Alexander Indian Reserve at Pine Falls, Manitoba.

Apparently this important development has been a live issue since 1938 when a survey conducted by Winnipeg Electric Company indicated this project could be effected at an approximate expenditure of $6000.00. For some time thereafter this was not approved for execution, and obviously during the war years lay dormant for apparent reasons.

Now I am informed by Father Brachet, Principal of R.C. Residential School, Fort Alexander that this was discussed by him personally with some Departmental Officials at Ottawa and a favorable consideration is pending.

Inspector Hamilton delegated the writer to explore status of this venture with the Winnipeg Electric Co., and report further.

Mr. Merritt, Assistant Manager, Electric Sales, Winnipeg Electric Company was interviewed and he informs me that his Company is now in a position to fulfill this program, and if all factors required are complied with that all installations could be completed before freeze-up this fall.

Company requirements are as follows:

1. A petition from Residential School and potential users of electric service to Company at Winnipeg.

2. A meeting of Chief and Council approving development on Reserve.
3. Departmental (Indian Affairs Branch) approval along with #2.

4. Authority to install power line along highway for lessened installation costs to Indian homes which border on highway.

5. Company requires right of way for repairs of line.

6. Original cost estimate 1938 basis of $6000.00 likely to increase by some 30% to 50% today. Electric Company to stand some unspecified expense or amount depending on business possibilities.

7. Company will make new survey re engineering problems, installation, etc., also survey all potential users for electric service at own expense.

8. If foregoing satisfactory they will forthwith proceed, and assume complete installation of transmission line could be accomplished this fall and installation to home users to follow immediately.

Visiting Fort Alexander Reserve I contacted Councillors Paul Courchene and John Moirisseau both of whom are most favorable, in fact, enthusiastic about development. Several band members seen and all likewise in accord. Needless to say Father Brachet was delighted and immediately undertook to obtain petition to Company on behalf of users.

It seems indicated that costs will approximate eight to nine thousand dollars today. I am assuming the appropriation for this development was discussed with B.F. Neary, Supt., of Welfare and Training.

Personally I would strongly urge the favorable consideration of this meritorious development. The far reaching benefits accruing, especially re obtaining electric refrigeration for food is of prime importance. The band members have been hoping for this for years and the residential school would so greatly benefit. I think this development a great forward step and unhesitatingly recommend its approval.

I respectfully request your comments at an early date as to proposed action on this matter.

B.E. Olson,

Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,

October 9, 1947.

B. E. Olson, Indian Agent,
Selkirk.

Dear Sir,

Yesterday three men of the Winnipeg Electric Co. came from Great Falls to measure the length of the road, together with the number of curves, starting at the Pine Falls Hydro line on this side of the railroad track coming this way to Fort Alexander. When they reached Chief John Thompson's place, he stopped them and sent them back, telling them that white people had no business to come to the reserve without his permission and insulting them heavily.

Before returning, they came to consult me. I told them to proceed, but they did not dare until I brought the Chief to reason, which took quite a time.

I told him that this was only a survey for a report to the Indian Affairs Branch, which is interested in supplying electricity for the two schools, that he could hardly stop this improvement for the two government schools, that the Indians did not have to take this convenience unless they really wished to have it. For him the government or anybody else has no right to step on the reserve, that an exorbitant price would have to be paid for the use of the land regarding the poles, that the Indians would not be fooled any more as they had been by the Manitoba Paper Co., that the two schools were no good as they had failed to form any one for a high public office, that the Indians were all against the use of electricity, telephone, etc... First he did not want to speak to me at all as I had not told him beforehand that these men were coming, but finally he agreed to let them finish their work.

The foreman was quite upset about it, and though quite big, he felt all shaken. I thought they would not come any more, but they were here today, although the road was wet with rain, and they must have finished their work.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal.

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Residential School

My visit to this school was unexpected but I found the school throughout in its usual immaculate condition. The boy's playroom has been refloored with cement and painted. It is now bright and cheerful and a splendid recreation room.

There are enrolled 105 pupils but the Principal expects to take in another 6 or 8 shortly. The classrooms are nicely arranged and are bright and cheerful. The pupils are making fair progress and their exercise books show careful work.

The dormitories were well aired, tidy and clean. The beds were neatly made and supplied with plenty of bedding.

The children were well clothed and clean. Their health appears good and I am convinced they are well fed.

The fire escapes remain the same. I understand a full report with pictures was submitted by Mr. Gow, District Chief Engineer, Surveys and Engineer Branch, months ago. Dr. Keenleyside on his visit was much concerned about the present pole fire escape and expressed the opinion that action to make secure the present poles and build extra escapes should not be delayed. I was indeed surprised to learn this week that no action has apparently been taken on the report already submitted. I would urge that action be taken at once to correct the present unsatisfactory condition.

The sewing room in all boarding schools is one of the busiest departments and I found this one no exception. Last year two new Singer sewing machines were supplied - these have helped greatly. However, other old machines must yet be replaced as they are past repairing. I would recommend that two more new machines be supplied.

The kitchen is a heavy department but the Sister in charge is doing an excellent piece of work. The range has no warming oven and this is a great inconvenience. A warming oven for a McClary, two oven and one fire pot type of stove is required. I recommend it be supplied.

Another requirement urgently needed is a refrigerator. I would suggest the present fruit storage space off the pantry as a suitable location to install the equipment. I am recommending this equipment believing the Department will approve the necessary expense in supplying the Hydro power to this school. I understand a definite proposition has been submitted which is considered reasonable and if this is correct the line should be built with as little delay as possible. Mr. Olson, the Indian Agent, has this matter in hand and will submit a complete report with his recommendation.

The pupils at this school appear very happy and I consider Father Brachet operates a very excellent school. The children are well treated, well fed and clothed and have a splendid opportunity to fit themselves with an all round useful education.

Rev. Father:-

Re Hydro Line.

Immediately on my return from Ottawa in May I went to see the Manager of the Winnipeg Electric Co. at Great Falls. It was only on my third trip there that I was able to see him. Afterwards he came to see me here and discuss the installation of a power line from Pine Falls to the school.

The great objection that the company had was the scarcity of material and labour. Later on the company was agreeable to contemplate the possibility of a line extension, but it wanted a petition to that effect, with the names of the probable users, and the proposed location of the line. All this was forwarded on August 19th. We were informed on Sept. 6th that their representative, H. Vialoux, would make a survey some time after his holidays. I went with him back and forth all the way between Fort Alexander and Pine Falls, contacting the possible users of electricity and measuring the distance from the highway. On Oct. 8th three men came from Great Falls to measure the length of the road, together with the number of curves. When they came opposite Chief John Thompson's place, they were ordered to return loaded with insults. After much arguing I induced the chief to let them finish their task.

On Oct. 25th I asked the Company to give an estimate of the present cost of a transmission line to the school. I herewith submit the answer given on the 5th inst.

I would have wished that at least the poles would have been planted before the frost sets in, so as to tie the sum of $6,000.00 appropriated for the purpose, but before the Indian Affairs Branch takes a decision and the Indian Council here agrees, it shall be too late likely.

The Chief, who complains that there is no progress and who in the same time hinders all progress as much as he can, is not in favour of an electric transmission line, but the great majority of Indians are in favour. If their approbation is necessary, it should be obtained early. Mr. B. E. Olson, Inspector of the Clandeboye Agency, Selkirk, states that there is on record at Ottawa a lease right covering this problem.

Besides the Residential school and the Catholic Mission, the Indian day school, the Anglican mission, and the former store of the H.B.C., there would be at least 15 families that would use not only the lights, but also electric appliances, such as frigidaires, motors...

Miss Alice McCready found our ice house very poor and wished for us a frigidaire.

Sincerely,
