Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 15th instant, file 202-11, reporting on your recent inspection of the Fort Alexander Residential School.

With regard to the fire escapes, this matter was brought to the attention of the Department in a letter from Acting Agent Hughes, dated September 27th, 1946. We referred the request to the Surveys and Engineering Branch and on October 3rd, 1946, they advised us that from the drawings of the school on their files, they estimated the cost of a cylindrical steel chute type of fire escape at $600.00.

Consequently, we included this amount in our appropriation for the year 1947-48.

In memorandum dated July 26th, 1947, the Surveys and Engineering Branch advised us that one of the members of their staff had recently visited the school and from the measurements and information given by their officer, they expressed the opinion that it would be necessary to construct two wood frame enclosed stairs at a cost of approximately $2,500, and that an additional amount of $1,000 would be required to replace the end pale escapes.

You will note that this meant an expenditure of approximately $3,500, and as funds for the purpose were not available in the current year's
appropriation we advised Surveys and Engineering not to proceed with the work.

The information just given regarding fire escapes has been supplied Superintendent Olson in our letter of November 19th. In that letter he was also authorized to make immediate repairs to the boiler room doors in order to reduce the fire hazard. We also told him that we were prepared to supply additional fire extinguishers on receipt of information from him stating how many are actually required.

He was also advised that the Department was prepared to allow an amount of $40.00 a month towards the salary of a night watchman.

We will order the two new sewing machines and also the warming oven.

We hope to be able to make arrangements for Hydro power to this school next year. In the meantime you might let us know the size of the room in which you consider refrigeration equipment could be installed. If you can obtain a quotation on installing this equipment from a firm in Winnipeg, you might also forward this for our consideration.

Fire Protection.

and he was surprised that we did not have any yet, but I remarked to him that he had failed to mark them in his last year's report, and he noticed with regret that he had forgotten to write them down.

Re: Power Transmission Line,
Fort Alexander E.R., Pine Falls, Man.

Considerable correspondence is on file relating to above matter along with definite proposal by Winnipeg Electric Company as to costs and required pre-requisites to proceed to erection. Inasmuch as funds were not available in last year's estimates to defray costs but were included in 1948-49 estimates it is desired to bring this to issue at earliest possible date.

To obtain electric power on the Fort Alexander Reserve has been a live issue more or less since 1938. Last year this came to head when Winnipeg Electric Co., indicated they could proceed providing their requirements could be met. It has been discussed in Chief and Council meetings, and Band meetings, and, with countless band members. Aside from Chief Thompson and small group who do as he says there is general endorsement of this forward step. A special Band Meeting was called March 9th essentially to discuss the acceptance of Power Transmission Line to Reserve. A well attended meeting resulted and after full discussion participated in by every Councillor, Chief and band members, also Father Brabbert, Principal of Indian Residential School, and Canon Walters, Anglican minister a standing vote was taken which resulted in overwhelming endorsement of the proposal. Only Chief Thompson and about four band members did not vote in favor, but, incidentally merely refrained from voting.

Following this meeting I travelled to northern Reserves and on my return to Selkirk received a letter signed by Chief Thompson that he desired to take the matter up with Indian Association of Manitoba before approving. No meeting has been held since and according to my information no meeting is contemplated in near future. Accordingly I proceeded to Pine Falls to interview Chief Thompson and find he has gone out trapping and is not expected to return for at least a month.
The time is now arriving that this matter should be dealt with. The Winnipeg Electric Company has stated its proposal. It would now be appreciated to hear Departmental requirements so this matter can be dealt with as relates to what this need do to further this essential development.

B.E. Olson,
Superintendent,
Clandeboye Agency.

July 7, 1923.

Dear Mr. Foran,-

We are erecting a barn at the Fort Alexander Indian boarding school, and, as the contract is now being awarded, it will be necessary for us to appoint someone to act as Inspector of the Work during the construction of the building. Last year when an annex was erected to this school we employed Rev. Father Bousquet, the Principal of the school, to act as inspector of that work. He performed the duties in a most satisfactory manner, and we desire, if it is possible under the regulations of the Civil Service Commission, to have him appointed this year to inspect the work during the construction of the barn. The school is in an isolated location and to send in an outside man would entail a great deal of expense that is quite unnecessary. Winnipeg is the nearest point. We would have to pay the expenses of an inspector to and from Winnipeg, his maintenance while at the school inspecting the work, and his services would cost a great deal more than Father Bousquet is willing to accept, namely, $100.00 per month.

Incl.- I am inclosing requisition herewith, and, as Father Bousquet is quite capable of performing the work, I would ask that you accede to our request and have him appointed without competition.

Dear Sir,

Re 125-1-5 (El)

In answer to your inquiry of the 8th inst. regarding our 12 H.P. Engine, I beg to submit the following information.

On July 31, 1940, we obtained from Mumford, Medland Limited, of Winnipeg, one 10 H.P. K.W. Lister Diesel Engine, with one 6 K.W. Shunt Wound Battery Charging Generator, for the sum of $947.00.

The account was paid by a school cheque No. 275 on October 19, 1940.

The engine was overhauled in Dec. 1944, and is presently in good running condition.

The main work of the engine, besides operating the charging generator, is to revolve the water pump (Myers Self-oiling Bulldozer No. 315), which on wash days is running continually and on other days at very frequent periods.

Even after we obtain the hydro-electricity, the engine shall be precious to produce a supply of light when the line is defective during or after storms.

There is much animosity among the protestant element of the reserve against the transmission line and it is hard to say what some individuals may do in the matter of interference, though I hope that the line shall not be cut.

In short if we would dispose of the engine, we would need another one in its place. As it is, the engine is well set on a specially built foundation.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I., Principal.

Dear Sir:

Further to the inspection which was made on October 29th of the electrical equipment and wiring at the above school, the Department recommends the following changes:

1. That all outlets with drop cords and sockets be removed, and that ceiling fixtures or porcelain receptacles be installed.
2. That both sewing rooms on second floor be equipped with separate circuits complete with pilot lights for use of electric irons.
3. That the return condensate pump and the small furnace room be re-wired in conduit.
4. Temporary wiring in basement hall to be removed and wired in approved manner, and a plug be installed for Projector Machine, and wiring made available for the connection of X-Ray equipment.
5. That an approved type fire alarm system be installed in the school with a signal bell located in the Father's residence.
6. That exit lights be installed above all exit doors controlled from a separate circuit.
7. That a new service and distribution be installed in the Boiler Room with a minimum capacity of the main switch rated at 200 amps. If it is the intention of the school at a later date to install hot water heating and electric ranges we would recommend that the service switch be of ample capacity for any future load.
8. Secondary lines of ample capacity to be run overhead to supply Father's residence, Church, work shop, barns and residences.

The general condition of the wiring throughout all buildings was found to be very good and no re-wiring is necessary other than the few recommendations which have been previously stated.

Any further assistance you may require in this matter the Department will cooperate to the fullest extent.

November 14, 1948

It is to be appreciated that contracting work in an old institution takes into account probable cost factors which must be allowed in tender. Actual performance of work may greatly reduce the cost and the proposal with a reliable company like S.A. Johnson and Company would be to the Department's advantage.

I wish to report that I have checked probable costs and find foregoing tender very low. Mr. Watson, Inspector, Department of Labor, thoroughly familiar with estimate as to cost, and who thoroughly examined and inspected the school expected a tender for $4,000.00. Therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending acceptance of tender in "A".

I would draw to your attention the important recommendation for safety re fire hazard in points 5 and 6 of Inspector's report. This is a "must" for this school. You are familiar with previous correspondence regarding fire hazards. A proper alarm system is our first essential - fire escapes will, no doubt, be considered later.

There is reason for gratification that wiring throughout school and buildings was found to be satisfactory and no re-wiring necessary. This represents a saving of several thousand dollars.

Re Refrigerator.

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

With reference to your letter of November 16th, file 579-5 (E), the sliding pole fire escapes now in use at the above mentioned school, extend to the second storey, and in view of the long drop are not satisfactory. However, in our schools where the pole extends to a veranda, it more or less makes the drop very short and the children are not nervous about going down them.

The Rev. Father Ruest is very much against sliding pole fire escapes, for while they might be satisfactory for older children, the younger children will not use them because of the drop; also, the drop is so sudden it might break their legs.

I am quite aware that it would be very expensive to go into a wholesale replacement of fire escapes, but I feel that at this school, a wooden chute could be built - covered with tin. This should answer the purpose and be much less expensive. I must admit, however, that the stairway type of fire escape is far the best, but the cost is too high.

Please advise me if you consider I should get prices on a wooden fire escape, or if you think it is better to put in the steel one.

Ottawa, Nov. 23rd, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School requesting to be supplied with a young Holstein bull for the use of the Fort Alexander Band and school herd.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the supplying of this animal, and you may therefore arrange for the purchase of the same. It would be advisable to consult Dr. J. B. Still, Room 711, Boyd Building, Winnipeg, who is the Agent of the Health of Animals Branch, Department of Agriculture, and who would, no doubt, assist you in purchasing a pure bred bull. Before purchasing, you should make sure that the animal selected is free from tuberculosis and has been inspected by a Veterinary. The Department will expect you to obtain this animal as cheaply as possible, and when the purchase has been made, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. This animal should be kept in charge of the Principal at the school, and should be available for the use of both the school and band herds. The cost involved in the purchase will be divided equally between the funds at the credit of the band and Parliamentary appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

In the month of December last you were kind enough to grant us a pure blood bull to improve the herd at the school and on the reserve. Before it was brought over it was examined by a Veterinary Surgeon of the Department of Agriculture of Manitoba, and found to be perfectly sound. In fact, during all of last Winter he seemed to be in perfect health.

In the Spring, we let him run around with the cattle of the reserve and part of ours, as this was understood at the time of the purchase. Unfortunately being in contact with some diseased animals during the month of July he started to weaken and get thin. We isolated him to treat him in some special manner, until at the end of October he died with all the symptoms of tuberculosis, coughing, ejection through the nose, difficulty in breathing, choking, etc.

I regret sincerely this Holstein bull, as he was beautiful and promising for the reproduction. Today we are left without a bull worth while. If, after this sad happening, I was not shy I would ask the Government to replace the one we have lost and if you were kind enough to grant us another one, I would be infinitely thankful.

Dear Father Brachet:

I am enclosing herewith three photos received by the Department from the Anglican Missionary stationed at Trout Lake, in northern Ontario.

It would appear that this missionary purchased three or four goats two or three years ago at Winnipeg. In his letter he states that these animals have contributed substantially to the physical fitness of his Indian population. The Indians, it would appear, enjoy both the milk and the meat of these animals.

I have discussed with Inspector Hamilton on more than one occasion the desirability of securing goats for a number of Indian reserves in the province of Manitoba, particularly Indian reserves where milk is scarce and where relief costs are high. Goats are immune from tuberculosis and their milk if widely used by the Indians would, I feel sure, tend to arrest the ravages of tuberculosis among young Indians.

I am anxious that you should discuss with Father Plourde the desirability of securing three or four goats and establishing these at your school by way of experiment. It would be, in my judgment, a fine thing if you could place these goats in the care of three or four of the senior pupils, in the hope that these students after graduation would feel disposed to care for such animals. April 26, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of April 1 addressed to the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources in which you offer, on behalf of the Reverend Oblate Fathers, to establish a hospital for Indians on lands belonging to your Order beside the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. The Honourable the Minister had at the same time a proposal from the Abitibi Pulp and Paper Company Limited in respect to the provision of hospital accommodation for Indians at the town of Pine Falls. He has decided to accept the proposal of the Company as regards hospital accommodation for ordinary sick and injured Indians.

I am directed to express the gratitude of the Department for your offer to establish a general hospital and to ask whether, in view of the Honourable the Minister's decision, your Order would be willing to establish an institution for the special purpose described hereafter.

It is the Department's hope to enter upon a program for the control of Tuberculosis among the Indians of Manitoba with special reference to the elimination of this disease from the Indian Residential Schools. From rather extensive surveys of these schools in that and other Provinces it has been found that there are two classes of children suffering from Tuberculosis. The one

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
c/o University of Ottawa
Laurier Avenue East
Ottawa, Ont.
class consists of pupils who have the disease in a definitely active form and for whom the only effective treatment must be carried out in sanatoria specially designed and equipped for this purpose such as the institutions at St. Vital and Ninette. The other group includes children who are only slightly affected and who have the prospect of becoming fit for ordinary school life after a period of special care extending over a year or two during which they can carry on their studies in a modified degree. They may remain pupils of the school but they require extra care, rest and feeding, and should be segregated from the other pupils for the sake of both groups.

Experience in other Provinces suggests that in the three accessible schools under the charge of your Church in Manitoba there might be found from twenty to thirty children of this latter class. The Department is convinced that for the efficient conduct of their isolation they should be in a place where they are under the frequent and careful supervision of a Physician and where that Physician can secure regular periodical advice from a specialist in Tuberculosis based on his personal examination of the pupils.

It will be agreed that these conditions obtain at Fort Alexander in a degree which would be impossible at Sandy Bay and Pine Creek, and the Department's proposal is that your Order should establish at the Fort Alexander school, in the building under discussion, a section for the accommodation of this class of pupil from that school and the other two schools mentioned above. I wish to make it clear that this institution would be designed only for pupils belonging to your Church. They would remain school pupils with at least nominal attachment to the schools to which they belong. These schools would
receive the usual grant for their education and in addition the Department is prepared to pay annually a sum sufficient to provide the additional cost of special food and the services of a graduate nurse or nursing Sister. At other units of this kind this has worked out at about $1000 per annum.

The plan, of course, is designed for the rehabilitation of pupils who are found to have been admitted to the schools after all precautions have been taken to exclude those who are actively tubercular. It is not intended to serve as a means of providing hospital accommodation for tubercular Indian children at large.

I recommend this proposal to the careful and, I hope, favourable consideration of your Order. It is based on the best advice the Department has been able to secure from recognized authorities on Tuberculosis as the means of solution of what has come to be regarded as the most accessible key to the control of Tuberculosis in the Prairie Provinces at any cost which might be approved by Parliament. It is possible that the Department is asking for some slight financial co-operation on the part of your Order but it will do its best to ensure that the Order is not put to any substantial expense. It has the advantage which I think will appeal to you of retaining the school status of these children, a status which it might well be impossible to retain under any other plan of procedure.

I am authorized to lay this proposal before you and I shall hope for fairly early consideration of it as the Department is anxious to be able to plan a definite program, of which this would be a part, to be got into operation as nearly as possible at the beginning of the new school year in September.

Yours very truly,

My Dear Doctor McGill:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 26th 1937 in which you ask whether our Order would be prepared to cooperate with the Department of Indian Affairs in the establishment of a health unit in which certain cases of T.B. Indian children might be taken care of as far as their health is concerned whilst receiving at the same time that amount of education which their condition might permit.

Your proposal is that this institution be located at Fort Alexander and that arrangements be made to receive therein from twenty (20) to thirty (30) children who are slightly affected by tuberculosis and who can be made fit for ordinary school life if given special care and diet for a period of a year or two.

I am authorized by Reverend Father Lamontagne, Provincial of the Manitoba Province, to advise you that the Oblate Fathers are prepared to establish a sanatorium or a preventorium at Fort Alexander for the purposes above set forth. However, after examining carefully the building which we had offered to the Department for hospital purposes we have come to the conclusion that only part of that building can be used for a preventorium and that we will have to build an addition at least 30 x 35 with full basement and two stories to accommodate the number of children.

that you mention in your letter. The last estimate that we have been able to secure for this building and also for the alterations needed for the new existing building is $6,000. We are prepared to advance this amount but must naturally look to a revenue that will at least take care of the interest and the other carrying charges such as heat, light and general upkeep. We are confident that if the number of these children can be set at thirty (30) as you mention in your letter that such expenses can be provided out of the revenue now proposed to be given by the Department for the upkeep and running of such institutions.

Your proposal to have just one such institution for all the Catholic children in the territory served by the Pine Creek, Sandy Bay and Fort Alexander schools may not be very practical on account of distances and lack of transportation facilities. Camperville is about three hundred (300) miles from Winnipeg and Fort Alexander is another one hundred (100) miles, so that the distance between the Reserves in the district of Pine Creek and Fort Alexander is at least four hundred (400) miles. Transportation facilities as stated above are not good and we feel that parents will have very serious objections to allowing their children to be taken away so far because they will not have much chance to see them. It might also work to the detriment of these children because they would be very homesick and their mental state might make their progress to normal health very difficult.
3- Dr. Harold W. McGill.

Possibly the best solution of the case would be the establishment of two such health institutions or preventoriums, one in Fort Alexander and the other in Pine Creek. As the expenses connected with an establishment of this nature will be quite heavy we are not prepared to go ahead this year with both of them but we might be able to do so next year.

Our architect is now drawing plans for the Fort Alexander establishment and we expect to be in a position to commence building operations about the last of July. Given propitious weather we are satisfied that the building can be completed by about the first or at the latest the fifteenth of September.

Before bringing this letter to a conclusion I cannot refrain from expressing our disappointment at the refusal of the Department to accept our offer of establishing a general hospital on the Fort Alexander Reserve for the care of sick Indians of every category. Our offer carried no demand upon the Department for funds and neither were extra fees for the care of the sick Indians asked for. Instead of accepting our offer the Department has given a very substantial grant to the Abitibi Power Company and our sick Indians will certainly be in an environment which will not be conducive to the attainment of the best results neither from a mental or moral point of view. The Churches have done so much for the Indians in the past and they
are prepared to cooperate with the Department so wholeheartedly that offers of the nature of the one made by the Reverend Oblate Fathers should not be refused to give consideration to plans of groups or companies which are here today and may be gone tomorrow.

The above statement is made without any acrimony on our part but we think it was essential for us to state our position as clearly as possible.

Reverend Sir:

I regret the delay in replying to your letter of June 12 in which you accept the Department's proposal to have the outside building at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School adapted for what has come to be known as a preventorium. The Medical Services of the Department have been occupied by the convention of the Canadian Medical Association and particularly with a meeting of a committee on tuberculosis at which were represented the Provincial Governments and tuberculosis health authorities from all parts of the country; in fact it was thought well to ascertain the views of that committee before going further with this and one or two other projects of the same kind which have been under consideration.

The Tuberculosis Committee gave a good deal of attention to this phase of tuberculosis work among Indian children and was convinced of its value. I believe that your Order will come to regard this institution as very valuable and will be pleased that the Department urged you to adopt this plan, rather than the other you had in mind.

I gather from your letter that you are prepared to advance $6,000 to adapt the building to its intended use and that you are willing to do this if you can look forward to having at all times about 30 children.

Re: Preventorium at Fort Alexander.

Dear Mr. Hamilton,

To supplement and confirm our conversation on the above subject, I wish to make the following comments:

Three questions immediately arise, namely:

1. Are there enough suitable cases to fill thirty beds?
2. Would the Preventorium plan really make a substantial contribution to the Indian tuberculosis problem?
3. If not, how can the plan be improved?

I shall deal with each of these problems separately.

1. Are there available cases?

It is presumed that the proposed unit will be run along the lines usually implied by the word "Preventorium", i.e., the inmates will all be in the following classes:

a. They shall be of school age, i.e., six to sixteen and of both sexes.
b. They shall not have open tuberculous lesions of any sort and will therefore be non-infectious.
c. They shall all be fit for ambulant treatment and will be up and about most of the time.
d. They shall not require intensive medical or surgical treatment.

The above is the usual conception of a Preventorium case. It will be found that very few such cases are actually in territory tributary to Fort Alexander.

A real Preventorium case is not really a clinical entity. It is an abstraction built on the assumption that doctors can predict by examination what children are likely to contract tuberculosis. This is, of course, not so. It is certainly true that children who have had contact with open tuberculosis are the only ones who ultimately get tuberculosis. But all contacts cannot be cared for in an institution. Even if they were, there is no assurance that there would ultimately be less tuberculosis among them. The same applies to those with a positive tuberculin test and those with healed childhood lesions. The possibility that contacts with open tuberculosis would be broken for children in a Preventorium might operate in their favor. This breaking of contact should, however, be accomplished for all Indian children in boarding schools without providing separate buildings. This could be done by frequent tuberculin tests and x-ray examinations.
2. Would the Preventorium plan make a substantial contribution to the Indian tuberculosis problem?

The death rate in infants—which is said to be high—would obviously be unaffected. Also just as many would be infected up to going to school. While in the Preventorium there would presumably be less spread of infection. This would, however, probably not be absolute. Among thirty suspects or alleged closed cases there would always be some who would become "open." Indeed the criteria by which we have previously judged cases to be "open" or "closed" have recently been brought into question. In any event, a very close scrutiny would need to be kept to prevent spread in the institution.

But suppose no such spread took place, what will be the position of these children when discharged to their old environment at the age of fifteen or sixteen? Will the fact that they have been in Preventorium prevent them from breaking down at the usual age (sixteen to thirty-five)? Probably not. Since a larger number than usual will possibly be tuberculin negative, the reverse may quite possibly happen; i.e., they may be more susceptible.

The crux of the whole tuberculosis problem in Indians is no different than in whites, i.e., sources of contamination must be removed by treatment and isolation. The Preventorium plan does not do this and it would seem a misuse of funds if they were spent on anything so fantastic when there are so many other urgent necessities.

3. Can the plan be improved?

An institution at Fort Alexander might possibly contribute something if it went right out to treat tuberculosis among young Indians in the ordinary way. It might be arranged that patients be sent into Sanatorium for a few weeks or months observation and when considered suitable be transferred to Fort Alexander where they could continue modified Sanatorium care and pneumothorax if necessary. Even then I feel that there would never be enough of school age Indian children to fill thirty beds. However, I suppose the age limit for inmates could be changed. Such an institution, properly supervised, might develop into a very useful organization.

The plans of the new building which you showed me are quite good except that there are no single wards whatever, and when one is treating many children facilities for isolation is imperative otherwise you would be almost always harassed with inter-current infectious diseases.

I hope you will not consider these opinions as being merely destructive. They are offered in complete candor and sincerity and I think the opinions given are those generally held by all those experienced in the treatment of tuberculosis.

I feel that this whole matter should be referred to the Committee recently appointed in Ottawa for the consideration of the Indian problem in Canada.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

December 22, 1937

Dear Sir:

The Manitoba Sanatorium Board, following its recent tuberculosis survey of your school reports that the following pupils should be kept under observation: Bernadette Catcheway, Eva Nepinak, Richard Cook, Bertha Tanner and Alfred Mintuck. Re Preventorium

Dear Father Brachet:

Under date of December 22nd, 1937, I received a letter from the director of Indian Affairs, Dr. McGill, in regard to the above institution. As you will note from his letter, (which I have shown you), Dr. McGill is taking a personal interest in this institution. Just what financial aid has been provided by the department I do not know, consequently we must, consistent with giving adequate care to the children, keep a close eye on expenditures. The success or failure of this institution will apparently have a decided bearing on the department's policy in respect to the establishment of similar institutions elsewhere. We must therefore use every effort towards seeing that children admitted are given every chance to benefit during the timespent in the institution, and it follows that complete and careful records of each child be kept for the Department's later information as well as for our own guidance in the matter of treatment.

The following is an outline for the general conduct of the Preventorium. Although we will probably find as time goes by that it will be necessary to modify it. Personally I consider this work among Indian children of vital importance, as in such a Preventorium the child is removed from danger of infection, and by improving his health we increase his resistance to any infection which he has already received, and prevent the development of clinical or active TB.

Rules Governing Admission to Preventorium: No child with TB of the lungs is to be admitted, nor any with a discharging tuberculous wound, nor any child which by reason of any discharge or excretion might be considered a menace to others.

Children from Other than Fort Alexander Reserves: These children will be detained at the Fort Alexander Indian Hospital, Pine Falls, for a complete examination, prior to being admitted to the Preventorium. This examination to include an X-ray of the chest, and when found necessary inoculation for Small Pox, Diphtheria, etc. Experience shows also that children with large and diseased Tonsils are slow in making recovery from any illness, and are also found to be largely the cause of the prevalence of colds in institutions, consequently in these cases Tonsil operations will be done. In connection with these operations it is necessary to have the consent of the parents. Would you therefore be good enough to ask the Rev. Fathers in charge of such schools as may send children to the Preventorium, to secure, and forward to you the written consent of the parents of such children, to have Tonsil and Adenoid operations done where deemed necessary.

Clinical Records to be Kept: I have provided from the supplies of the Fort Alexander Hospital regular hospital charts for your use. On admission, Charts must show the child's family history, especially in regard to TB. Also the weight, height, and temperature, with the pulse rate. Temperatures should be taken twice daily, and
noted on the chart. Each child should be accurately weighed once a week, and weight noted on the chart. It is exceedingly important that these records be kept as they will give us the best indication as to whether the children are improving or otherwise.

I am asking the department to supply the Preventorium the following:

1. Scale with measuring rod attached.
2. 3 dozen Clinical Thermometers.
3. A supply of Iron Tonic and Cod Liver Oil.
4. Sufficient hospital charts for a year's use.

Now as to the ordinary operation of the Preventorium, the following is a suggested Daily Routine.

7 A.M. Children Arise—Wash, dress, and make their beds.
Temperatures taken and noted on their charts. Examination is made for any acute infection. If any adverse signs are found the child is to be removed to the isolation ward provided for that purpose, and the Medical Officer notified.

7:50 A.M. Breakfast.
8:25 A.M. Dental Toilet
8:30 A.M. School
10:30 A.M. Return from school and play outside until 11:45 A.M.
12 P.M. Noon Meal
12:30 P.M. Rest period for one hour.
1:30 P.M. School—One hour
2:30 P.M. Afternoon lunch, play outside until 4:30 P.M.
5 P.M. Evening Meal
5:45 P.M. Shower Baths, evening temperature, (which is noted on the chart.)
7 P.M. To bed.

I am attaching a suggested typical menu for a week. This can be modified where necessary.

Medication: Each child is to have a tablespoon of Cod Liver Oil twice a day, and a Teaspoon of Iron Tonic once a day, routinely. In addition it would be advisable around the noon period to have each child take a sun bath for about 15 or 20 minutes.

Dentistry: I will ask the department to arrange to have a Dentist make periodic visits to the school in order to see that the children's teeth are kept in proper order.

School work: I would suggest that during the warm months that an open air class room be set up. This could be done near the school on the river bank, and I believe will be found of definite value. In addition to the ordinary class work could you arrange to have classes given in basketry, sewing, fish net making, shoe repairing, and some modelling and painting to those who show special aptitude for that type of work. Nature talks and the life history of Native birds, flowers, and insects, giving special attention to those insects which are a pest in gardens would be instructive as well as interesting. I will be glad to assist your staff by taking over some of these nature study lessons myself, if you think it will be of any assistance. In addition to the above, if you could arrange with one of your staff to give ordinary Setting Up exercises daily it would be of advantage.

Building: The Preventorium, as I feel admirably suited for its purpose. There is a large unobstructed, heated basement, (60 x 32), in which Setting Up exercises and talks can be given. The window space is ample to provide for necessary ventilation with abundant sunshine. The screen, glassed in verandah will be an excellent location for certain children to sleep out on during part of the year.

As you know the 27 children in the Preventorium have all been examined by the Ninette Sanitorium Travelling Clinic, and are all TB contacts, all under weight, and have all been described by the clinic as having evidence of TB, but not necessarily of present or active disease.
I will visit the preventorium weekly, and between visits should any emergency arise kindly advise me.

I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Dr. McGill, Director of Indian Affairs for his information, criticisms, and advice.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Medical Officer

Dear Doctor Bissett:

Being now in a somewhat better position to forecast what can be planned for during the next twelve months, I feel able to discuss your letters of January 21st to Mr. Hamilton, and of February 5th to Dr. McGill.

This is the third cut and out Preventorium unit we have got into operation. All have developed along certain lines suitable to local conditions, and you appear to have utilized this one for what seemed to you a good immediate purpose. I am glad you have put it to use, and will only ask you to consider the following principles as essential. Beyond them, we do not want to impose any hard and fast rules.

1. It is settled policy to keep within the school framework and therefore the religious framework, children who will return to normal school routine within not more than two years and, preferably, one year or less.

2. It is equally settled policy to remove from the schools, and so from religious auspices, those children who definitely require sanatorium treatment.

The former group continues to be subject to that section of the Indian Act which says that a Roman Catholic child must not be compelled (is in practice allowed) to go to a Protestant school, and vice versa. The latter group are subject to no such law, but are subject to the consent of their parents as to where they may go or be sent.

3. We do not want Preventoria to become Sanatoria.

4. The Fort Alexander institution will serve the three R.C. Residential Schools in Manitoba, those at Fort Frances, McIntosh and Kenora in Ontario, and any R.C. Day Schools which can be got under tuberculosis control.

5. As the very object of a Preventorium is to make weak children strong, you are carrying out the principle by using yours for the twenty-seven children, but we do not want it to become a hospital, nor a place where the school can get a higher revenue for pupils who only require observation, without any special care. Our guide in this must be the best tuberculosis opinion we can get, and so, we want to share your and our responsibility by getting periodical inspections by the specialist.

E.D.R. Bissett, Esq., M.D.,
Pine Falls,
Manitoba.

We want to.........
6. We want to leave sanatorium work to those who are now doing it, at least until such time as they cannot meet the demand. For this reason, we want to turn over sanatorium cases to the Manitoba Sanatorium Board, much as we do mental patients to the Provincial Mental Service. We shall accept any disposal they can make of them.

7. We want, in the final settled program, to do for Indians about what white people are now doing for themselves and one another. With due regard to the possibility of doing anything, or much, for certain remote groups, we want to keep down the overhead cost. This year has been experimental and fact finding in a large degree. You can't go wrong if you deal with adult Fort Alexander Indians much as you do with the people of Pine Falls. As they come under your notice you will try to get a final diagnosis on suspected tuberculosis, and we will try to find room and money for their sanatorium treatment. We cannot expect, at one jump, to go from almost no tuberculosis service to one which the white people have not attained.

Beyond this, however, we want to get as complete control of tuberculosis among children as we can, hence the preventorium and the preference all along the line for children.

We shall have some new money after April 1st, sufficient I should say, at first sight, to do about a quarter of what might be done. So far as possible, I want to utilize the utmost possible proportion for treatment, and the least necessary for diagnosis and other overhead costs. I am asking you to incur any of the latter sort of costs grudgingly, and if there is any caution to be enjoined on your letter of February 2nd to Father Brackett, it is along this line. I think the outline of it is admirable, for a start at least.

You may think all these replies very general in tone, but we don't want to lay down hard and fast rules on details, and, up to about the last week, have not known whether any of the things we have undertaken would be gone on with, extended or abandoned.

I may see you in about two weeks, if a half-formed plan of going west should come off.

You had best get the Principal to ask the Agent for the Dentist.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.D.,
Superintendent of Medical Services.

We want to...........

E.D.R. Bissett, Esq., M.D.,
Pine Falls,

6. We want to leave sanatorium work to those who are now doing it, at least until such time as they cannot meet the demand. For this reason, we want to turn over sanatorium cases to the Manitoba Sanatorium Board, much as we do mental patients to the Provincial Mental Service. We shall accept any disposal they can make of them.

7. We want, in the final settled program, to do for Indians about what white people are now doing for themselves and one another, with due regard to the possibility or doing anything or much, for certain remote groups. We want to keep down the overhead cost. This year has been experimental and fast finding in a large degree. You can't go wrong if you deal with adult Fort Alexander Indians much as you do with the people of Pine Falls. As they come under your notice you will try to get a final diagnosis on suspected tuberculosis, and we will try to find room and money for their sanatorium treatment. We cannot expect, at one jump, to go from almost no tuberculosis service to one which the white people have not attained.

Beyond this, however, we want to get as complete control of tuberculosis among children as we can, hence the preventorium and the preference all along the line for children.

We shall have some new money after April 1st, sufficient, I should say, at first sight, to do about a quarter of what might be done. So far as possible, I want to utilize the utmost possible proportion for treatment, and the least necessary for diagnosis and other overhead costs. I am asking you to incur any of the latter sort of costs grudgingly, and if there is any caution to be enjoined on your letter of February 2nd to Father Brachet, it is along this line. I think the outline of it is admirable, for a start at least.

You may think all these replies very general in tone, but we don't want to lay down hard and fast rules on details, and, up to about the last week, have not known whether any of the things we have undertaken would be gone on with, extended or abandoned.

I may see you in about two weeks, if a half-formed plan of going west should come off.

You had best get the Principal to ask the Agent for the Dentist.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.B.,

Dear Sir:

You will recall discussion about securing the services of one of the officers of the Manitoba Sanatorium Board to make periodical visits to the Fort Alexander Indian Reserve to consult with Doctor Bissett, the management of the preventorium at Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. Several suggestions have been received that Dr. J. D. Adamson should be asked to do this work, and the Department would indeed be pleased to have him, if there is no objection on the part of the Board. It will be within your authority to make an arrangement at such reasonable or nominal fee as may be decided upon for a visit to the Reserve.

The immediate situation is that the preventorium has about 27 inmates. Four are entered as regular preventorium patients at a tentative rate of $1.00 per day and the remainder at 25 cents per day in addition to the per capita grant for education. The building, it is believed, was designed for a capacity of 20. The account for the month of March was $325.00, which seems rather a severe tax on the funds for tuberculosis. I do not like to ask you to go to Fort Alexander, but if you can find time to do so it might be advisable.

The Department is not complaining of the situation. The Development of the preventorium could not be foreseen in detail, but it is necessary that it should now be reviewed and get on a good operating basis which will

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Dr. Stone:

I had occasion last week to meet Father Brochet, Principal of the Fort Alexander school and also Director of the Preventorium. He informed me that he has only four children that might be classed as preventorium cases. Three of these come from Sandy Bay and one from the Fort Alexander reserve. Reverend Sir:

In reply to your letter of April 26 I may say that the Department has long since given instructions that the Preventorium cases from the four residential schools you mention be removed to Fort Alexander. The instruction was made conditional on the consent of the parents and as you point out, none of the cases from these four schools have gone. Some light is shed on the matter by a report just now received from the Indian Agent, Fort Frances that he has not been able to induce any of the parents to allow their children to go. The sentiment among them in that neighbourhood appears to be that "they would rather see them die here than send them away and have them die at Fort Alexander".

It appears to me that something might be accomplished by missionary work on the part of the school Principals if the Indians at other places had the same views as those at Kenora. Perhaps you are in the best position of anyone to request the Principals to do what they can in this direction. At the same time the Department will see what can be done through the Indian Agents and Medical Officers.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
General Superintendent,
Oblate Catholic Indian Missions,
Winnipeg, Man.

E. L. Stone, M. B.
Superintendent of Medical Services

IM
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter 5-413 of April 27 I may say that the Department is very discouraged at the attitude of the parents of the children recommended to the Preventorium section of the school at Fort Alexander. Far from there being any likelihood of the children dying at Fort Alexander, the Preventorium there has been set up as a place where they will receive even better care and attention than they could have in any ordinary residential school where they will be among children of their own kind, have ample rest and no work and where every effort will be made to produce happy surroundings for them. If there was any prospect of these children dying or even becoming bed cases, the Department would not think of sending them to any school.

This appears to be a matter in which the Indian Agent, Medical Officers and school principals should all combine to explain to the Indians the true facts. The Church which operates the Fort Alexander School has very kindly spent a good deal of money in providing this institution and the Department has furnished it also at considerable expense. It hopes that this kindness and thoughtfulness will not be defeated by the very persons for whose benefit it was intended. While this letter is addressed to you, copies are being sent to other Indian Agents who will gather from it what the Department would like them to do at their Agencies.

Yours truly,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

Dr. J.G. Wherrett, Secretary of the Canadian Tuberculosis Association, reports having discussed the Fort Alexander Preventorium with Doctor Adamson on a recent visit to Winnipeg. Doctor Wherrett said there was still some doubt as to the principles which should govern the administration of this institution and suggested that definite regulations should be laid down by the Department.

It was thought that this matter would have been settled fairly satisfactorily by your consultations with the Manitoba Sanatorium Board last Spring and I must say that it is difficult for the Department to lay down more than a very general ruling if it has not to run the danger of making regulations which may not turn out to be satisfactory.

It is the Department's intention that the preventorium shall be used for the benefit of Roman Catholic children suitable for treatment in it, and coming from any district within a reasonable distance from its location. This would include the whole of the Province of Manitoba and Northwestern Ontario as far East as Kenora and Sioux Lookout and the areas from which Indians come to those places. It was anticipated last year that there would be at least twenty candidates

A.G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

DW
for treatment from the Sioux Lookout and Kenora Districts, but the Department made the error of consulting the parents over the disposal of the children who were already school pupils. That will not be done again. The suitable candidates for the preventorium should have positive tuberculin skin reactions, should be in some danger of becoming actively tuberculous, but should not have the disease in a communicable form. Perhaps one way of expressing this would be that their bodily discharges should not contain tubercle bacilli. They might have indications of early tuberculosis, or be convalescent from sanatorium or more active treatment. They should not be bed patients in the ordinary sense of that term.

Their admission and discharge should be decided upon in consultation between the local medical officer, either at Fort Alexander or elsewhere, and one of the medical officers for the sanatorium board. This consultation might, in some cases, have to be carried out by mail. Admissions and discharges should be finally authorized by you and it is undesirable that there should be frequent admissions from and discharges to residential schools after the early part of the school term, unless an exchange can be made between the preventorium and the school without affecting the number of grant earning pupils in the school.

Pupils admitted to the preventorium from the Fort Alexander School will remain on the school roll and the Department will pay 25¢ per day in addition to the grant for education. Pupils from other schools will be struck off the strength of the schools, may be replaced by other children, and the Department will pay the Preventorium authorities $1.00 per day,
subject to adjustment of this rate after audit of the expenditure by the departmental auditor.

The staff of the preventorium must include one graduate nurse and provision must be made for limited school instruction. It is requested that you and Dr. J.D. Adamson act as a committee with any other persons whom you may wish to bring into it, to decide with the preventorium on the suitability of the staff provided, the food and care made available, and other details of the actual operation of the institution. Presumably you will wish to add to this committee Dr. E.D.R. Bissett.

Immediate medical supervision of the preventorium will be carried out by Dr. E.D.R. Bissett, to whose compensation the amount of $300.00 has recently been added, partly to provide for this duty.

In laying down these principles the Department wishes to avoid imposing them, or any of them upon you in so strict a form that the effective operation of the institution may be interfered with. If, therefore, in any respect they are not suitable or workable, you may vary them in consultation with the members of the committee referred to above. In any event, the Department would like to be informed of the rules laid down so that, by its approval, it may strengthen your authority in having them carried out. It thinks that Doctor Adamson or any available medical officer of the sanatorium board should be asked to visit the preventorium about once monthly, or as required, and is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this service.

The Department is not prepared to pay for the maintenance in this institution of school pupils or other children who have no tuberculosis, even though they may be below the average standard of health in other respects. That situation occurred...
during the last term, but the time has obviously passed when it should be permitted to continue.

It may well be that this letter does not cover the whole field and that other aspects of the problem may have to be decided on the ground. It may also be said that few institutions reach their best standard of operation within the first few months of their existence and the Department will be well satisfied if its hopes are realized within the course of the present school year.

An earnest endeavour has been made in this letter to cover the whole ground, but it may be well to add that the children admitted to this preventorium need not necessarily have been residential school pupils. Its object is to prevent the progress of tuberculosis among Roman Catholic children to a point where they will become sanatorium cases.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.
Fort Alexander Indian Residential School,
Pine Falls, Man.,

Dear Sir:

Re Preventorium - July & August.

In answer to the inquiry of the Department regarding the care of some pupils in the preventorium during the month of July, I beg to say that we had no directions from the Department. Dr. Biscott, however, insisted on keeping during the holidays all the pupils cared for in the preventorium.

Regarding the three pupils brought to the preventorium from Sandy Bay, one, Marie Louise Beaulieu, was found to be well enough to be discharged and I brought her back to Sandy Bay at the end of June. The two others, according to the report of the Ninette Clinic, had to be kept in, and we did keep them throughout the holidays. The others were taken out by their parents in turns. This account for a few days marked on some patients. We regretted, however, that some went away. Annie Sutherland, for instance, lost 10 lbs. during her holidays.

I may add that for the month of August we have only on the report the two pupils from Sandy Bay, Louisa Malcolm & Harry Houle. The two others, who have each 4 and 3 days to their name, were brought back before the end of the holidays.

Trusting this explanation will make matters plain, I remain, dear Sir,

Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter dated December 5th, file 125-1-25 and to say that I accompanied Dr. Adamson to the Fort Alexander School on December 30th. The trip was somewhat delayed but the Doctor was unable to leave prior to that date.

The roads were very heavy from Pine Falls to the school and it was necessary to hire a special livery for this trip.

The eight pupils without positive tuberculin reaction have been discharged and at present there are 27 receiving special care. Dr. Adamson is reporting on the situation but in my opinion there is little ground for criticism as to the situation now stands. If this 'preventorium' is to be operated as outlined by Dr. Adamson it will require additional equipment and staff etc. will be almost a 'sanatorium'. I do not know if the school authorities are willing to do this. The Rev. principal feels that an institution of this nature, operated in conjunction with a school, will change the environment and make the preventorium children restless, thus preventing their rapid return to health. He also intimated that, if carried out, the present financial arrangement would be insufficient.

Dr. Bissett acted on Circular 706-778 dated August 5th and made his admissions from the previous clinic report. I did not advise Dr. Bissett of letter 125-1-25 dated September 21st but did advise Doctors Adamson, Ross and Jackson and Mr. McEachern. The circular made clear to me that the Provincial Tuberculosis Clinic was to be used if available and Dr. Bissett knew the clinic would later be making a return visit to the school.

As pointed out above, I feel we can offer very little criticism other than with regard to the eight pupils and even in these cases I believe Dr. Bissett acted in the interest of the children, and felt that three or four months special care would tide them past a possible breakdown.

The clinic has recommended fourteen pupils. Four have not yet arrived but we hope to secure their admission. We have not received any, as yet, from Ontario. Discharges can be affected any time to accommodate new admissions.

Re: Preventorium at Fort Alexander.

Dear Mr. Hamilton,

To supplement and confirm our conversation on the above subject, I wish to make the following comments:

Three questions immediately arise, namely:

1. Are there enough suitable cases to fill thirty beds?
2. Would the Preventorium plan really make a substantial contribution to the Indian tuberculosis problem?
3. If not, how can the plan be improved?

I shall deal with each of these problems separately.

1. Are there available cases?

It is presumed that the proposed unit will be run along the lines usually implied by the word "Preventorium", i.e., the inmates will all be in the following classes:

a. They shall be of school age, i.e., six to sixteen and of both sexes.
b. They shall not have open tuberculous lesions of any sort and will therefore be non-infectious.
c. They shall all be fit for ambulant treatment and will be up and about most of the time.
d. They shall not require intensive medical or surgical treatment.

The above is the usual conception of a Preventorium case. It will be found that very few such cases are actually in territory tributary to Fort Alexander.

A real Preventorium case is not really a clinical entity. It is an abstraction built on the assumption that doctors can predict by examination what children are likely to contract tuberculosis. This is, of course, not so. It is certainly true that children who have had contact with open tuberculosis are the only ones who ultimately get tuberculosis. But all contacts cannot be cared for in an institution. Even if they were, there is no assurance that there would ultimately be less tuberculosis among them. The same applies to those with a positive tuberculin test and those with healed childhood lesions. The possibility that contact with open tuberculosis would be broken for children in a Preventorium might operate in their favor. This breaking of contact should, however, be accomplished for all Indian children in
boarding schools without providing separate buildings. This could be done by frequent tuberculin tests and x-ray examinations.

2. Would the Preventorium plan make a substantial contribution to the Indian tuberculosis problem?

The death rate in infants—which is said to be high—would obviously be unaffected. Also just as many would be infected up to going to school. While in the Preventorium there would presumably be less spread of infection. This would, however, probably not be absolute. Among thirty suspects or alleged closed cases there would always be some who would become "open". Indeed the criteria by which we have previously judged cases to be "Open" or "closed" have recently been brought into question. In any event, a very close scrutiny would need to be kept to prevent spread in the institution.

But suppose no such spread took place, what will be the position of these children when discharged to their old environment at the age of fifteen or sixteen? Will the fact that they have been in Preventorium prevent them from breaking down at the usual age (sixteen to thirty-five)? Probably not. Since a larger number than usual will possibly be tuberculin negative, the reverse may quite possibly happen; i.e., they may be more susceptible.

The crux of the whole tuberculosis problem in Indians is no different than in whites, i.e., sources of contamination must be removed by treatment and isolation. The Preventorium plan does not do this and it would seem a misuse of funds if they were spent on anything so fantastic when there are so many other urgent necessities.

3. Can the plan be improved?

An institution at Fort Alexander might possibly contribute something if it went right out to treat tuberculosis among young Indians in the ordinary way. It might be arranged that patients be sent into Sanatorium for a few weeks or months observation and when considered suitable be transferred to Fort Alexander where they could continue modified Sanatorium care and pneumothorax if necessary. Even then I feel that there would never be enough of school age Indian children to fill thirty beds. However, I suppose the age limit for inmates could be changed. Such an institution, properly supervised, might develop into a very useful organization.

The plans of the new building which you showed me are quite good except that there are no single wards whatever, and when one is treating many children facilities for isolation is imperative otherwise you would be almost always harassed with inter-current infectious diseases.

I hope you will not consider these opinions as being merely destructive. They are offered in complete candor and sincerity and I think the opinions given are those
generally held by all those experienced in the treatment of tuberculosis.

I feel that this whole matter should be referred to the Committee recently appointed in Ottawa for the consideration of the Indian problem in Canada.

Yours sincerely,

J.D. Adamson, M.D.,
Medical Director.

Dear Dr. Stone,

In accordance with your suggestion, Inspector A. G. Hamilton and I visited the Fort Alexander Preventorium on December 30, 1937.

I examined the records and the x-ray reports of the 27 children now in. They all have demonstrable tuberculous lesions which are healed or healing, and none of them can be called open cases in the ordinary sense, and none of them require care in a fully equipped Sanatorium. Some of them may at times produce tubercle bacilli.

This situation is a very definite improvement over the one that existed when the Travelling Clinic examined the school in October, 1936, when of 34 children only 6 were considered to be proper cases and 8 were actually skin negative. According to Dr. Bissett and Father Brachet, these 34 were put in on the understanding that the institution was to be run on the original idea of Preventorium, i.e., it was to be used simply as a unit in which undernourished and generally run down children should be given extra food, rest and medical supervision. Their instructions apparently specifically stated that potentially infectious cases should not be admitted. These instructions are contained in a Head Quarter's circular letter No. 706778, September 21, 1936.

Since the Travelling Clinic report (October 17, 1936) the 8 negative reactors have been discharged. Also, 10 "spreader school" cases, as selected by the Travelling Clinic, have been admitted. At present the large majority of the patients may be regarded as suitable cases for the institution.

The obvious objection to the present situation is that the new cases sent in are potential spreaders and might possibly contaminate the children in the school with whom they freely associate except with regard to sleeping quarters. If it is to be run as a "spreader school", arrangements for complete isolation from the other school should be made. It is obvious that this would require an extensive change in general routine and establishment. Separate dining room, class room and play grounds will be necessary, and these children should not be allowed to mix in any way with those of the larger school; also, a nurse or attendant with some training in tuberculosis should be available, and the treatment should be continued throughout the year and not simply for the school year.

These suggestions came as a surprise to Dr. Bissett and Father Brachet who apparently up to now considered that the procedure would be similar to that which was in vogue last year. I am convinced that when they selected the

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McGILL
Re: Fort Alexander Preventorium

In my recent inspection trip to Manitoba I visited the above institution in company with Inspector Hamilton and Doctor Bissett.

The institution consists of two dormitories which are, to all intents and purposes, a part of the main school.

The type of children chosen by recognized authorities such as the travelling clinics of the various provinces for this kind of institution fall into a very definite group. They all have demonstrable tuberculous lesions which are healed or healing, are not open cases in the ordinary sense and do not require care in a fully equipped sanatorium. They would include the children with enlarged hilar glands and the so called childhood type or primary infection type of pulmonary tuberculosis. Some of them may at times produce tubercle bacilli. Bone and joint cases which had been treated in a sanatorium, and were ambulant or on casts could be removed to this type of place for more economic care.

I now quote from a report on this institution made to the Department on January 5, by Dr. J. D. Adamson, Winnipeg, a recognized authority on tuberculosis, with which report I fully concur:

"The obvious objection to the present situation is that the new cases sent in are potential spreaders and might possibly contaminate the children in the school with whom they freely associate except with regard to sleeping..."
quarters. If it is to be run as a "spreader school", arrangements for complete isolation from the other school should be made. It is obvious that this would require an extensive change in general routine and establishment. Separate dining room, class room and play grounds will be necessary, and these children should not be allowed to mix in any way with those of the larger school; also, a nurse or attendant with some training in tuberculosis should be available, and the treatment should be continued throughout the year and not simply for the school year."

It is not reasonable to remove children from one school because of the obvious danger they are to other pupils, and bring them to another school where they are in constant contact with the other children except for sleeping quarters.

The Reverend Principal of the school recognizes this fact, and asked me not to transfer the children from Western Ontario to the Preventorium until the question was settled and some more suitable way of caring for these cases found.

I think I should point out the experience of Dr. Geo. Ferguson, in connection with these "observation cases" at Lebret school. While they were kept in the school, although under supposed segregation and special routine, twenty-five new cases of tuberculosis developed in one year. Since they have all been removed from the school, not a single new case has developed in more than two years.

I do not believe the present Unit to be at all satisfactory and it is distinctly dangerous. Nor do I believe that alterations could be made to make it satisfactory. Such a Unit should be entirely separate and away from the school where non-tuberculous children are living.

Therefore I recommend the abandonment of this Unit.

P. E. Moore, M.D.
Asst. Superintendent of Medical Services

Dear Mr. Dewdney,

As the Pas Agency is in the Manitoba Superintendent's hands writing a letter to you to ask if there is any prospect of an industrial school being established there during the year 1870, less has been done by the Department for the Pas Indians than for almost any Indian under twenty. They are very poor, and their prospects appear to me to be very slight unless they are induced to remove to a part of the country where farming or stock raising are possible. These Indians are very keen for education. They are now all members of our Church.

I think Archdeacon J.A. Macdonald's application for such schools to be treated at Lac la Ronge. The school there is excellent, may receive a favorable response also. Have delayed this letter so long, a great deal can be made toward the object.

My Dear Sir,

The Executive Committee of the Diocese of Saskatchewan desires respectfully to represent to you the need of a Boarding School for the Indian children in the Pas Agency.

There are over two hundred and fifty (250) treaty Indian children of school age in this Agency. Many of these children cannot attend the day schools, and of those who do attend the attendance is so irregular that practically they receive very little education. Experience fully shows that under existing conditions the day schools are not very effective.
Railway communication is being extended to The Pas, and the Indians will come more and more in contact with white people and the changes in the conditions of life consequent upon the advance of civilization. They will need every help to meet the new conditions, and without education it would be almost hopeless to expect them to grapple successfully with these conditions.

At or near The Pas—where the railway reaches the Saskatchewan River—and where the Indians come into immediate contact with all that railways usually bring with them, would be a very suitable point for such an Indian Boarding School. The Pas is the headquarters of the Indian Department Agency, and also of our missionary work in that district.

Ottawa, October 17, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The Bishop of Saskatchewan has enclosed a memorial from the Synod of his Diocese, asking for the establishment of a boarding school in the Pas agency, to be built by the Government, to accommodate 50 pupils at the usual per capita grant.

The question of opening a boarding or industrial school at the Pas has been before the Department since 1887, and applications from the Church of England for such a school have been renewed from time to time since then. There are some 250 children of school age in this agency; practically all of them are recognized as members of the Church of England. To meet the educational needs of these Indians there are eight day schools, conducted under the auspices of that Church. The last published annual report shows an enrolment at these schools of 186, with an average attendance of 96.

In the memorial it is pointed out that many of the children cannot attend day schools, and of those who do attend they are so irregular that practically they receive very little education and it is claimed that experience fully shows that under existing conditions the day schools are not very effective. I regret to say that this statement is in the main correct, but there is no reason why day schools should not be made
made effective. This could be done by raising the present salaries and holding out inducements to efficient teachers to take charge of these schools, and although the clergy generally, and some few laymen, hold that the only way to civilize and educate an Indian child is to place him in an industrial or boarding school, where he will be removed from the influence of the reserve, I do not share this opinion, as my experience has taught me that the boarding and industrial schools do not, in most cases, achieve the end aimed at. The ex-pupils of these schools, I have learned from reliable information, failed, with few exceptions, to benefit from their stay there, and to make any return for the large outlay entailed in maintaining such institutions. For the six years and nine months ended March 31, last, the cost of schools of this class in the West was close upon two million dollars, and I claim that, if a portion of this sum had been expended in bettering the Indians' condition on the reserve and improving the existing day schools, better results would have been obtained. As an argument against boarding and industrial schools, I might point out that the long hours and confinement tell against the health of the pupils, as is conclusively shown by our medical reports. Then again, the relieving of Indian parents from all responsibility for the maintenance of their children does not encourage industry and self-reliance, and the pupil who has had everything found for him up to the time he leaves school does not show much inclination for steady work when he is removed from restraint. In fact, the greater number are much more helpless.
helpless and disinclined for steady work than those who have never attended schools of this class. These remarks are more applicable to boys than to girls.

The memorial, as before stated, asks the Government to contribute the full cost of building and equipping the school, and, should it not be successfully carried on with the usual per capita grant, which is most likely, the Department would have to meet the deficits. Again, if the Department once undertakes to build and equip boarding schools and hand them over to religious denominations to carry on, it will be flooded with applications and there will be no limit to the expenditure.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Oliver,

Venerable Archdeacon MacKay of Battleford called on me on the 17th instant with reference to the Church of England Schools in the Saskatchewan Diocese. The growing difficulty of obtaining pupils for the Battleford Industrial School and the need for new buildings there if the School is to be continued has forced the Bishop to consider the situation.

Evidently the arrangement which the Department made with the Presbyterian Church on the closing of the Regina Industrial School commends itself favorably to the Church of England. Archdeacon MacKay presented the attached memorandum, making alternative propositions; first, as to an increase in the grant for the existing Boarding schools and the establishment of a new Boarding School at the Pas; second, proposing the closing of the Battleford Industrial School and a partition of the grants amongst the other schools on an increased scale of per capita allowance. This latter proposition appeals to me as being in line with our policy of closing the larger Industrial schools and where Boarding Schools are at all required to establish them upon the Reserves. It involves also the improvement of three Day Schools. The present buildings of the Battleford Industrial
School are in a dilapidated condition and if the School were to be longer maintained we would have to consider putting up a new building, which could not be done to meet the needs of the institution much under $50,000.00. Taking everything into consideration, therefore, I think we should accept the proposal to close Battleford, allow the Boarding Schools at Lac la Ronge and Onion Lake an increase in their per capita grant to $100.00, establish a Boarding School at the Pas providing for 100 pupils at $100 and either make an addition to the present Lac la Ronge Boarding School or erect a new School at Montreal Lake. We should be able to build a school at the Pas for about $30,000.00.

I do not think it would be advisable to decide hastily on the needs of the Montreal Lake situation but to consider the matter most carefully before we decide what buildings to erect. In Archdeacon MacKay's memorandum of the funds available for redistribution under the new plan he includes those formerly voted for Emmanuel College. This item disappeared from the Estimates some years ago, but we could close a number of day schools in the Pas district which are now doing very poor work. While I think the Church of England might have some claim for consideration as to the loss of Emmanuel College also the closing of these Day Schools will assist the gross saving.
