Referring to your letter quoted above, with regard to the establishment of a boarding school at Montreal Lake or the enlargement of the boarding school at Lac la Ronge, I have the honour to state that I have given the matter my best attention, and have no hesitation in recommending the establishment of a school for 50 pupils at Lac la Ronge.

My recent report on the boarding school at Lac la Ronge will show that neither the present building nor its site is well adapted for a school for 50 pupils, much less for 100. In case of its being rebuilt on a new and more suitable site the building could be built to a plan and of dimensions adapted to 100 pupils, it is true. But the educational needs of Amos Charles' band (at Stanley) have to be provided for; and if two of these bands are to be provided for in one school it would naturally be those at Lac la Ronge and Stanley, as being in every respect more closely associated. But in my opinion it will be necessary to provide for the education of the children of these three bands separately, in order to secure the full attendance that is desirable; while I also believe that these smaller schools will in every respect do more efficient work than one large one. I may say that although the question before me has reference only to Montreal Lake and Lac la Ronge, yet I find it impossible to discuss it fully without making

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
this reference at least to the needs of the people at Stanley.

It is practically certain that it would not be possible to secure more than a small percentage of the children of school age at Montreal Lake for attendance at a school at Lac la Ronge. Communication between the places is at present difficult. The canoe route by the Montreal river is so labourious that it is now practically abandoned for freighting purposes. There is a winter trail overland which is shorter and easier, but it is not much used by the Indians, who are poorly equipped for travelling by trail. It is true that before many years have passed conditions of travel will in all probability have altered very much for the better; but notwithstanding this, from my knowledge of the geographical situation of these two bands, their relations to each other, and the experience of schools elsewhere in regard to attendance, I feel convinced that a school at Lac la Ronge will never satisfactorily meet the educational needs of the Indians at Montreal Lake.

While the present site of the school at Lac la Ronge is both picturesque and healthful, as are also many other possible sites on that lake, and there is also plenty of timber there for fuel and building purposes, yet various sites could be selected at Montreal Lake which, besides having these advantages, are surrounded with land well adapted to farming and gardening and affording fair facilities for the keeping of stock. The timber around Montreal Lake is very fine; the soil is of excellent quality; there is much native hay to be had conveniently, while cultivated feed for stock could be grown abundantly. This last is a consideration of no slight importance, since a good supply of milk is indispensable in a boarding school, which necessitates the keeping of a number of cows. Schools in these regions find a liberal supply of fish equally indispensable. For this purpose there could be
no better location than Lac la Ronge; but while Montreal Lake is not itself a particularly good lake for fish, the Bittern Lake, a small lake at the south-east corner of the reserve, furnishes a plentiful supply of whitefish of the best quality.

In William Charles' band, at Montreal Lake, there are between 45 and 50 children of the ordinary school age, that is, between six and fifteen years. In James Roberts' band, at Lac la Ronge, as it is since the division of the band, there are 72 children of school age; while in Amos Charles' band, at Stanley, there are 56. Though children from Stanley are never likely to attend the school at Lac la Ronge in large numbers, yet they are more likely to attend than are those whose homes are at Montreal Lake.

A most important consideration, to my mind, in favour of the establishment of a school at Montreal Lake of similar capacity to the one at Lac la Ronge, in preference to doubling the capacity of the present school, is that each school is a very important center of influence for good upon the lives and habits of the Indian population around. This is an influence which belongs to every similar institution, apart from the direct work of education, and while it is somewhat increased through any increase in the capacity and importance of the institution, it is not exerted so widely or so beneficially by doubling the capacity of one school as by establishing a similar school in a different center.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

With reference to your letter No.373371-1, of date the 17th ult., I may say that having looked as fully as possible into this matter of a hospital in connection with the Indian boarding school on the Pas reserve, beg leave to report as follows.

In the course of my inspections during the past four years in this and other Agencies, I have found on all the reserves a number of cases drawn to my attention by the visiting Physician, and also coming under my own personal observation, where a simple operation would cure the patient. When the Doctor's attention was called to these cases he invariably declined to operate because his personal service could not be given to the patient for any length of time after the operation.

For instance, in the summer of 1911, on the Manitowapah Agency, an Indian came to see Dr. Clarke on one of his reserves, for a swelling on the side of his jaw, the Doctor gave him something to rub on his cheek, but told me later that it was a very simple operation to remove the lump and cure the young man, but he would not operate on account of not being able to give, say a week's personal attention to the wound.

The average Indian does not give very much attention to personal cleanliness, and in their houses the same characteristic disregard of hygiene prevails, in consequence of this trait our medical men are afraid of blood poisoning in connection with operations on the reserves, in their homes.
All surgical cases should be sent to the hospital, but the doctors on the Manitowah, and the Pas, agencies hesitate about sending such cases which are not immediately dangerous to the hospital, on account of the very large expense to the Department of Indian Affairs.

The closest Protestant hospital to this agency at the present time is at Swan Lake, distant about 193 miles from Le Pas, and in addition to this all the bands in this agency are situated from 75 to 100 miles from this point, with water communication for at least six months in each year, and a hospital situated where this boarding school is built, will be easily accessible from all the reserves in the Agency.

After carefully looking into this matter I have come to the conclusion that the establishing of a small hospital in connection with the boarding school, would be a great favour to the Indians of this agency.

As to the expense, outside of the building, it would only be necessary to have a trained nurse of experience, as all the other help required would come from the staff of the school and the elder pupils, (as at Birtle).

There is also the side of the question, the benefit to the school itself. There are times when when a number of the pupils require a weeks lay off in the hospital for minor ailments, which can be better looked after under the personal observation of the nurse, and the advantage thereby conferred it would be hard for me to estimate. After consultation with Dr. Crok, I have drafted a rough plan of building required, with the probable cost of same, which you will find enclosed.

Also find enclosed letter from Mr. Fischer, and a report from Dr. Crok, on the subject.

Dear Sir:—

I have been requested by Mr. S. J. Jackson, Inspector of Agencies, to report to the Department on conditions that exist among the various bands under my care that would make the addition of an hospital to the proposed school an essential part of the scheme.

In my July report I mentioned having seen various cases that could only be treated successfully in hospital, and at the end of another month in the work I am still more of the opinion that such a place is needed here. For instance a woman brought in a child two years old suffering from a bad form of hernia. This is her third child and both the others had the same trouble and are both dead. It is possible that had the doctor had the necessary hospital facilities something might have been done for the little ones. It would be an utter impossibility to do any sort of surgery in the houses, they are so filthy, and the minute you would be out sight even if you did risk one they would be wandering over the wound with dejections of their own. With a small hospital and a nurse in charge this difficulty would be overcome. I am only mentioning this one instance of a case requiring surgical treatment but there are others just as urgent.

Again from the surgical aspect of the question I am of the sure opinion that we could get great benefit from a place of this kind with many of our medical cases. Saw a case of acute rheumatism the other day, the patient lying on the floor. I found on enquiry that there was not a bed in the house, and the sick as well as the sound slept practically in the same heap of blankets. This state of affairs you will admit would not tend to the welfare of either. This practice of crowding the ill and the well into the same room and often into the same bed is another argument in support of our request. Again, too often the Doctor in charge of the Indian work, just because he is unable to apply the same scientific principles in the treatment of his Indians, as he can to his white brother, is unable to get the same satisfactory results and consequently loses the Indian's confidence, and without you have their confidence you can do very little with them.

As to the size of building required, I would suggest one having ward that would hold five beds. Would want two such wards one for male and female patients, two private rooms for special cases, and a room for operations, these would be ample for hospital purposes. Besides, we would require the usual nurses quarters, drug dispensary, also kitchen dining room closets etc. If you think it better something on the cottage system would work out very well and could be added to as required.

The site proposed for the school buildings would be an ideal one for an hospital. Placed as it would be on a hill high above the swampy land around, the very fact that we would be able to get our sick there would help in many cases as much as medicine.

I, as medical attendant to the bands here, want to give them the very best I can, and I cannot let an opportunity such as this pass without bringing to the notice of the Department, the urgent need of such an institution here. I trust that you will see your way clear to grant us this boon.

I will be ready and willing at all times to give you any desired information. Thanking you in anticipation,

I beg to remain, Sir,

Chief Surveyor.
If the Pas Indian Boarding School is to be built during the next season, it would be greatly to the benefit of the building operations if say ten acres of the Island was cleared this fall before the snow gets too deep. The trees should be made into cordwood, and the brush piled and burned.

It would also be advisable to put down a well near the site of building when the same was cleared, and have it finished before building starts.

As the Island is underlaid with limestone it will be necessary to have the well drilled.

All the wells around here at the present time are shallow and have only surface water, by going into the rock a never failing supply, such as is wanted by an institution of this character, is usually found. Sir,

With reference to the Boarding School building which it is the intention of the Department of Indian Affairs to erect on Fisher Island on the Pas reserve, I beg leave to make a few suggestions on the subject.

Tenders should be called for at an early date, so that contractors outside of here would be able to visit the place and see what they have to contend with in tendering on a job of this size, and at such a distance from their base of operations.

I would recommend that tenders be called for, say not later than the first day of January, and to be in the hands of the Dept. by the 15th day of March, and that such advertisement be placed in newspapers in the following places, Winnipeg, Portage La Prairie, Brandon, Dauphin, Saskatoon, Prince Albert, and The Pas.

If this done, from what I know of the situation, the result will be satisfactory to the Department.

As there is a large limestone quarry on the property it might be advisable to consider the question of using that material in the buildings, there is also a large quantity of sand and gravel in the immediate vicinity suitable for concrete work.

It would be greatly in the interests of building operations, if my former recommendation to clear 10 or 20 acres on the Island, and put down a well, were carried out, the Indians will all be home from the fall hunt by the middle of December, and would be glad of the opportunity of doing this work.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

While you were in the west the Bishop of Saskatchewan wrote under date of the 31st ultimo recommending the appointment of the Rev. Louis Laronde as Principal of the new Pas Boarding School. He is a French half-breed, a graduate of St. John's College and withdrew from treaty in 1909. He is a married man and has had experience as a teacher in Indian day schools. Venerable Archdeacon MacKay has also recommended his appointment in a letter received today. So far as his educational attainments go Mr. Laronde is fully qualified, but it is a question for you to decide whether you would be willing to intrust the success of a new school to a half-breed. I think our past experience goes to show that we would be taking great risks in putting a school of this class in charge of a half-breed.

The Bishop inquires what is to be done in regard to salaries of the principal and any of the staff who may join before the school is open. His Lordship says that it will be necessary for the principal to be there sometime in advance of the opening of the school.
As this will be a per capita grant school there will be no money coming in until after the school is opened. His Lordship would like the Department to assume the payment of the salaries until the per capita grant comes in and, as they have no money available for meeting current expenses even after the school is opened, he thinks the Department ought to furnish funds to start the school, to be repaid gradually out of the per capita grant. It is certain that the church has no money and if the Department makes an advance they will be starting in debt and it will take them a long time to work it off.

With regard to the stock which is to be transferred from the Battleford School Mr. Inspector Jackson is to arrange for this being done.

I think under the circumstances the Department will have to make an advance to the school to enable them to purchase their supplies, which could be deducted from the quarterly earnings.

Ottawa, August 28, 1914.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 31st ultimo in reference to the management, maintenance and equipment of the new Pas Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say with regard to Your Lordship's recommendation of Rev. L. Laronde for the position of principal of this school, that, while the Department recognizes that Mr. Laronde has the educational qualifications, it has no assurance that he has the business ability and experience which would justify the Department in entrusting a school of this class to his management. This school will be conducted on the per capita grant system and, while the allowance is considered enough under careful business management to meet all legitimate demands, there can be no margin left and it will require the closest economy and supervision to make ends meet. The school will have a deficit from the start, as funds will have to be advanced to enable it to be carried on from its inception, which will have to be repaid out of the per capita earnings. The Department regrets that it cannot accede to Your Lordship's wish to place this school in charge of Mr. Laronde, as it does not consider that he has had the necessary experience to enable him to successfully carry on an institution of this class. Sir,

I beg to report that one of the two teams of horses that were transferred from the Battleford Industrial School to Le Pas School as part of its equipment, has ever since its arrival here been useless and a source of expense. One horse of this team is troubled with rheumatism and lung trouble, and being over 20 years old, there is no hope of his becoming fit for service again. According to Mr. F. G. Barnes, he was sick at Battleford, was hardly able to make the landing here, and has been sick since.

We have tested this team regularly once a month after a month's rest and care, but at each trial the horse in question becomes almost too lame to walk and bleeds from the nose after a few hours' work, however light the work may be.

Under normal conditions we need one team to haul wood and hay and work about the place, and another team to assist, and to bring freight from the town, to get up ice, saw dust etc. The work in spring and summer...
will be still heavier as we shall require two teams to prepare our garden, pulling up stumps, haul away heavy stone, besides freighting etc. The roads here are of the heaviest, consisting of clay, stones, stumps and corduroy.

THE PAS AGENCY.

BY W. R. TAYLOR, INDIAN AGENT.

The Pas Agency consists of six Reserves, viz., The Pas, Moose Lake, Chemawawin, Cumberland, Shoal Lake and Red Earth; it embraces an Indian population of 1077 souls at the last annuity payments, when was paid the sum total of $5720.00.

The largest Reserve is The Pas, which also leads in population. These Indians draw more money annually than any of the other bands in the Agency, due to their sale of the land which now forms The Pas townsite. These Indians, being more numerous, also usually earn more by their hunting than the others. In previous years, their earnings amounted to thousands of dollars annually from the fur hunt alone, the prices of furs being so encouraging, that all who were able went to gather in the fur harvest. At the close of the fur season, which is May 15th, each hunter of thrift had a substantial account to his credit. What a contrast is found this season. The war between the Allies and Germany, has completely demoralized fur prices, and the Indians find it difficult to make even a living. I write now of the Reserves in general.

Times have been hard for our Indians. The fur trade outlook was so discouraging at the beginning of last winter that the usual outfitting for the winter hunt was stopped by the various traders and stores. The Indians were therefore thrown upon their own resources, which generally, towards winter, are limited. The Dept. of Indian Affairs, upon proper representations being made to them, stepped in and gave assistance to the more deserving cases. Ammunition and twine were given to help them in fishing and to store game for their winter use. Encouragement was given to lay up provisions, rather than to exert themselves in the fur hunt. Provisions had been placed on every Reserve for the aged and destitute, but owing to failure in prices for furs, our issues began in some instances earlier than usual. Consequently, the supply ran short sooner than in other years and had to be replenished.

Farming is encouraged among the various Bands, as far as is practicable, considering the nature of the country, which is not adapted to grain growing. Potatoes and vegetables are freely grown and mature well. In this, two Reserves, Shoal Lake and Red Earth, excel; there are grown the finest potatoes procurable, and in large quantities. These Indians always have a large surplus, which they sell to the Finger Lumber Company at a fair price.

The Reserves are visited in summer by gasolene launch, the "Ogemah;" and in winter, by dog-trains and, in some cases, by horses. We touch at all Reserves by water with our launch, with

OUR BOARDING SCHOOL.

In order to give our readers some conception of our School, we herewith subjoin a brief sketch of the site, buildings, and the present Staff of the School.

THE SITE

The School is situated on Fisher Island, about six miles from The Pas, and near the Big Eddy of the Saskatchewan River. The site is called an island because, at high water, it is entirely surrounded by water. At this time the only means of access is by boat which could come to within 200 yards from the School. At very low water, a narrow neck of land to the east connects the Island to the main-land, and it is possible to walk over this crossing on foot. Ordinarily, however, the water is high enough to isolate us, and crossing over to the mainland with horses would not be possible. The Fisher Creek to the south of us flows in a southerly direction and enters the Saskatchewan two miles away. A chain of lakes and mud-flats forms the other barrier around the Island. Fisher Island is about 320 acres in extent, and is thickly wooded with white poplar, with a sprinkling of birch and a few spruce, and the only clearing is a 20-acre space around the School. With the exception of a few acres this clearing is thickly studded with stumps and stones, and it will require hard work to clear enough acreage for a farm. The soil is vegetable mold over a clay sub-soil, which, with cultivation, should be productive. The thick woods which cover the Island will provide fuel for some years to come; while hay, barring floods, will be plentiful. The character of the Island points to farming as our principal means towards self-support, and this fits in with our hopes and aims. Other sites may claim superior advantages in the way of accessibility and beauty of surroundings, but we believe that a site of equal acreage and natural resources would be difficult to find within the same radius from The Pas.

THE BUILDINGS.

The main building is a three story frame structure on concrete foundations, 90ft. by 85ft., in the shape of a T, with commodious balconies on the whole of the front, where are located the fire escapes, consisting of brass sliding poles, with doors leading out from each dormitory and hallway. In the basement are located the bakery, acetylene gas-plant, laundry, drying-room, tank room, with a 3000 gallon compression tank, and a large soft-water cistern, boys' gymnasium, and the furnace room. On the main floor are the Indians' waiting-room, office, two sitting-rooms, main class-room dining-room, kitchen and pantries, and the girls' play-room, used also as a class-room. On the second floor, which is used by the
girls and staff, are two dormitories, with large clothes closets, two wash-rooms, two bath-rooms, sewing room; Principal and Matron's suite, and staff rooms. The third floor is similarly laid out as the second, and is occupied by the staff and boys. Hard-wood floors are used throughout, hot and cold water laid out on every floor; the building is heated by steam, while an acetylene gas plant, of 150-lights capacity, provides excellent light for the building.

The out-buildings, which are all excellent, consist of a barn, pigery, hen and root house, engine and pump house, store house, an ice house, and pupils' out-buildings.

These buildings were built and are owned by the Dept. of Indian Affairs, who have spared no expense to render them up-to-date and sanitary, and are an outcome of many years' experience of Indian education.

THE STAFF.

Rev. L. Laronde, M.A., B.D., acts as Principal. Mr. Laronde has an intimate knowledge of most of the different phases of Indian boarding school life and work, and also passed through the practical stage of teaching in Indian day schools in Western Ontario and Manitoba, and later as missionary under the Church Missionary Society, was engaged in Indian Mission work in the Diocese of Rupertslad among the Crees and Ojibways.

In every large school there is need for a mechanical genius. We have such a man in our Engineer, Mr. F. J. Watts, who not only attends to the machinery of the School and keeps them in proper running order, but also can turn his hand to almost anything that requires solving about the School, as he is a first class carpenter, and has served his time in tinsmithing and farming, and can also work at the forge.

Mr. M. Demerse came to us only recently, but has already made his influence felt. He knows farm work both in the East and West, and under his management, our stock has shown a marked improvement. Besides assisting the Principal in the care of the boys, his interest and skill in athletics has caused increased enthusiasm for outdoor sports among the pupils, and we feel sure that the important work of clearing and laying out our farm will prosper under his charge.

Mr. Robt. McGillivray, as labourer, has proved himself thoroughly reliable in his own field, and has ever been a staunch advocate of the School among his people. We regret that he is severing his connection with us this month.

Mrs. Laronde, as honorary matron, brings to her work both ability and the experience needed for this important position. She has had a successful career as a school teacher in Quebec, as well as among the Indians in the West, marked by a succession of prizes and bonuses secured by her schools.

Miss H. Hayes, assistant matron, has had a long and successful career in a similar capacity at the Battleford Industrial School. We consider ourselves fortunate to have secured her services, as her experience has gained her control of children and the ability to win their affections.

Miss M. G. Willis, B.A., is a graduate of Owen's College, of the University of Manchester, with five year's practical experience in England, and two years in Canada, in country schools, as well as at St. Alban's Ladies' College, Prince Albert. Her work as senior teacher will be increasingly effective with the advance of her pupils.

Miss K. S. S. Upsdell, our primary teacher, has a second class professional standing. She received her training at Goldsmith's Training College, University of London, and her practical experience consisted of six year's teaching in London and in Dartford, England, and one year in Canada, at Coblenz, Sask. Full of energy and enthusiasm, and gifted with unusual musical ability, she fills an important place in our school, and under her tutelage, our pupils are gaining fast in music, singing, as well as in their other work.

Miss Olive Hitchcox is one of the workers sent out by the Women's Auxiliary to our School,
and we have been fortunate indeed in her choice. She presides over the kitchen with great ability, and a great deal of the good health of our pupils is due to her skill. Miss Hitchcox came from England four years ago with her people who made their home at Oakville, Ont. She was accepted by the W.A., and was sent as a probationer to the Chapleau Indian Boarding School, and completed her training at the Hospital for Sick Children and at the Alexandra School for Girls, Toronto, when she was accepted as a W.A. missionary and sent to our School.

Miss Norma Moody, the other of our W.A. workers, received her training at the Battleford Industrial School, and the Battleford General Hospital. She is in charge of the Sewing room, and of all the pupils' clothing, which is a work which requires patience, industry and able management. Miss Moody, we are sorry to say, is not with us at present, as an unfortunate accident to her arm made it necessary for her to go to Winnipeg, but we hope to have her back with us soon. Miss Moody has endeared herself to all the girls.

The Indian Hospital at Fisher Island

THE INDIAN HOSPITAL.

For the benefit of the School and of the Indians of the surrounding Reserves, the Dept. of Indian Affairs built on a site within 300 feet from the School a hospital for the sick, at a cost of $10,000. As can be seen from our cut, it is a substantial frame building, capable of accommodating 25 patients, with basement and a veranda extending the width of the front. Water and light are supplied from the School plants, while the heating is from two hot air furnaces in the basement. On the ground floor are the doctor's office, men's ward, women's ward, dispensary, operating room, dining room, kitchen and pantry; on the second floor are two semi-private wards, doctor's bedroom, nurse's bedroom, and sitting room, house-keeper's room, bathroom, linen room, and a bedroom for emergency help. Separate in a wing by itself is the isolation ward for infectious cases. The interior is finished in beaverboard; the walls are sheeted with alternate layers of lumber, Cabot's quilt and Neponset paper, and the whole finished off on the outside by three-ply roofing.

The nurse in charge of the hospital is Miss Mabel Jenner. She is a graduate of St. Joseph's, Chatham, Ont. Before she came here she was engaged in private nursing in Winnipeg for three years. Miss Jenner is indefatigable in her duties to the sick from the School and from the Reserves. She is winning her way into the hearts of the Indians and quickly breaking down the prejudice against hospitals which usually characterises them at first. From the very first good work has been accomplished, and we look forward to its still greater usefulness and benefit. Patients are coming now as far as from Nelson House on the Hudson's Bay. The hospital is entirely under the control of the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Mr. Glen Campbell, Chief Inspector, was a visitor at our School.

S. J. Jackson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, made his official visit recently. His visit has been very helpful to us, not only by his friendly counsel and advice, but also by his practical efforts in our behalf. Our long delayed equipment has been purchased and shipped by him since his departure and is now ready to our hand.
Indian Agent, W. R. Taylor, in his monthly visits, has shown unfailing interest in our School.

Rev. Canon and Mrs. Matheson visited us last January. The long experience of these faithful workers was specially helpful to all.

Miss Kate E. Halson, the General Dorcas Secretary, spent two weeks at our School last Oct. while on her Western tour of W. A. work. We were delighted to have Miss Halson come to our School for first hand impressions of our position and needs. We have no sincerer friend or a more indefatigable worker on our behalf than Miss Halson, and we gladly render our thanks to her. Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just been staying for three days at the "John A. Macdonald" Boarding School, The Pas. In my judgment all is going on exceedingly well. There are just now 82 children on the roll, a few more, just under age, who will join the roll next quarter. They are the healthiest looking lot I have seen at any of the schools, & in manners & conduct already show a marked improvement; while they seem very intelligent & are making rapid progress in their learning. I am particularly pleased with all I see at the school. The buildings & equipment also merit commendation, & I am really grateful to the Department for such an institution & have told the parents of the pupils that they are very fortunate. Some of the equipment is not yet complete by any means, especially as regards the forming of their outdoor departments; but I think that for a beginning it is in fairly advanced condition. All this has meant hard & faithful work on the part of the Principal & all his staff, & I think praise is due to them. The work has been all the harder because they are a little short-handed. Miss Moody has been absent from serious trouble following a broken arm, which has necessitated serious surgical treatment. But we hope that she will be back very soon, & we are expecting another lady also to take charge of taking care of laundry work, which for some time has been done by members of the staff who should be free from this extra work. There will also be changes in the female staff.

Sir,

I have been given to understand by the Ven. Archdeacon Mackay on his return from his visit to Ottawa, that the Department would assist the school in defraying the heavy expenses in connection with the securing of our hay last summer.

As you are aware the floods destroyed every vestige of hay around the school, and it was necessary to purchase hay and feed to keep up our stock during the summer until we could bring in our summer's cut at the Carrot River.

As soon as our flats were flooded we had the Ross Navigation Co. transport our outfit 7 miles up the Saskatchewan where we cut about 15 tons before we were again flooded. We then had our outfit transported 35 miles up the Carrot River where we put up about 90 tons.

We found it would have been prohibitive to get our hay pressed and hauled during the summer, and found it cheaper to buy sufficient hay to carry us till we could haul our hay in winter from Carrot River.

In the winter hauling, it will be necessary to have a man in camp at the hay field to load and bring the team half-way to the school and be met by another team with an empty load, then exchange sleighs and return to camp and load up ready for the next day. We can only bring in 5 or 6 tons per week, and it will require about 15 weeks to haul all.
our hay with the two teams that would be available, leaving one team to do the work around the School.

The assistance of the Department in this matter will be very welcome, as without it, this heavy expense for hay and feed would become a burden to the School which would add much to our deficit.

Sir,

A few days ago Dr. Orok of Le Pas, while in the city, told me that there was an epidemic of sickness at the Le Pas Indian School, which he thought was due to a stoppage in the sewer, and that he thought it would be well for me to go out to investigate. So I left for there on Wednesday morning Nov. 24th, and arrived the following day and went out with Dr. Robertson, who is acting for Dr. Orok, to the Hospital and Indian School. I found thirty cases of typhoid fever including four of the staff at the School, and the Housekeeper at the Hospital. A woman had been authorized to assist at the School, so I left her to take care of the staff, sick at the School, and instructions for all the pupils, laid up at the School, to be removed to the Hospital with their beds and bedding, as soon as another nurse had arrived from Winnipeg, for whom I had telegraphed for. The nurse at the Hospital was absolutely alone, to cook and look after about ten cases, and it was utterly impossible for her to continue without help. I requested Mr. Taylor, the Agent, to have a woman replace the Housekeeper at the Hospital for a month, and that with the assistance of the extra nurse, who left here on Friday morning, Nurse Jenner says that she thinks they could manage. It will mean about twenty-five cases at the Hospital, and there are more cases developing each day.

The sewer has been attended to and it is running freely now, but no disinfectants had been used, so I ordered lime, chloride of lime and formalin to be used thoroughly, and also instructed that the water and milk be boiled before being used.

Dr. Robertson will go out every second day, and if necessary will go every day.
I brought in samples of milk and water to be analyzed. The water was found to be all right, but I think the trouble is carried by the milk through handling. A thorough process of disinfection will be carried out, but there has never been any stationary laundry tub placed in the laundry and connected with the water system, for which a request had been made before.

There is also a hot water tank there which is burst from top to bottom and the nurse says that they have no hot water for their baths, since she has been there, and it is very important to have good facilities for washing in Hospitals, particularly with an epidemic of this sort. The tank, I am told, can not be repaired without sending it back to the foundry and a new one can be got for somewhere in the neighborhood of $15.00.

In clearing out the sewer, a man-hole has been put in between the Y and the septic tank, but to facilitate it being cleaned out other times, a man-hole should be put in at the Y and another one between the Y and Hospital. Mr. Jackson, the Inspector, had sewer rods supplied for cleaning out the sewer, and Mr. Lerond, Principal of the School, has asked for some plungers to be used. So I have ordered a dozen of them and a dozen enamel bed-pans and a dozen towels.

I have sent out typhoid vaccine to inoculate those at the School who have not contracted the disease.

I have taken all this responsibility of engaging the Nurse and so forth, on myself, as it is too serious a matter to trifle with, and I trust you will approve of my actions.

Yours respectfully,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

The Indians of Canada, as a race, through no fault of their own, have played but a minor part in the War. At the commencement of the war there were few more eager to offer their means and personal services than the Indians, but for some incomprehensible reason their offers to form battalions or regiments were refused, although they were not debarred from enlisting individually, as it were on the quiet, and their money was accepted. This anomalous state of affairs is now ended, and the Indians can take their place as an integral part of the British Empire, and go forth, as a unit, to fight for King and Country. The Indian has played a no mean part in the history of Canada, his courage and steadiness has been proved on many a battlefield, while his loyalty is undoubted. Their native qualities will make the Indians, once they adapted themselves to the intricacies of modern warfare, good soldiers, trench fighting would come natural to them, and, as scouts and snipers, they would have few equals. There are already many Indians at the front, fighting in the trenches with credit to themselves and to their race, many are now in training and we feel sure that they will rally round the Flag as long as there is need and their numbers last.

For the Church this movement means a call for further sacrifice,—to provide, as leaders, men who understand and sympathise with the Indians, or in other words, Indian missionaries and workers. As its capacity for sacrifice and the loyalty of its members is well known, the Church may confidently be expected not to fail in this crisis.
DOINGS OF THE SCHOOL.

Since our last issue we have passed through an anxious and critical time on account of an epidemic of sickness which visited the School from about the middle of October to the middle of December when the last case went down. Owing to the peculiar nature of the symptoms we failed to obtain a definite diagnosis of the epidemic until after six weeks, by which time the epidemic had reached its height and thereafter soon spent itself. The epidemic was ascribed variously as due to ptomaine poisoning, injudicious or over-eating, sewer-gas poisoning, mud-fever from the eating of ducks, etc.; consequently our efforts to combat it were of a random nature. The Department sent its Medical Superintendent, on Nov. 25th., who pronounced the epidemic a mild type of typhoid. Vigorous measures were prescribed in the way of diet, disinfection and the isolation of patients in the hospital. At its height there were 21 pupils down with the disease, and 5 out the Staff. With the help of nurses supplied by the Indian Department we were able to carry on the usual routine of the School.

Happily all our pupils and Staff have come through the epidemic as well as ever; but it was not permitted us to come through our time of trial altogether without sorrow. The infant son of Rev. and Mrs. Laronde, at a time when the mother herself was sick, became a victim of the typhoid and, in spite of robust constitution, succumbed to the disease on Nov. 28th. after less than three weeks' illness. The child's death was felt all the more keenly inasmuch as he was born and brought up in our midst, and was looked upon as the School baby.

As to when or how the infection of typhoid began it would be impossible to say. There had been an outbreak of typhoid in town and about thirty cases had developed, and it is thought that there was a connection between the two outbreaks.

The shadow of the epidemic passed away with the approach of the holidays, and, the time of anxiety being past, we were able to enjoy the Christmas season all the more, with our numbers complete with the exception of 18 pupils who were still in the hospital, but convalescent. Chiefly through the generosity of the Girls' Auxiliary of All Saints' Church, Ottawa, we were able to have a Christmas Tree entertainment on Christmas Eve. The class room was tastefully decorated with evergreens, wreathing, Chinese lanterns and flags, while the Tree was loaded down with gifts for over 100 people. Several carols were nicely rendered by different classes and by all the pupils. Then the jingle of Sant-
ta Claus' bells could be heard and he entered amid tense excitement on the part of the pupils and Indians. Santa Claus is still unfamiliar enough to most of our pupils as to be an awesome figure to them, and in spite of his gentleness was regarded with terror by the little ones. However, he won their hearts by his liberality, and all went happily to bed with their gifts after they had sung "God Save the King," and gave three cheers for Principal and Mrs. Laronde, and three for Santa Claus. Then Santa must needs go over to the hospital to visit the children there. So preceded by the members of the Staff, bearing his gifts, Santa here also brought pleasure to the children and, amid squeals of delight or fright, gave every one a gift. Mr. Turner made a very excellent Santa Claus.

On Christmas morning all the children attended the Christmas service, after which they sat down to a substantial Christmas dinner, which was eaten up with relish. Lastly, there is a rush on the part of the girls to wash up dishes and put things aright, for by this time there are many dog trains and an occasional horse and sleigh waiting outside which are to carry them home for a brief visit to their parents.

On the afternoon of the appointed day for the return to the School, there is a steady stream of men and women, on foot or with dog trains or horses, bringing their children home. The return is marked by a greater exuberance of spirits than the departure from School, showing that however great the attractions of the home were the School was still a dearer place. By the morning of Jan. 3rd. the School had resumed its accustomed routine and activity.

With the Christmas holidays we lost through their graduation four more of our pupils, viz; Gilbert Moore, Frederick Young, Simeon Bear and George Cowan. The benefit that these boys derived by their year's stay in the School, and their worth, may be measured by the extent they have been missed in the different departments of our School life, and we feel sure that they will acquit themselves true men in the battle of life.

The Farmer and his boys are busy transporting hay from our distant hayfield to the School. By steady hauling with two teams, they bring about six tons a week.

In the proposed Indian Contingent or Contingents, to be raised in this district and elsewhere, the War is coming nearer home to us. The call will find the School ready. The Principal has been offered a commission in the proposed contingent, and if the way be open, he will join. All our ex-pupils, interviewed so far, have expressed a willingness to join, and among our available pupils there is the same ready spirit.
LOCALS.

DIED.—At the Mackay Boarding School, on Nov. 28th., 1915, Melvin Jenner, son of Rev. and Mrs. Laronde, aged 10 months and 8 days.

To Mr. Demerse we owe the excellent cut of our football team, which is reproduced here.

Dr. Robertson inoculated with typhoid antitoxin about 40 of the children who had not been affected by the epidemic.

Dr. Robertson, of The Pas, was on Nov. 1st., appointed as Doctor for the Indian Department in this district, in succession to Dr. R. D. Orok, who has gone to the War.

Mrs. L. Laronde, accompanied by her son, left at the beginning of the Christmas holidays for a three months' visit at her old home in Lachute, P.Q., to recuperate after her recent illness.

Nurse Jenner, on her return from her holidays in the West, found enough fever cases to fill the hospital, and for next five weeks attended full wards, with the assistance of Nurse Smith, of Winnipeg.

Dr. Grain, Medical Superintendent of the Indian Department, visited the School in connection with the epidemic. Thorough tests were instituted by the Doctor of the water supply, milk, etc., without discovery of the bacillus.

Mrs. C. Holman, of The Pas, spent two weeks at the School to assist in nursing during the epidemic, and was relieved by Mrs. W. Slaney.

With the thermometer registering around 50 degrees below zero, our heating system has had a severe test, but, with the exception of the gymnasium and main class room, there was a sufficiency of steam to heat the whole building comfortably.

NOTES FROM OUR PUPILS

I went to the hayfield last week; it is not very far by the winter road—about sixteen miles.—Barnabas Marles.

The girls learn to play basketball; Mr. Laronde plays with us; first the little girls play, then the big girls. We like to play basketball.—Elsie Ross.

I am office girl this week. First thing in the morning before breakfast, I sweep the three office rooms, dust chairs and office desk, and set things right. After breakfast I tidy up the Principal's rooms.—Sarah Paul.

On Christmas night Santa Claus came; he first went to sit on a chair, but the chair fell down. Mrs. Laronde said 'Hello, Santa Claus.' I went out because I thought Santa was not nice. The little girls cried and got up on desks, but the boys laughed. But I guess Santa was having fun because he shouted 'Hip, hip, hurrah.'—Mary Moore.

Mr. Laronde got us a Christmas tree; he hung up dollies, candles and candies. Santa Claus came to the Christmas tree and ran round the room and gave presents to the children and ladies. The little girls screamed and cried. The girls in front sang carols. The girls wore their blue Sunday dresses. When all was finished the children sang "God save the King." Santa took off his hat and mask, and let the cheering, and said good-bye to us.—Elsie Ross.

I went home for the Christmas holidays, and I was very glad to come back to school again. On New Year's day we had a good time; all of us girls from Big Eddy and Carrot River were sliding and playing other games; the men played football, while the women played other nice games. I was glad to meet the girls who left the School last October.—Hagar Cook.

We were in the hospital for three weeks sick with fever. We did not eat anything at all, but had things to drink. We were very hungry sometimes. We asked Miss Jenner to give us bread, but she didn't because she was afraid of the Doctor. The Doctor said if we ate meat or bread we would not get well. We were sorry to miss the Christmas tree at the School, but Santa Claus made us happy by coming and giving us our presents.—Mary Jane Cook.

At the School they had a Christmas tree, but I did not see it because I was in the hospital. Santa Claus came to the hospital and gave us our dolls, ribbons and handkerchiefs. We all sat on our beds and screamed when he came in. He gave us our presents, and he danced in the middle of the ward and he told us that he came from Cumberland and that he had seen the children there. Then he sang "It's a long way to Tipperary," and after that he took off his hat and mask, and we saw it was Mr. Turner.—Sophia Thomas.
There were four calves born before Christmas.—John W. Harris.

I work on the skating rink and sweep it clean.—Alfred McGillivray.

I work in the laundry. I fill the tubs to the top and look after the engine.—Elijah Tobacco.

I can go on my skates well now. We have to keep the rink swept each day.—John Bear.

My work is in the furnace room; I put in wood into the furnace every hour because it has been so cold.—James Partridge.

Walter Head and Matthew McGillivray are gone to the hayfield today; two others will go next day.—Absalom Cook.

We go to school every afternoon, and after school we play basket-ball, first the little girls, and then the big girls.—Priscilla Bell.

I was happy on Christmas night, Santa Claus came and peeped in at the window and frightened us. He came in and ran round the room, giving each girl her present.—Sarah Buck.

I carry wood into the kitchen and bakery every day; when I finish there I go to the skating rink and sweep it. When I hear the big bell I come in and brush my hair; when the little bell rings I line up with the other boys in the play-room and march in to school. I learn arithmetic, spelling, reading, to write stories from the 3rd Reader and to draw maps.—Simon Gavin.

The pigs are growing big. There are seven young calves.—Robert John Head.

The little girls learn to play basketball. We play with Mr. Laronde, first the small girls and later the big girls. When we finish we get ready for supper. I like the game very much.—Eliza Paul.

Some of the boys sweep the rink every morning. We play hockey after dinner; the boys and girls skate together after school. We have lots of fun on the rink, but some of the boys are too lazy or are afraid to play hockey.—Albert Flett.

One Wednesday evening the bigger boys and girls had a social evening. We played musical chairs, the Jolly Miller and other games. Then one the Staff hid the thimble and we tried to find it; if a girl or boy finds it she would hide it. When we finished playing, we had some tea and biscuits; then we had prayers and so to bed. The little boys and girls will play next week.—Emma Settee.

I work in the sewing room. Every day I sew clothes for boys and girls. Three girls mend mocassins every morning. I guess I will work in another place next week. I like to work everywhere for then I can learn. I was sorry Emma hurt herself on the eye with a needle. That is all the news I have to tell.—Matilda Wilson.

II. Adjectives.

Adjectives are more commonly found in a verbalized form; as, ā miywatiset eyine, lit. he who is good the Indian = the good Indian.

There are few Separable Adjectives in the Cree language; such are Kiche, great; Miyo, good; Muche, bad; Oske, new; Kwuyusk, right; but adjectives may be formed from abstract nouns by omitting the final 'n'; as U-yumihawin, prayer, U-yumihawe mussinühikun, a Prayer book.

The comparative of adjectives is formed by prefixing Uwusimä, more, to the positive; and the Superlative by prefixing Uyiwak, most.

Miywatisew, He is good.
Uwusimä meywatisew, he is better.
Uyiwak meywatisew, he is best.

Good, nice, minwasin, meywasin.
Good, kind, he is, miywatisew.
Bad, mayatun; he is-, muchatisew. Lazy, he is, kitimew. Happy, he is, meywäyimoo, meywäyitum. Obedient, he is, nunuhitum. Proud, he is, kechetwawayimoo. Cowardly, he is, sakotääo.

In regard to your criticism of our article on Compulsory Education in our Sept. 9 Oct. issue, I beg to say that I was aware that there is a provision whereby regulations may be made at any time by the Governor in Council to secure the compulsory attendance of children at school. So that theoretically the Dept. is up-to-date on the question of Compulsory Education, but practically it is as stated in our paper; there is Compulsory Education in potential but not in actual Instances to my knowledge of appeal for enforcement of education to the Indian Act have been in each case refused. I beg further to refer you to the Winnipeg Resolutions of 1907, wherein the need of some system of Compulsory education was felt to be necessary by those interested in Indian work, and admitted by the Deputy Superintendent, in his reply, as far as attendance at the day schools was concerned.

In my request for assistance in the way of literature, I was bidding at the same time for your co-operation, so that whatever was published bearing on the work of the Dept. should be done from the point of view of the Dept. Your reply to this was a condemnation for incompetence in regard to the management of our sewers which condemnation, in turn, was based on a report made at random, without personal inspection and only from hearsay, and consequently unreliable. Failing a supply
of material from the Dept. we must use what we can secure, and naturally this will be utilized from the individual standpoint with the consequent liability to error. But as our aim is for truth and justice we shall not knowingly be party to any prejudicial utterances, and if found out in such will thankfully publish any corrections submitted.

Your intimation to bring these matters to my Bishop characterizes your letter, which otherwise was very fair, as being on a par with your previous personal communications wherein I have yet to find that spirit of patient and friendly sympathy and justice which, as Principal of one of your schools, I have the right to expect from the active head of the Dept., and being deprived of which renders one discouragingly handicapped.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Committee base their action on the assumption that the floods on the Saskatchewan come in cycles—that following last year's floods there will be another six years of successive floods. This assumption is contradicted by the testimony of the Indians here as well as by the old timers, who unite...
In saying that there is a flood once every seven years, and that successive floods have been unknown.

It is a well-known fact and a matter of common sense that floods on the Saskatchewan are caused, not by excessive snow-fall in the mountains, but by cloud-bursts and excessive rains, and these conditions are unusual.

Because other schools, e.g., Lac la Ronge Boarding School, can plod along with one team, 1 cow, hand-pumps, box-stoves etc., is no reason why the MacKay Boarding School which was built on first-class principles, should be degraded to the level of a second-rate school.

One good year will enable us to put up more than two years' supply of hay from our own flats, while two years would make our stock a source of revenue.

Even were the assumption of successive floods true, it would still be an easy and worthwhile to go up the Carrot River for our hay—provided the Dept. assisted us, e.g., by the grant of a hay-press and perhaps by undertaking the cost of our transportation. The Dept. has set the school forward.

Sir:

The Bishop of Saskatchewan has informed me that at a meeting of their Indian School Committee held Feb. 15th, it was decided that the Department should be asked to reduce the farm stock at this school to two teams of horses, 6 cows and 1 bull—the balance to be sold for the benefit of the School to recoup in part the heavy expense of the season for hay because of last summer's floods and that the stock be limited to the above number.

As the one most concerned in the success or failure of this School, I wish to register my protest against the course advocated by the Committee.

The grounds on which they base this sudden reversal of policy are (1) the assumption that the floods on the Saskatchewan come in cycles—that following last season's flood, there will be a succession of floods each summer for six more years; and (2) stock raising does not pay.

In asking that the above request be not allowed I do so on the following grounds. (1) the course advocated by the Committee is too precipitate. Let us put the question of the possibility of stock-raising to a thorough test. A year's test is not a fair criterion and a year's experience does not give a true indication of the resources and possibilities of a locality.

(2) The assumption of the Committee is contradicted by the Indians and old-timer, who live on the River, who claim that there is a flood once in about every seven years, followed by successive good years.

(3) It is a matter of common sense and a well-known fact that floods on the Saskatchewan are due not to excessive snowfall but to excessive rains in the Mountains in conjunction with cloud-bursts and these no one can predict with certainty and are not of yearly occurrence. Present indications do not point to a flood;
The River is low; the heavy snowfall of November and December has shrunk under the recent three days' thaw and last season's waters were drained away.

4. The Fundamental reason which has influenced the Committee in their request is not the floods but undue conservatism and an adherence to a conservative ideal. Lac la Ronge B. School happens to be a pet of the Ven. Archdeacon Mackey and it is the Archdeacon who has inspired the course of the Committee. But that Lac la Ronge Boarding School has hitherto plodded along with 1 team, 1 cow & hand pump box-stoves etc., is no reason why the Mackey Boarding School should be degraded to follow the same narrow rut. The Mackey Boarding school was built on a different principle and was launched on a more ambitious scale and should be allowed the necessary liberty of action, time and patience to work out its destiny.

5. It is easy to descend but difficult enough to ascend in the scale of endeavour. To deny a person the right to pursue the path of any high hope he may have formed, or to see the outcome of his enthusiasm, is to take from him all incentive to living endeavour. It is cruel if not utterly wrong to destroy or nullify the ideals and enthusiasms of the young, because, perchance, the old have seen their futility.

6. I believe that one good year will enable us to put up more than two years' supply of hay from our own flats; that two good years would make our stock a source of revenue, and that once we can insure ourselves against a poor season, we could never again be compelled to pass through such a trying season as the last.

To make a success of our farm however, we need generous treatment from the Department, in the following form:

1. The setting aside of a hay reserve for the school on the Carrot River beyond reach of floods. Steps are being taken with the Department to have this done.

2. The grant of a hay press, so that in case of a flood we could press our hay and have it hauled by water to the school.
We could not afford to repeat this year's experiment of hauling about 80 tons of hay by the school teams, because of the labour and time involved.

The undertaking by the Department the cost of transportation by water involved in getting hay in seasons of flood.

I have written to the Department on this subject but I wish to secure further your co-operation, as I know you are a firm believer in the possibilities of Fisher Island, and consequently would not passively allow this injustice to be done to the school on a matter which will mean success or failure for us.

I am Sir,

Obediently yours,

Louis Leronde (sgd)

Christian in Heart; Manly in Character; of Sound Body.

Vol. II. THE PAS, MAN., MAR. & APR., 1916. No. 1.

The Advocate will be issued once every two months under the auspices of the Church of England Boarding School, The Pas, Man.

All communications and remittances in connection with our paper to be addressed, The Principal, The Mackay Boarding School, The Pas, Man.

With this issue we enter upon the second year of our little paper. While we have not yet realized our hope to make our paper a mouth-piece of the Indian missionary work of the Diocese, we have succeeded in keeping the School before its friends. We trust that our friends will continue their support and encouragement to The Advocate.

In the academic field the education of the Indian is carried on by four classes of schools—the Day, the Improved Day, the Boarding, and the Industrial Schools. Beginning in this, and in subsequent issues, we hope to deal with each type of school, and endeavour to point out their respective merits and defects and relative importance and interdependence. The Day School, with which we deal in this issue, is, in point of numbers the most important, but in results the weakest in the chain; yet its persistence, in spite of general condemnation, consists in the fact that it is a pioneer in its field, a flame, however feeble, where otherwise would be scholastic darkness; matters would be infinitely worse without its existence, and it is capable of modification and improvement as to become potent for good in its field. The day will come when, as a Consolidated School, it will take its rightful place, in the vastness of its sphere of influence and capacity to keep in advance of the civilisation of its neighbourhood, to a position of the first importance, as the foundation and nourisher of all other types of schools. The attainment of this desirable end is now in its initial stage; its realisation is a matter of liberality on the part of the Canadian people.
DOINGS OF THE SCHOOL.

The health of our pupils for the past four months has been excellent, and there have been but a few minor ailments incidental to the season.

With the break-up of the river the high water has cut us off from the mainland and there was no crossing except by boats for over two weeks.

Our gasoline launch, the "Big Eddy," has been thoroughly overhauled, cleaned and painted, and is ready again for service.

The pupils viewed with regret the sudden cessation to their hockey and skating, but, with the optimism of youth, they have turned to quoits, baseball, football, and other summer pastimes and games, and find them fully as delightful as the winter games. An innovation has been made for the girls in the introduction of baseball among their games, and judging from the comments overheard this game has come to stay.

The boys have no more occasion to covet the girls' swings, as they have had a double swing with horizontal bar put up for them; another is soon to go up, with a third swing and a trapeze. We have now a full equipment to occupy healthily the leisure hours of all our pupils.

Our pupils have shown their eagerness to learn the English language by voluntarily asking that they be forbidden to talk Cree; we were prepared to make a rule to this effect sometime in the future, but we hardly expected to have our hands forced in this manner, and to have to jump in eighteen months from exclusive Cree to exclusive English. Although we know the hardship and lapses it will cause, the rule has been made, to apply at first only within the building. We notice that the children are more subdued than formerly about the building.

That the interest and love for the Cree hymn-book might not be destroyed by overuse the Sankey & Moody hymn-book has been introduced for use in the Sunday School. We now have the Cree hymn-book at the Sunday morning Service, Sankey & Moody in Sunday School, and the Hymn Book at the evening Service and daily prayers.

With the passing away of the snow our almost endless warfare against brush, stones and stumps has been renewed in earnest. The boys work in relays, half being at school while the other is in the field; while from four to five the girls add their willing hands to the work, and the boys in the field are reinforced by those just out from school. Though the work is still vast, we are able more and more to centralize our efforts on the important work of the farm.

Mr. Demerse, before leaving the School, presented the boys with a new football.

Inspector S. J. Jackson, made his annual visit of inspection of the School last month.

The School will be represented by Miss N. Moody at the coming Annual of the Diocesan Women's Auxiliary at Saskatoon.

THE DAY SCHOOL.

The day schools form over 75 per cent. of the total number of schools in Canada for the education of the Indians. There are supported by the Government, are Government inspected, but are under denominational control. The salary paid is $300 a year. A change for the better was made a few years ago in this respect, and a certificated teacher can now receive $500.

The Day School was the earliest experiment in the education of the Indian, and was the result of missionary enterprise. The first grant by Parliament was made in 1875, when $2000 was voted for day schools in Ontario. From that time this class of school has passed gradually into the hands of the Government. The typical day school of the old type was unpretentious: a simple one-roomed building was planted in as central a location as possible on a reserve, and gave tuition to the children who choose to come to the school for five or six hours per teaching day; while the teacher was empowered to help and encourage the pupils by the issue of two hard-tack biscuits to each. Owing, however, to the peculiar condition of most of the Indian reserves and the characteristics of the people, the insufficiency of the average day school became apparent at the outset. The following are the chief difficulties met with in connection with Indian day schools and which militate against their success:

1. The nomadic habit of the Indian which takes him away from the reserve for long periods at a time in pursuit of his livelihood, prevents regularity of attendance. An absence from the school for two months on the part of a child nullifies that child's previous half-year's training.

2. Too often there is apathy and a lack of desire for advancement in both parent and child, and the advantages of the school are neglected or used only spasmodically.

3. The severe deterrent of poverty is often present. Many children have insufficient clothing during the winter, and the provision for a mid-day meal is in many cases neglected.

4. When the child comes to an age between 12 and 14 years, the call of the wild overcomes his fondness for the school; or, he is then required to help at home. The school age of the average child is thus from 6 to 12, and the limit of education is the 2nd or 3rd Reader.

5. The supply of fuel for the winter months is left to the management of Indians, and too often they have not sufficient interest in the school to induce them to fulfil this duty, and, in consequence, the school is frequently closed.
6. It is exceedingly difficult to get efficient teachers. The insufficiency of the Government grant, the lack of proper accommodation, the enforced residence on the reserve, the isolation, often in the remote parts of the country, the discouragements due to the apathy of the people for any efforts made for their advancement, the lack of all incentives except, perhaps, that of doing good, and the absence (apart from the Church) of any hope of advancement—these are enough to daunt and discourage all but the most devoted and self-sacrificing.

7. The teaching and influence of even our best teachers is sadly hindered by bad surroundings. The old Persian belief in the struggle between light and darkness—good and evil—finds its sad counterpart, alas, too real, in the life of many an Indian child.

8. Lastly, there is the drawback of ignorance of the English language, and the unsatisfactory nature of the text-books and course of study. The texts deal mostly with matters requiring previous knowledge of the world—the manners, customs, and ways of thinking of a different race, if not of a different country; while the course of study is that of the Public School. And when we consider that most of the children are learning to read in an alien tongue, we must admit the amount of work required of them is very great.

It is only fair to remark that these facts become modified in proportion as the Indians become civilized. Under the most favourable circumstances the Indian day school approximates closely to the Public School, and in some cases becomes merged with it, and its evolution is then complete. These circumstances, however, are rare, and, on the whole, the day school of the past generation is a failure. This is acknowledged both by the Department of Indian Affairs and by the Churches:

(a) "The Indian day school of the lowest type is a burden to the teacher and an inexplicable punishment to the scholar, almost useless in its results."—Superintendent of Indian Education, Blue Book, 1910, p. 274.

(b) It has been the practice of the Romanists, whose wisdom and foresight no one doubts, to do away with day schools in the West, and establish boarding schools in their place. In this connection we may quote one of their Bishops, (Bishop Legal, in the Manitoba Free Press, May 13, 1908):—"As to trying again the system of day schools in place of the boarding schools, it is, to any one who is even slightly acquainted with the conditions of our Indian reserves, at least in the West, a perfect delusion and a farce. This system has been tried and found wanting."

Sir,

On July 26th last I made a visit of inspection to The Pas Indian Boarding School. I found that on account of the very high water in the Saskatchewan river it will be impossible to get any hay this season. No hay will be obtained during the present season anywhere within forty miles of The Pas. Mr. Taylor, The Indian Agent, was arranging to go out with the Councillors of the Pas Band to see if they could get hay somewhere in the Moose Lake district. If they find hay, they will put it up and then drive all their stock there after the ice forms and will winter their stock where they put up the hay.

I am sending you attached a statement showing you what the school will likely have in the way of feed for their stock, the land cleared, and the number of horses and cattle they now have on hand. I am of the opinion that it will be advisable and necessary to come to the relief of this school by assisting them to buy hay for the coming winter. If this is not done authority will have to be given them to dispose of their stock. The deficit since starting the school is roughly $3000.00 and the church feel that they cannot increase this to the large extent necessary to feed the stock on hand during the winter.

It will take about 100 hundred tons of hay to feed their stock and in the Swan River or Melfort districts I can buy this hay baled for about $8.00 a ton delivered at the Pas. As you will notice by the Statement they now have cleared about 20 acres more land and if assistance was given this fall they could clear this land of stumps and stones.
and have it ready for planting fodder corn next Spring.

I would recommend that assistance be given as outlined and if thought advisable I will go up and see that matters are arranged as desired by the Department.

March 10th, 1917.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that our financial statement for the year ending March 31st, 1917, shows a total deficit of $3673.51. This sum is sufficiently large as to be embarrassing and might cause inconvenience. We beg, therefore, to make application to the Dept. for relief, and in doing so we beg to submit the following considerations:

I. We began operations in 1914 with a deficit of $200, incurred in our taking over the buildings from the Contractors and putting them in running order.

II. For our first quarter, instead of receiving our full income of $2000, we received only $1369, due to a shortage in our numbers, which in turn was caused by the difficulties of travel at the season we opened the School.

III. In 1915, our first season, we suffered from floods and drought. To provide feed for our stock we had to go far afield for hay, incurring, over and above what we considered would have been the legitimate expenses had we cut from our flats, an extra expense of $1700. Our farm also, for drought, caused us loss.

IV. In 1916, our second season, we suffered from even worse floods than in 1915, and also from rains in Spring and drought in Summer. The feeding of the stock in summer, fall and first part of the winter, was a continual expense, while our farm did not make a return of the outlay put upon it.

V. In this season, when we saw that a bad flood was inevitable, help was procured, after our seeding was about done, to provide an emergency pasture of about five acres for our stock, entailing an expense in this work and in other things of a similar nature, to provide against the flood, of about $1000.

VI. Because our gasoline had become unsafe, we found it neces-
necessary to procure a new hull in a knock-down state, at a cost, for the materials alone, of $200.

VII. The freezing of water-pipes, sewer, septic-tank and septic-tank outlet, has made it necessary to open up these lines in the dead of winter, for which fires and their attendance were required day and night, and entailing an outlay of about $200 to date.

Summarized, the above may be given roughly as follows:

| Description                                      | Amount |
|--------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Preliminary expenses                             | $200   |
| Loss of Income during first Qr.                  | 621    |
| Extra expenses for hay, 1915                      | 1700   |
| Expenses due to floods, 1916, Pasture, Hay       | 1400   |
| Purchase of a new hull for gasoline boat         | 200    |
| Frozen sewer, water-pipes, etc., expenses         | 200    |
| **Total**                                        | **$4321** |

We believe that the Dept. will recognize that our circumstances have been very difficult, and of such a nature as to make a deficit unavoidable. We beg therefore to make application to the Dept. for relief and aid in the form of a loan of about $3000, with as low an interest rate as possible, for a term of at least two years, the principal to be paid off in installments of about $200 per Quarter out of the Per Capita Grant to the School. These terms are only suggestions dictated by our needs; we believe that the Dept., if generous enough to give us the loan, will also be generous as to terms.

We believe, given a good year or two, that we can make good financially, and it is in this faith, and to ensure our making good, that we ask the assistance of the Department.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Louis Laronde,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

I duly received from you a copy of Rev. L. Laronde's letter & his financial statement. You ask me to state (1) whether His Diocese can assist the school, and (2) if not, what I recommend to be done.

It happened that my Committee on Indian Schools met on Wednesday, 16th, & I brought the whole matter before them. Their reply was unanimous & decided to quite agree with my firm opinion in the matter. I give you that reply somewhat briefly.

I. We think that Rev. L. Laronde has made out a very strong case for expecting relief from the Indian Department. The deficit is caused partly by unfortunate weather conditions, flood, etc., for two years past, partly seemingly by imperfect workmanship or planning of the agents employed by the I.D. in building & equipping the premises. It is entirely connected with that part of the enterprise in which the I.D. has much more interest & concern than the Church has.

II. The Diocese has absolutely no funds which it can apply to this object. You will note from the yearly financial statement of the School that the Church contributes in cash & clothing some $1800 yearly. It actually has given more
more, which does not appear. Thus we have worked without any charge an extra teacher etc., for months at a time, & we have paid the salary of such. You speak of the funds at the disposal of the S.D. as being very limited, owing to the War. Ours are much more so; in fact we are struggling to reduce our overdraft in the Bank by $20,000. Therefore the only possible thing seems to be, what I recommend, that the S.D. should meet this deficit, as Mr. Larmde suggests as a "loan with small interest" that is a poor way out & will cripple us for years; but as a definite grant to cover losses, or at least as an advance to be paid off gradually in a term of years. And I should ask Mr. for $3,000 but for the amount of deficit, viz. $3,673.

I trust you will submit this letter & the matter to the responsible heads of the S.D. & that they will see the justice of my request.

Believe me

Yours faithfully,

J. H. Saskatchewan

Mr. Scott:

Bishop Newnham in his letter of the 27th of July states that the church cannot and will not permanently carry the burden of the Indian Department, and he encloses a memorandum explaining the cause of the deficit of this school which amounted to $173.94, which he claims is largely due to the destruction by floods and the unsuitability of construction for drainage, electric lighting, water connections, etc.

This school is built on Fisher Island in the Saskatchewan River, Le Pas Agency about six miles from the town of Le Pas. The site was selected by Mr. Jackson and Mr. Fisher, and was approved of by Bishop Newnham, and contains 549.7 acres, which was presented by the Chief and principal men of the Le Pas Band on the 19th of August 1912.

The contract for the school building and hospital was $76,578.00. In addition to the contract, the following amounts were expended; cellars $406.50, installing furnace and cistern $196, erection of outbuildings $6664, pump and tool house $460, acetylene tank room $443.25, fence and closet $575, extras: setting in sewer and pipe $1200, trenching for and connecting water and gas $1076.24, installing cistern, etc. $693.76, making well $251, metal ceiling, sewestrough and pipe $323, extra windows, doors, etc. $370 sundry extras $162.73,- Making a total amount
amount of $91,411.68.

Mr. Laronde, the late principal on the 10th of March 1917 gave the following summary of the expenses which the school had been put to under his management.

Loss of Income during first Qr. - - - - - - 621
