Expenses due to floods, 1916, Pasture, Hay, - 1400
Purchase of a new hull for gasoline boat - - 200
Frozen sewer, water-pipes, etc., expenses - - 200

Total - - - $1321

The Bishop admits that Mr. Laronde's want of judgement and incompetency of management may have contributed somewhat to the large deficit. When Mr. Laronde was recommended to the position of principal by Bishop Newnham in August 1914, the Department wrote the Bishop stating "that, while he recommended Mr. Laronde's educational qualities, it was no assurance that he had the ability to conduct a school of this class. The Bishop was informed that the school would be conducted on the per capita grant system, and, while the allowance is considered enough under careful business management to meet all legitimate demands, there can be no margin left and it will require the closest economy and supervision to make ends meet. The school will have a deficit from the start, as funds will have to be advanced to enable it to be
be carried on from its inception which will have to be repaid out of the per capita earnings. The Department regrets that it cannot accede to your Lordship's wish to place this school in charge of Mr. Laronde, as it does not consider that he has had the necessary experience to enable him to successfully carry on an institution of this class." To this letter Bishop Newnham replied that he had already appointed Mr. Laronde, and on the 22nd of September the Bishop was again written and told—"that, in view of the fact that he had practically become responsible for the appointment of Mr. Laronde as principal of this school, the Department will consent that he be given a trial on the distinct understanding that, should his management not prove satisfactory, his services are to be dispensed with on three month's notice."

Bishop Newnham in his recent memorandum claims that the architect, contractor, and those responsible for the location and character of the school are to blame for its deficit, but on the 26th of March 1915 Bishop Newnham wrote the Department stating that he was exceedingly pleased with all he saw at the school, the buildings and equipment, also the accommodation. While the buildings were in the course of erection the Department engaged the services of a building inspector who was employed for 183 days at $6 a day. The location chosen is said to be the best in the locality and, as before stated, selected with the approval of the Bishop, and if any faults are now to be found with the drainage, lighting, water system etc., they are probably due to carelessness and incapacity of the management, however it might be well
well to carry out the Bishop's suggestion that Archdeacon MacKay be asked for his proposals to remedy it.

The trouble with this school is want of funds. The per capita grant of $110.00 is insufficient. Eighty pupils are provided for which will give them a gross income of $8500 a year. It will require at least $3500 to pay salaries which only leaves $5300. For the year ending December 31, 1916, food, and incidental expenses cost $7060.33, and clothing cost $585.34 a year, a total of $5945.67. No saving could be made in any of these items and it is quite evident that the school cannot be carried on for $110.

Norway House and Cross Lake are in receipt of $135 per capita being classed in the Northern Division. As the church is not in a position to supplement the grant at present allowed the MacKay Boarding School, and if this school is to be continued the Department will have to place it on the same basis as the above mentioned schools, at least until the Island is brought under cultivation.

My dear Bishop Newham -

I have given consideration to that portion of your letter of July 27th, last, which deals with the conditions at the Mackay Indian Boarding School. I find upon examining the records that this site was selected by Inspector Jackson and the then Agent, Mr. Fisher, and was approved by Your Lordship. It would appear that the site was the best available in the neighbourhood of The Pas. I note also that in March, 1915, you wrote, expressing your pleasure with all that you had seen after a visit to the school, including the accommodation as provided.

I am prepared to admit that there may be faults in the drainage, lighting and water systems, but I am of opinion that the faults cannot altogether be attributed to the systems themselves, but are due to a great extent to incompetent management. As your Lordship is aware, we have had wide experience in the

preparation of plans, etc., for these residential schools, and it would appear rather singular that our work in connection with The Pas School should be such a signal failure when compared with other similar institutions throughout the country, more especially at Norway House, where the building is an identically the same plan. Dear Mr. Scott,

I am afraid I am going to inflict upon you a very long letter, or group of memoranda. But troubles have come very thick fast lately, so I desire your very careful consideration of my notes, and then your advice as to any best method of action. I don't want to be ungrateful. Half a loaf is better than no bread. But really now! Every single person to whom I have told the news of the increase has made the same sort of criticism. "When prices have gone up 50% a time almost 100%, what real aid is an advance of 10%?" In other words, "we could not run the schools free of debt on the $100 per cap. old prices: we certainly can not nearly do so on $110 per cap. new prices. Dear Mr. Scott,

I prefer to send these letters on various subjects for your use, though you may have to hand them on to others to deal with. They all concern the Pas School.

1. Archdeacon MacKay is at last resigning the helm which he has so bravely managed for so long. After work needs him. With his approval or advice I nominate Rev. Mr. Minchin for the post of Principal of the MacKay School; I hope you will appoint him. He has done most of the work lately, & I believe has satisfied the Archdeacon, the staff, & your Agent at the Pas. He has had varied experience, some business experience, is good with young people, & a disciplinarian.

2. Finance. While Archdeacon MacKay was here the Church paid his salary, as Archdeacon, & the J.D. was therefore saved the salary of a Principal, & in that way the Archdeacon was able slightly to reduce the school debt. But it is quite impossible to pay the Principal's salary out of the per cap. grant, & yet to go on reducing the debt. The J.D. is placing the School & the Principal in an impossible position. A man of Mr. Minchin's proven age, & position should not have less than $800 or $900. The Church is willing to pay part of this. It is neither willing nor able to pay the whole of it; let it be asked for & be asked to do so.
The per Cap. grant has only been increased 20 per cent whereas the cost of living has increased from 50 to 75 per cent since say 1914. I desire to press the desirability of either increasing the per cap. grant further or voting an annual sum towards his salary. The Church is now paying actually the salary of 4 out of the staff. But whether that be possible or not, I do most earnestly urge, I think I may justly demand (!) that the S.D. does the fair thing by the Principal, agrees him a fair start by paying the present deficit or debt of the school some $2,395.22. Archdeacon MacKay has reduced the debt to that amount; or rather, as I have pointed out this has been done partly by the Archdeacon's management, but still more by the Church paying his salary, & so saving enough from the per cap. grant to reduce the debt. This can not go on when Mr. MacKay's salary has been taken out of the per cap. grant. The debt I have always maintained, was almost unavoidable under conditions which were no fault of ours or of Mr. Larouche. (a) the failure of hay harvest two years running & the greatly increased cost of food for live stock. (b) the great expense during two winters of repairs of sewers & machinery owing to faulty construction, with which we had nothing to do, & which should be charged to Capital account paid by S.D. & not in any way to maintenance or current revenue. If this debt is not paid, the Principal enters on the work with a full-time round his neck, & the...
It is prevented from a fair chance of proving itself a success. I ask then that the S.D. should at once pay off this debt of $2,395.

3. Hospital. I feel that it is a great pity that the S.D. closed their hospital. It was well worth its cost. It should be re-opened. We understand that it may need a good deal of overhauling, to make it weather-proof. Bad construction! But, any how, will the S.D. do for this Reserve what it has done for Lac la Ronge? Will it provide for the salary of a field matron, if I find a trained & certified nurse acceptable to you & to the Civil Service examiners? I have a splendid candidate; all-round experience & certificate. The school would accommodate her, & be thankful to have some one at hand to supervise the health of the children. There are now sick children in the school, & the doctor has given up his own bed-room to one who needs isolation because of tuberculosis trouble. What can you do about this?

Then, what about the Pas. Miss Meakin has received a formal letter of appointment at $45 a month(!) & to report & get instructions! Not a word as to where, when, to report, no instructions, etc. To whom shall she report? Who will instruct her? Is $45 all the S.D. will give? She was getting $20 to $25 a week nursing. She can not go till end of May or early June now. Roads all gone; lakes not yet open. Who will pay expenses of travel? About $75 from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge, & $15 or so from her home to P.A. Can you please answer pretty soon. I am for highland soon, & shall be very busy till then.

Sincerely,

Sir,

I have the honor to report as follows regarding matters at Mackay Boarding School.

Soon after the new Principal took charge some of the bog boys raided the store room and got some extract, and generally misbehaved during the absence of the Principal, who was in town. On his arrival back at school he investigated the trouble and decided to bring the boys in here, and the boys were suitably punished.

Matters seemed settled after this, until last week when the same bunch of boys brought their skating boots, with skates attached, in to town here and sold them to a second hand store. The same day two of the boys arrived back at school drunk. We found that one of them had bought peppermint extract at a local drug store, and I placed the drug clerk in jail for a month after due trial. The Principal recovered the boots and skates from the second hand dealer.

The Principal is new to his work, but is doing his best to control matters. However, the whole institution will be disorganized if things keep on as at present. I have given the Principal my full support at all times.

It seems that something more than strapping the boys will have to done, but I wish authority before taking further steps. There are one or two means we have under discussion.

First - Try the boys under Sec 139 Indian Act for being drunk. This puts the school in a bad light, and might seem to the parents too drastic, in case the boys were sent to jail.

Second - Take the boot thieves in front of a magistrate and have them sent to the reformatory. This is also too drastic in my opinion. We have to keep so many things in mind as to the effect on the parents as well as the children.

Third - Discharge following pupils with dishonorable papers. McIvor Cook, Gilbert Paul, J.W. Harris. These will soon be 18 years old at any rate. Discharge with honorable discharge Nathan Flett, R.J. Head, they are nearly 18 and are in the gang but only as sympathisers and prompters.

I have the honor to report that I visited the Mackay Boarding School on the 13th inst., the medical officer came with me.

The health of the pupils was very good, an epidemic of influenza of mild type had gone through the school lately, but all the pupils were about over it at time of my visit. Some minor ailments were treated.

The building was very clean and the rooms all kept in tidy condition. The cupboards supplied were all in position, but the bed springs had not been changed yet, the new ones will be put in place shortly.

There were 82 pupils on the roll at time of my visit, but the March return will only show 80, as two entered after April 1st.

The Principal asks if the Department will request the Provincial School Authorities in Winnipeg to arrange to have the Inspector visit the Mackay School this spring. Last year the Indian Department informed me that arrangements had been made for this work, but up to date no Manitoba Inspector has visited any school in the district.

The principal also asks if the old hospital building near the school can be given to the school. I have made numerous reports on the condition of this building, it is going to pieces. Mr. Tinney wants to use the lumber in the building to make a new shed and a stable, and to use the cellar as a root cellar. The only salvage we could use would be the windows, doors, furnaces and furniture, and this could be shipped wherever desired. I do not know whether we will ever use the building as a hospital again or not, the expense of putting it in shape would be heavy.

Matters at this school seem to be settled down, the staff get along better than they did last autumn. The Principal has not got the business head of the former principals and will have trouble with his own superior officers in time, as he is inclined to value the dollar too lightly.

I have the honor to report that I visited the Mackay Boarding School yesterday.

The staff seems to have settled their disputes and matters are going on very quietly there now. The building as usual was kept in a very neat and tidy condition, and sanitary arrangements are all that could be desired. There is little sickness in the institution, just two cases that require medical attention, the doctor will visit the school to-morrow I expect.

The Principal drew my attention to the following repairs and replacements which are required.

The school has not been painted on the outside since it was built. A good job was made by the original contractor, but now the building needs paint to preserve the wood work. I think this should be allowed, the Department probably has had similar buildings painted and can figure the cost. If not I could have a figure submitted if the Department requires same.

The screening requires replacement in many places, 200 lin feet of 36 inch wire would cost about $40.00, I would beg to recommend that it be supplied.

The air compressor on the water system should be renewed, the cost is about $50.00. A trip by the plumber costs us $15.00 and we will save this work by supplying a new compressor.

The Principal asks if we will supply a barrel of lime for the outside closets, the cost is $5.50. This is a new item, but it seems reasonable.

The gasoline engine for pumping water is continually out of order. A new 6 h.p. field engine will be required, the cost is $250.00. This is another place where the plumber gets a revenue, and there seems little use in trying to carry on with the old machine, it is continually giving out.

Mr. Tinney also asks if the Department will allow a grant for further clearing of the land on the island, he has to enlarge his fields to get fodder for the cattle, and asks for a grant of $100.00 which would be paid out to Indians for work as done some years ago.

He also asks if the electric light plant was passed in the estimates, this has been promised before.

I am not aware of the amount of funds on hand for this institution, but practically all the above requirements are urgent.

Dear Sirs:

I beg to submit the following explanation in regard to Arthur Dorian.

On August the 28th the above boy was reprimanded by Mr. Grant, the Farm Instructor, for sending another boy out to the barn to milk his cow, and not turning out himself. He said his hands were blistered. This, however, was not the case as he has a habit of getting another boy to do his duties whenever he can. The Farm Instructor informed him that he would not be allowed to play football at night as a punishment. The boy laughed and said something to the other boys in Cree and Mr. Grant then told him he would have to miss football for one week.

Mr. Grant reported this to me, and as I was getting some Gasoline in preparation for going to town, the boy came in the Engine house, apparently in a bad temper. I turned to the boy in the presence of another boy, and said to him "You must not be rude to the staff or take things into your own hands. If you do not feel fit to do your duties report to Mr. Grant!" He took no notice, so I said "Arthur, did you hear me speak to you?" He turned around and shouted back to me "Yes, I hear!" I walked over to him and placing my hand on his shoulder remarked "Arthur, my boy, I do not allow any boy to speak to me like that." He threw my hand aside and caught hold of me, apparently with the intention to fight. After a struggle I got his arm behind his back and told him that he would have to come to the office to be punished. When we arrived in the office I gave him a few strokes with the strap on the hand. He put his hands up and in order to avoid a repetition of his closing in again struck with the strap at his arm. He received four or five strokes on his back and shoulders ere he put his hands down.

I can well understand that it possibly left a mark as he would only have his summer clothes on covered with his jacket.

I then told him that though boys in the past had wrestled with former Principals that I would not do so. Then I sent him out to his duties. On arriving home from town I heard that he had gone home. He was brought back next day.

His father who was away at the time, on arriving in The Pas, came up to see me, and brought an ex-pupil to interpret. On hearing my version of the affair, he stated "that he was
astounded that his boy would dare to attempt to fight either with the Principal or any other member of the staff, and that he felt the boy deserved all he got.

I might state that in answer to Mr. Waddy's remark, when he speaks of "too much abuse" that there have only been three cases of punishment since March, and these were minor cases.

I might also point out that there are only two alternatives for a Principal when a big boy attempts to fight him, that is to fight or wrestle, or beat his arms down. It has happened here, though not in my time, that a Principal has closed with a big boy and the boy has put him on the floor. Also one male member of the staff, who has left the school, was pushed or knocked in a corner, and another member had to stop the boy, and I think that this boy was trying the same thing out to see if it would work.

I had received many complaints from the lady members of the staff that they would have to send Arthur Dorian in to me as he was getting very troublesome, and some of them had said that it would be better if I punished a little more. This is not my policy. If it is possible I always try to win a boy over.

Trusting that this explanation is quite satisfactory.

I am

Yours truly,

(sgd.) Rev. E.V. Bird
Principal

Dear Sir:  

Re the punishment of Arthur Dorion at the Mackay School.

With further reference to your letter of September 16, (128-1-1) and my letter of October 15, relative to the punishment of the pupil Arthur Dorion at the Mackay School, I beg to state that I have just returned to this city, after an absence of over three weeks, on a tour of inspection to some of our Society's Schools in the Prairie Provinces, during which I visited the Mackay School at The Pas in Manitoba and reviewed with your representative, Mr. Indian Agent Waddy, and the Rev. E.V. Bird, the Acting-Principal, all the circumstances connected with the punishment of the pupil in question.

During my interview with Mr. Waddy which lasted about one hour, he gave it as his opinion that while corporal punishment was frequently a necessity in maintaining discipline and checking misdemeanours and had been resorted to by him as Indian Agent on various occasions for both purposes, he considered that the punishment administered to Arthur Dorion was too severe. As the statement contained in Mr. Waddy's report to you dated September 16 that the pupil "was black from his neck to his buttocks where he had been strapped" was not corroborated either by the Rev. Mr. Fraser, the Missionary living at The Pas as superintendent of the Indian missionary work of our Church in that part of Saskatchewan, and who saw the boy's back shortly after the punishment was administered, or by Bishop Lloyd, the Bishop of Saskatchewan, who saw the boy's back at the same time as Mr. Fraser, I was, and still remain, somewhat puzzled to know why so strong and damaging an assertion was made. Mr. Fraser, when interviewed, first in Toronto and subsequently at The Pas, emphatically declared that the statement was not only an exaggeration but quite at variance with the facts of the case, while...
Bishop Lloyd when I conferred with him on this matter in Prince Albert, also informed me that although traces of the punishment were visible, there was a lack of evidence to justify the descriptive terms used by the Indian Agent in his report.

During the time I was at the School itself, namely from Saturday November 1 until November 3, I requested the Acting Principal to recapitulate the whole of the circumstances related to this matter, and as these did not vary from those set forth in his report of September 26, a copy of which has already been forwarded to you, I do not consider it necessary to repeat them here.

At the time of my visit the pupil in question was in residence at the School, and I learned that his conduct, which, prior to his punishment, had been one of defiance to various members of the staff, had undergone a very decided change for the better. This circumstance alone seemed to me to go quite a long way towards justifying the Acting Principal in the action he had taken. In addition to this, however, the Acting Principal informed me that the pupil's father when he had heard all about his son's misbehaviour, and which apparently he had not done when he took him to the Indian Agent, not only exonerated the Acting Principal from any act of unfairness or injustice, but thanked him for the strict discipline which was being maintained, and which he knew was necessary if the work of the School was to be a success.

I conclude, therefore, in the light of the information presented to me, and none of which I have reason to doubt, that,

(a) The punishment was deserved
(b) It was not unnecessarily severe
(c) It was not administered in anger or in a state of temper and that
(d) It has thus far been productive of good results.

Why your representative should in this particular instance have written in such strong language I may never be able to understand. I myself, personally, have always found him both courteous and obliging, but I have been forced to the conclusion that if he had carefully and thoroughly investigated all the circumstances connected with the punishment of the pupil in question before forwarding his report he would have given expression to his opinion in somewhat more moderate terms.

You will know, I think, that our Society is extremely desirous of cooperating with your Department to the fullest extent possible, in all matters pertaining to the education of the Indian peoples of this land. In doing this we are prepared to welcome suggestions, to accept and act on criticism of any mistakes which may inadvertently have been made, to carry out, so far as our ability to do so will enable us, all legitimate rulings and instructions, and to do our utmost in every way to make this great and important work an unquestionable success. Experience, however, is teaching me more and more, as the days go by, that unless many of your representatives in
In charge of the Indian Agencies are prepared to meet in a friendly way the Principals or Acting Principals of the Indian Residential Schools administered by our Society and talk over together with them matters similar to the one which forms the subject of this letter before submitting to you an adverse report, there can be but small hope of our ever realizing the consummation of our wish in this respect.

Any steps, therefore, which you may be able to take, and which will tend to secure the friendly counsel and closer cooperation in the way suggested will be greatly appreciated by us.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:-

With further reference to your letter of March 21st, (no.128-1-1) relative to the appointment of professionally qualified teachers at the Mackay School, The Pas, Manitoba, I beg to state the teacher in charge of the senior class-room is not without Normal Training having taken a short course as prescribed by the Department of Education of the Province of Manitoba and may therefore be reckoned in the professional class. Her sister who is in charge of the junior room has not been through Normal but has an educational standing equal to a third class certificate in this Province.

It is the rule of our Society to appoint none but fully qualified teachers. An exception, however, had to be made in this instance in the case of the junior teacher owing to the sudden breakdown in health of one of the teachers at this school before the close of last year, and the unexpected and enforced retirement of the other at very short notice. Sooner than leave the class-rooms without teachers, these two ladies were sent at once from Winnipeg being transferred from the Peigan School while on short leave of absence in Winnipeg during the Christmas holiday season. Dear Mr. Waddy:

I arrived home on Monday with Baker Siwap, though I feel sure that on landing if there had been no boys to meet me, he would have run off as soon as the canoe touched the shore.

He was placed in the dormitory and brought down to supper and then taken back, thinking keeping him shut in for a day or two might do him good. I kept him in next day, but he slipped away after supper time and was caught near the Reserve and brought back (this was Tuesday) at 8 P.M., I fastened him to the bed at night, so as to make sure that he would get into no mischief, then released him next day and left him in the Dormitory - he was caught trying to pull the pins in the hinges on the door. I gave him a spanking over my knees with his clothes on. His clothes were taken away next day, but during Thursday afternoon he apparently put the bed near the clothes closet, climbed through the transom light and secured his clothes, got a window open and slipped down the fire escape. He had told the boys he meant to run away again, apparently he is going to make another Colin Tobacco.

I sent a boy down the Reserve on Wednesday and on to town, he returned on Thursday noon - no news of the boy and he forget to call and notify you.

Question what shall be done with him and Colvin?.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Rev. E.V.Bird.

Sir:

I have at last decided to write and let you know how this McKay School is being run, and to ask if anything can be done immediately to find out the cause of troubles which rise from there. I have tried not to pay much attention to the various reports made to me in regard to the treatment of children there by the Principal; but having seen what he really does I have at last made up my mind to report same to you. On investigation several witness can be got to testify. I will just tell you of one instance which happened very recently. A young boy was flogged at the school and he ran away to his people. His parents then took him back and kindly asked Mr. Bird, Principal, not to flog the boy again, as he was not doing anything seriously wrong. The Principal replied that he would flog the boy again. As soon as the parents were out of sight he started to flog the boy. There were some person there from Moose Lake and they could hear the distressing cries of the boy. After the flogging the Principal told the boy he would again whip him in the evening. So he locked him up, but somehow the boy again made his escape almost naked and bare footed. There are some white men and some Indians who saw the boy in the state he was in after his flogging, in fact, we were afraid that he would probably die somewhere as those who saw him say that he was nearly out of his mind. Since then the boy has been found and as far as I know is kept at the hospital for treatment.

Trusting that you will see to attend to this at your earliest convenience.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Pal Constant.

I shall, therefore, be greatly obliged if you will be good enough to direct that a copy of such statements and complaints be furnished me at an early date.

(2) That, in our previous experience, when charges were made against the Rev. E.V. Bird, in relation to "the punishment of Arthur Dorion" as set out in the letter dated Sept. 16th, 1924, of the acting Deputy Superintendent General, in which it was stated on the authority of the local Indian agent that "he (i.e., Arthur Dorion) was black from his neck to his buttocks where he had been strapped," such charges were, in my opinion, decisively rebutted by the evidence of the Rev. Rural Dean Fraser and of the Bishop of Saskatchewan, who both examined the back of the boy shortly after the infliction of the punishment in question. This decisive rebuttal of the charge laid by Mr. Indian Agent Waddy and backed up by Mr. Commissioner Graham (who apparently never saw the boy) was set out in my letter to you dated Oct. 18th, 1924, and in the letter of the Rev. Dr. Westgate to the Secretary of the Department under date Nov. 28th, 1924, and has never been controverted or, as far as I know, questioned.

I have, also, before me a copy of the letter of Dr. Westgate, dated Oct. 31st, to the Secretary of the Department in relation to the case of the accident suffered by Anna Constant, a pupil at the same school. The manner in which both these cases have been reported to your Department appears to us to afford considerable ground for a suspicion that either Mr. Indian Agent Waddy, or his associates, are not well-disposed personally towards the principal of the Mackay School and that, in consequence, they are not only ready, but desirous, of placing the worst possible complexion upon all incidents in relation to the discipline and management of the school which may come to their notice. Dear Dr. Westgate:

Your letter of the 3rd inst. to handle Baker Siwap.

The boy apparently intends to settle down, and I would prefer to try him out; we have another boy Colin Tobacco, (a brother of the Frederick Tobacco who was sent from here to Elkhorn, and who escaped from there and so I understand was caught in Winnipeg), this boy has constantly run away from here; he was brought to the school during 1923. Grennan R.C.M.W.P. has instructions from the Department to bring him back from Moose Lake, as soon as the trails are fit enough for winter travel, this boy is indeed incorrigible and will do almost anything to run away.

The third time that Baker Siwap ran away, I spent two days up the river hunting for traces of him, as we expected that he would make for Cumberland where his home is, we did not find him, three Indians hearing that he had been seen away up the river trying to get to Cumberland on foot, left their Duck hunt and hunted for him, they found him on the second day, and as he had had very little food, he was in an exhausted condition, they brought him back to The Pas and he was placed in hospital. Dear Mr. Scott:

With further reference to your letter of Oct. 31st, addressed to our General Secretary, and the reply on Nov. 4th, relative to the information conveyed to you that "Mr. Commissioner Graham, Mr. Indian Agent Waddy, certain Indians, and other residents of The Pas considered that Rev. Mr. Bird, during the last week in September, was again abusive in the case of Baker (William) Siwap, a 10 year old pupil at the School". I beg to state that on the occasion of my visit to this institution on Nov. 26th and 27th last, I gave special consideration to this important matter.

During an interview I had with Mr. Waddy immediately after my arrival in The Pas on Nov. 26th I learned that his report in this connection was based very largely on information he had received from the man Sanquedor at whose house this pupil had arrived after leaving the school and was making his way back to his home at Cumberland. I also learned from Mr. Waddy that this man was a Frenchman and a member of the Roman Catholic Church.

On my arrival at the School I saw the boy himself and his condition appeared to me to be so rugged and healthy that I did not consider any physical examination necessary.
I discussed the whole matter personally first with Mr. Bird alone and subsequently with the whole staff when neither Mr. Bird nor Mrs. Bird were present, and both of whom were unaware until afterwards, of the action I had taken.

During the meeting with the staff they unanimously assured me that the boy Baker (William) Siwap had not been "abused", and that, in their opinion Mr. Bird erred on the side of leniency rather than on the side of severity, in the punishment of any of the pupils. I have to state, therefore, that in the light of this information, and in view of the source from which Mr. Waddy received the information on which he based his report, I find no justification for the serious charge which that report contained.

That the boy was punished for a serious breach of discipline there is no doubt. That the punishment administered was neither abusive nor unduly severe, but barely what would be expected under the circumstances, is equally certain, and I am of the opinion that it would be a mistake to remove Mr. Bird from the Principalship of this institution at the present time.

About a year ago, a similarly damaging report was issued by Mr. Indian Agent Waddy in connection with the punishment of the pupil Arthur Dorian. I investigated at that time all the circumstances and having satisfied myself that the report contained statements which were unsupported by the facts of the case informed your Department accordingly. Subsequent events have shown, I think, that the action taken by the Principal and his staff at that time were fully justified. The pupil Arthur Dorian is still at the School and is one of the best behaved, healthiest, and most helpful of the bigger boys. He played in the School's foot-ball team which won the Silver Cup this fall in competition against the foot-ball teams from The Pas School, and The Pas Mill.

At the time of my visit I had the pleasure of presenting this beautiful cup to the team, and with it a small silver medal presented by Premier Bracken of Manitoba to each member. After the presentation the captain (Joseph Bignell) and Arthur Dorian made short speeches in reply.

That punishment is necessary, at times, in the maintenance of discipline, must, I think, be acknowledged, and I have good reason to believe that the results in the case of Baker (William) Siwap will be equally as beneficial as they have proved to be in the case of Arthur Dorian.

But it can hardly be expected, I think, that a Principal can obtain the best results possible if he is to be subjected to
adverse reports such as those referred to in this letter, and any action you may take to have it discontinued will be deeply appreciated by our Society.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th of December 128-1-1, informing me that you had received a letter from Dr. Westgate in connection with the treatment of William Siwap, a pupil at the McKay Indian Residential School, by the Principal, Mr. E.V.Bird, and containing extracts from same.

I have read very carefully the extracts from Dr. Westgate's letter, and it seems to me that the investigation which he held was anything but satisfactory, and the inquiry or investigation was not carried on as it should have been in order to get at the true facts of the case. Dr. Westgate merely went to Mr. Bird's own staff, and to Mr. Bird himself, the accused; he did not go to the people who picked the boy up on the river bank and made the complaints to the Agent in the matter, and who were the parties in a position to say the condition in which the boy was found. It would not be very natural for Mr. Bird to admit to Dr. Westgate that he had punished this boy and left him in the condition described by Mr. St. Goddard and others.

After receiving your letter I again took the matter up with Mr. Waddy, in fairness to him in view of Dr. Westgate's report. I asked Mr. Waddy to procure a signed statement from Mr. St.Goddard as to the boy's condition when he first saw him; this he did, and I am enclosing same herewith, as well as a copy of Mr. Waddy's letter. You will notice Mr. Waddy says that Mr. St. Goddard is one of the most respectable citizens in the district. Signed statements are also enclosed from Joseph McGillivray, who picked the boy up on the bank of the river, and from Arthur Anderson who was with McGillivray at the time. All of which statements go to show that the boy was abused.

On the 12th of October I forwarded to the Department a copy of a letter from Pat Constant, Chief of The Pas Band, in which he reported the unsatisfactory conditions existing at the McKay School. Mr. Indian Agent Taylor speaks highly of this Chief, and says that any complaints which he makes would be reliable. I also forwarded at that time a copy of Indian Agent Waddy's letter of Oct. 5th. in which he makes the following statement,-

"One of these times"

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
"One of these times a pupil will starve to death in the bush after running away from school. This boy was away for a week and nearly made a nice case for publicity against the Department, as in the final analysis we are responsible. The boy tells me he was whaled twice across the rump with a paddle before the Principal took him into the school and gave him the strapping."

Dr. Westgate makes the following statement in his letter to you:

"About a year ago a similarly damaging report was issued by Mr. Indian Agent Waddy in connection with the punishment of the pupil Arthur Dorian. I investigated at that time all the circumstances and have satisfied myself that the report contained statements which were unsupported by the facts of the case informed your Department accordingly. Subsequent events have shown, I think, that the action taken by the Principal and his staff at that time were fully justified."

In connection with this matter I would quote from Mr. Waddy's report to me, dated Sept. 1st, 1924, as follows:

"Last Friday one of the pupils named Arthur Dorian, aged 15, was brought into the office by his parents to show how he had been treated. He was black from his neck to his buttocks where he had been strapped; altogether too much abuse in these times, though I have had plenty worse myself in different country than Canada. It appears that the boy could not work as he had blistered hands from handling a hay fork or some other tool and he got trimmed for this. He fought back, I understand, when he was getting strapped, and made the Principal lose his temper.

I called in Bishop Lloyd and Rev. Mr. Fraser to show them what was going on at the school, as the Principal has always denied abusing the children."

In this instance there was no hearsay; the Agent actually saw the boy in the condition reported, and it seems to me that he was fully justified in reporting as he did. The Agent also states in this report that he had previously drawn the Principal's attention to the fact that he was too severe in the punishment of the children at the school, but he did not seem to get any better.

In my opinion Dr. Westgate is taking altogether the wrong view of these matters, and I think you will agree with me that this sort of thing cannot be allowed to go on, and that the Department should deal with the matter seriously.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,

I have the honor to report as follows on a visit I made to the Mackay Indian Residential School on the 23rd inst.

The register shows the following attendance:

- On register: 75
- Average attendance: 70
- Present: 39 boys, 30 girls

In classes Standard:
- 1: 25
- 2: 4
- 3: 8
- 4: 16
- 5: 9
- 6: 11
- 7: 2

One pupil was in hospital, pupils Stella Thomas, Jimmy Johnson, Isaiah Flett, Arthur Brightness, and Molly Hall were absent without leave. I will see if I cannot locate the latter youngsters they are up near Split Lake someplace.

The pupils in the junior room were progressing quite well, the teacher there is Miss Vincent. She understands her work and kept good discipline.

The senior room pupils are in charge of Miss Farrow who is also a good teacher and the pupils there are getting on with their studies in a fair manner.

The children are well fed and were all healthy at time of my visit, they were also warmly clothed.

The school is clean, well ventilated and in fair shape all round. The broken windows have all been replaced.

The cows are not giving much milk at present, though nine are milking, so the pupils are not receiving much milk.

Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The Senior class room requires the following:
4 rear seats, A.S.Co. Single seats No 1., as sold by Christie & Co., Brandon.
4 wooden backs for repairs to C.O.& S.F.CO., Preston, single desks. 2 number 2.

24pcs 1x4x10' stripping for placing the desks in sets so they can be moved without danger of breaking.
2 gross wood screws for attaching desks.

The Principal asks for a visit from the dentist as he states that a number of the pupils need attention.

The feed for the live stock there is going to be quite a problem this winter. Last summer there was a flood in the Saskatchewan valley and hay could not be procured until late in August, and then it was of very poor quality swamp hay. A little hay was cut on the land given the school two years ago but this was also flooded and is poor stuff.

The cattle and horses are as follows:
Cow in milk 9.
Dry cows 2.
Bull 1.
Yearling heifer 1.
" steers 2.
Heifer calf 1.
Steer " 6.
Horses 5.

To support the above the supply of hay on hand is only about 80 tons. It would first appear as if we should request the school authorities to beef the young steers, with hay at twenty dollars a ton here it will not pay to raise them just now. This would leave nineteen animals. There are two or three old cows here that would be beefed out, but the expensive cost of feed alone but they would have to be replaced with others. If the school people eat the meat of the cows they could allow the value of this beef at time new cows are purchased, but I presume the Department would be asked to assume the balance. I am just suggesting these moves to save money, they could be avoided of course by supply of feed.

In any case the horses should be given a good supply of hay or they will die, they are loosing flesh rapidly from lack of nourishment from the swamp hay. At least ten tons of first class hay should be provided for them very soon, and a supply of hay of good quality supplied for a few of the best milking cows.

The warehouse has all been sheeted in with siding and the metallic sheeting will be placed on the flour warehouse next week.

I regret to report that the new Principal has had quite a lot of trouble from the actions of a number of the elder children deserting. Hardly a day goes bye that one or more do not take leave on their own account. The fault is hard to spot, but I think it is mostly from a lot of those nearing the age of eighteen trying to get away before their time expires. I have assisted in getting these pupils home every time without abusing them so as to leave no opening for complaint on that account. Mr. Conlin has also acted very decently and quietly and has kept his temper where you might excuse him if took harsher steps.
This matter of the children deserting will probably pass away shortly but in the meanwhile it is operating against our recruiting pupils locally for the vacancies in the school. The Indians will not send children while they think we are having trouble to keep those already there.

I do not know whether I should make the following remarks, but they are not made without consideration.

The Indian people here in the north respect size in a person much more than they do knowledge contained in a smaller person. Four of the staff at this school are very small and very young for this work, though they are well equipped for the work otherwise. The children really do not respect them at all. I would not suggest replacing them with matrons from a jail or rough people of any sort, but in future it would be well to supply good husky ladies for this school, a light weight one is out of place there.

TO WIT: Tinned Goods... Peaches, Sardines, Raisins, Pineapples & Salmon. Also: A large quantity of Soda Crackers & Prunes / Tea ADOLPHUS GEORGE... ALWICK DICK... HOP YOUNG... & TOM [illegible].

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to make the following short report on three schools in The Pas Agency, inspected while there between October 23rd and 29th, 1929.

MACKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The new house being erected for the Principal of the Mackay School was well along, being practically closed in, and the lathing was being started on the day I left. The house is 24x26, with 4 bedrooms and a bathroom upstairs and 1 small bedroom, kitchen, pantry, dining room, living room and hall downstairs. The work, up to the present, has been well done, and the house, no doubt, will be warm and comfortable. The difficulties experienced in digging the septic tank and outlet have been very expensive, due to the rock formations. I instructed the Principal to have all drains and outlets covered with manure and old hay to prevent freezing, and if these instructions are carried out, I do not think any trouble will be experienced.

Rev. Mr. Fraser has been Acting Principal during the past few months and expects to be appointed Principal on January 1st. The school is still sadly lacking in management, and I pointed this out to Mr. Fraser.

The Farming Instructor, Mr. Gibson, is a mere boy in appearance and has no experience to fit.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
him for the position. The yards were littered with hay, rocks and broken pieces of boards and apparently no attempt has been made to clean up the surroundings. The barn was also in an untidy condition, and the doors needed repairing. I pointed this out to Mr. Gibson, but I doubt if he is capable of doing the repair work necessary.

The school is very short of milk and now receives about 1 gal. twice a day. At present there are about 75 pupils in residence. I understand 4 of the cows are of little use as their udders are partly destroyed, so that this leaves only 5 good milk cows and at present they are practically dry. I have no doubt that the condition of the cattle is due, somewhat, to careless management, and although milk is certainly needed for the children, I pointed out to Mr. Fraser that I was not prepared to make any recommendations until a capable Farming Instructor was appointed. The present man is a joke, as far as filling his position is concerned, and should be discharged.

The chicken house stands only a few feet from the girls' playground, which ground needs re-fencing and should be enlarged. If a capable man were in charge outside, this work could be done with little expense to the Department and it would greatly improve the appearance of the school grounds.

I would further point out that the grounds have no equipment for the amusement of the children, and swings and teeters could be erected at little cost. Football, volley ball and basketball equipment could also be used to great advantage.

I regret
I regret I was unable to inspect the interior of the school building as it was quarantined on account of diphtheria. However, I was informed by Mr. Fraser that it is in much the same condition as when I last inspected it. The Acting Principal assured me that when he takes charge in January that a change will be made, and I would point out to the Department that this change is certainly needed.

The walls of the school building have been re-sided and are now in splendid condition. No paint was provided for the building, but this work should be done as soon as possible.

The Rev. Mr. Fraser, Acting Principal, realizes that there is considerable room for improvement about the school, both inside and out, and if he is able to carry out his intentions, I will expect to find changed conditions when I next visit the school.

At present they have no flag. I feel that all the schools should be provided with a flag, and the boys and girls should be taught to respect and honour it.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 9th instant, number 128-1-1, was received here yesterday, and in reply I beg to state as follows:

1. As the daughter of Mr. Fraser, Principal of the Mackay School has received an official appointment on the school staff, she is entitled to occupy staff room space in the main school building, and I have advised the Principal accordingly.

2. With regard to the statement made by the local Indian Agent to the Commissioner, that the cook had to prepare meals for 7 members of the Principal's family, I beg to state that this arrangement was only a temporary measure until the Principal had become fully established in his own residence, and his wife could undertake the responsibility of cooking for his family. Our Commission consider that the Principal himself is entitled to have his meals with the staff in the main school building, and he was instructed some time ago to take two meals at least each day in that way. They have found, by experience, that this arrangement has a wholesome effect on the general discipline of the school.

3. With regard to the statement that two or three of the sons of the Principal were occupying space in the main school building, I beg to state that when the Principal took up residence at the school, and before the furnishings were all provided for his own official residence, permission was given to him for some of his family to occupy space in the main school building until they could be accommodated in the residence. I am advising the Principal of the reports and information set forth in your letter, and am asking him to let me know if all the members of his family, with the exception of those occupying official positions on the staff, can now be accommodated in the residence. At the same time, I should let you know, I think, that in the opinion of our Commission, the residence is rather small to adequately serve the
purpose for which it was provided. In the meantime, I trust you may see from the information set forth above, that our Commission are fully cognizant of conditions obtaining at this school, and are doing their best to maintain the work at as high a standard of efficiency as the limited accommodation in the main school building as well as in the residence will permit.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of October 9th, #128-1-1, and my reply to the same on October 13th, relative to the report of your Indian Agent on his visit to the MacKay School, I beg to state that I have received from the Principal of this school a statement dealing with the points raised in the Indian Agent's report which confirms the information forwarded to you in my letter of October 13th, that there is only one member of the Principal's family on the school staff, and not three as you were informed. The Principal's sons were engaged to help in securing the hay supply, but only on a day labour basis.

The Principal's letter is too long to quote in full, but it is quite clear from the information which it contains that he has not been receiving the support and cooperation of the Indian Agent which he had expected. Amongst other things he refers to the following:

(1) The attempt to proselytize on the part of the management of the Roman Catholic hospital in The Pas, any parents who are members of our Church, who were admitted to that institution for treatment. The Principal states that he requested the Indian Agent to protect our people against such interference, but no action was taken.

(2) The Principal further states that he has received but little assistance from the Agent in the matter of recruiting pupils, and mentions an instance where the admission of pupils was sanctioned by your Department, but they were not brought to the school for five months after the sanction had been received.
(3) The Principal also states that two boys from the local reserve had been placed in the school because they were a nuisance on the reserve. These boys have given the Principal and his staff a great deal of trouble, and I have asked the Principal to take up with the Indian Agent the question of their discharge or transfer to some reformatory.

(4) The Principal also refers to a lack of co-operation on the part of the Agent in connection with certain repairs to such permanent items of equipment as the heating system.

To sum up the situation, I beg to state that it is the well-considered opinion of our Commission, that the present Principal of the MacKay School possesses in a very large measure the qualifications for the position which he holds. He speaks the native tongue, and has the confidence of the Indian people. He has already succeeded in bringing the enrolment at this school up to capacity, and could easily increase the enrolment if accommodation were available. This, you will understand, is a consideration which our Commission can neither overlook nor disregard. He has not, as yet, had a very long experience in presiding over an Indian Residential School, but our Commission are satisfied that if he is given a fair chance, he will be able to make that work a success. I shall endeavour to visit this school sometime towards the end of this year, but in the meantime, I beg to recommend that you instruct your Indian Agent to co-operate with the Principal a little more closely, and sympathetically, than he appears to have done in the past. If you take this action, I am not without good hope that a happier spirit will prevail between the school and the agency, and the Indian Peoples, both parents and children, will benefit accordingly.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

I have just received your letter of Nov. 28th, #128-1-1, and have noted the report which has reached you that the supervision of the boys at the Mackay School is not at all good, and that your officer suggests that there be appointed to the staff a boys' supervisor who is a strong disciplinarian.

For your information, I beg to state that I visited the Mackay School on the 16th and 17th of November, and made a careful inspection of every department of the work, including that of the boys' supervisor. The young lady who is filling this position at present has had very considerable experience in Indian Residential School work, having served for some time on the staff at the Carcross School in the Yukon and later at the Shingwauk Home. Her services have always been fully satisfactory to our Commission, and to my mind her competency for the position she now holds cannot be questioned.

I am not unaware of the fact that the boys at this school, especially the bigger ones have given the staff a good deal of trouble, but the impression which I received during my recent visit was that there was a considerable improvement in their behaviour. I attributed this change for the better, chiefly to the personal influence of the Principal, who is loyally supported by an efficient and hard-working staff.
The difficulty of handling the bigger boys and girls, as you will know, is not one which is confined to the Mackay School, but this difficulty is very much increased at the Mackay School through the lack of accommodation for class-room instruction as well as for vocational training. For some time past, our Commission have directed the attention of your Department to the urgent need for this additional accommodation, but so far it has not been provided, and, until it has been provided, the difficulty in handling the bigger boys is likely to continue. The school management find it necessary to keep them happily and profitably employed, but their task is at times rendered quite acute through the lack of proper facilities.

During my recent visit I suggested that the bigger boys should be given the responsibility of selecting a site for and making a good-sized skating rink. A good deal of the lumber from the old hospital I thought might be used for this purpose, and the Principal undertook to act on my suggestion. My own observations, since I have been associated with the Indian educational work, bring an increasing conviction that the character of the Indian boys and girls cannot be so greatly influenced for the better by methods of compulsion and strong disciplinary measures, as by keeping them happily employed under wise and patient direction. For this reason, I should like to see Mr. Fraser given a fair opportunity of trying out this latter method. It is the one which has made a strong appeal to him, and without making any changes in the staff at present, I sincerely trust that you will allow the experiment a sufficient period to be carefully tested.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your 205-11 of the 4th instant, re April report of the McKay Indian Residential School, the reason for my remarks which you term obscure, is that I am not aware just how far it might be permissible for me to suggest any individual change in the staff.

I have repeatedly suggested to the Principal that certain changes were needed, and his views have always coincided with mine, yet in no instance has there been any change made.

There are two (aged) ladies whom I consider should be superannuated - Miss Warner and Miss Norquay. Mr. Turner, the Engineer, also should be superannuated.

Mr. Fraser has two of his family (a boy and a girl) on the staff, which in principle is wrong.

The male pupils, some of whom are men size, have a young girl supervisor, a Miss Griffiths.

Out of school, lack of supervision has led to a number of run-aways, causing a great deal of trouble and unnecessary expense. I will mention a case which occurred recently. A boy named Roderick Young ran away on Saturday morning, the 18th April, 1931, and this was not reported to me till the Monday evening following. On Saturday this boy was seen in The Pas, and this was reported to Mr. Fraser yet no action was taken. On Tuesday I reported this to the R.C.M.P., who immediately started a hunt for the boy up and down the river and on The Pas Reserve. The boy was found on Sunday following, and returned to the school on Monday.

This caused unnecessary trouble and expense, and the school to my knowledge took no steps to find the boy.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of Nov. 18th, number 129-1-1 with a copy of your letter of the same date addressed to the Rev. A. Fraser, Principal of our Mackay School, The Pas, Manitoba. I am not a little surprised at some of the statements contained in Mr. Inspector Hamilton's report, but will refrain from further comment on the same, until I have received a copy of the Principal's reply to your letter addressed to him. The question of ventilation is one, which it seems to me can easily be solved, should any solution be required during the winter months. My recollection is that the chief difficulty which the school management have had in this connection is to overcome the excessive ventilation, especially during the cold weather.

The question of the laxity of discipline is one which, if it obtains must and will be remedied. I fully appreciate your desire to have regular fire drill maintained, and the Principals of all our Society's Schools have received a standing instruction not to neglect this important matter. The question of accessibility to the fire escapes is equally important, and I heartily wish that your Department had accepted the recommendation of our Commission, as submitted on different occasions, to install the spiral chute type of fire escape instead of the iron ladders. The iron ladders, in addition to being unsuitable for young children in time of emergency, provide a means for bigger boys and girls to get out of and return to the dormitories without being observed. They also afford a means for outsiders to enter the dormitories when the children are asleep.

I am surprised that the Inspector has reported adversely on the services of certain staff agents. These agents have all been
selected with great care, and I think it would be difficult to find workers with a wider experience and greater efficiency than Miss Warrener, the head matron, and Miss Northwood who is in charge of the laundry and bakery, and Miss Griffiths the boys' supervisor. Dear Sir:

Re- Letter, #128-1-1

In answer to yours, of the 18th., instant, I beg to state:

Ventilation of Class rooms.

It is hardly possible to give mere ventilation, especially during the Winter Months; we must have storm windows, and in the class rooms, they have been made secure, with the exception of one, because of the cold, and to save breakages.

Repeatedly have the teachers complained of the cold, and Miss Farrow, the Senior Teacher who has been here, for a number of years, states, that last Winter was the first time, she did not have to move her whole class into the dining room, to get to a part of the building that was sufficiently warm, to work in.

The Junior teacher, has had to take her classes, repeatedly into the dining room, because of cold. Her room being on the East side, makes it unbearably cold, when an East wind blows.

There are the warmer days, when the wind is not so strong, when the heat radiates more readily, and so warms up the building. Further, in the construction of the building, there is a large galvanised air chamber or passage, 2½ ft., wide by 2 ft., deep, leading from front outer wall of the basement, into various parts of the interior, until it reaches the cupola, on the roof, which gives air circulation, into class rooms, dining room, dormitories, wash rooms, and halls.

It is the custom in this school, that as early in the spring time, as can be conveniently done, all storm windows, are taken off, and put back in the Autumn.
Likewise there are the foul air exits, thus giving the necessary circulation.

I do not see that we can improve on the present system, as in the summer time, all the windows are open there being screens replaced where the storm windows were taken from.

**Cupboard in Junior class room.**

I appreciate this suggestion very much, as it has been most inconvenient for the teacher in this room.

This we have brought to the notice of the Indian agent, but no action was taken, as in many other instances.

As this class room is used daily, except Saturday, and even then, has to serve as girls' play room, which it really is, it will be most convenient to have a built-in cupboard.

I would suggest that a carpenter be asked to do this piece of work, the approximate cost of which would not be over $50.00, for material and labour.

**The Dormitories.**

Apart from the windows opening out on to the veranda, which have to be made secure; we have three windows in each of the four dormitories, with a sliding sash, size, 12 X 16, in each window, which serve for ventilation likewise the fresh air inlet, and foul air exit, with similar in the halls and wash rooms.

The dormitories have a foul smell chiefly from the dreadful mattresses, we have to put up with.

The Mattresses used here, I am informed, were first used in the old Battleford Industrial School, and the beds also.

They are dreadfully foul, and should be burned; This I have repeatedly pointed out to Inspectors, Agents, Doctors, and other Officials, since taking over the Principalship of this School, and have requested for new ones, but it remains the same.

I make request, Sir, that this very urgent need be attended to.

I cannot see how children can rest on such beds, and mattresses, and keep healthy, as they are here.
Doors leading to Fire escapes. These doors have to be kept locked, and your suggestion is the plan of action that has been followed; Two members of the Staff appointed to each of the four dormitories, with keys in their possession, to open doors leading to fire escapes.

Occasional drills are had from dormitories, and at times during class work periods. The alarm is generally given, unknown to members of the staff and children.

Further, during the Winter Months, beginning Nov., 1st., to March, 31st., there is a night-watchman on duty.

We try to exercise the greatest of care to prevent fires, and also attention given for the safety of the children in case of a fire.

Water. I am very pleased that some action has been taken, regarding the water, at this school.

Up to the present no word has come to our notice, as to how soon the chlorinator is to be installed.

I trust, before some serious outbreak of sickness results, because of the state of the water.

The engineer puts chloride in the water supply occasionally.

Junior Class Room. Regarding the discipline in the junior class room, is quite true.

Miss Payne does not seem to be able to handle the children in her class room, and further has no control over the bigger girls, when she has minor duties to perform with them.

It does not seem to be in her to command authority.

She does not seem capable to handle the position, which naturally affects the whole school. I am of the opinion, that a change, if the right person could be found, would be a move in the right direction.

Kitchen-Matron. Miss Spalding has improved in some ways, but seems very slow to see what is really required.

Apart from cleaning up, I do not think much is done, in instructing girls, in the art of cooking.

While she is rather lax, and possibly incapable of instructing girls in the art of cooking, or preparing meals, nevertheless, she is a good Christian girl, and possibly she may yet turn out to a very capable, and earnest worker in her department.

She is young, but not foolish, and would like to give her another chance.

The Children are not suffering at all.
it is more on the staff-table, that the service is lacking.

The Matron. I do not think a Matron's position is very easy, in the Indian Schools.

We have a very capable person in Miss Warrenner. But then all good things come to an end here on earth; and as far as I can judge, by what has taken place, quite a number of times, I have come to the conclusion, that she has lost to a great extent, the controle of the girls. She cannot handle them, and the girls know it.

The bigger girls become very unruly toward her, and even the smaller ones speak back very often.

She has not the ability to make them submit to her ruling. Miss Warrenner has done far more for the Indian children than will ever be recorded of her, and even now, she gives very attention to all their ailments, and readily sits up at night in attendance, over the sick, which is very important, especially where there is no nurse, and the Doctor's visits, few and far between.

Laundry and Bakery. Truly Miss Northwood, the member in charge of this Department, has done a great work, and is still a good worker, but she has no controle over the girls. I would suggest a change.

I am afraid she becomes very impatient, and nags at the girls, and upsets them, and then there is trouble.

This is a very important position, and much could be done in the way of instruction, in the laundry and Bakery, and requires someone that has a command over the big girls, that are allotted off for this kind of work.

Male Supervisor. This would necessitate an extra member of the staff, which is really required, because, of the smaller boys, who need supervision during their hours of recreation.

Were it possible, I would like to have a supervisor for the boys, whose duty would be to pay strict attention to the boys especially before and after school hours, providing we had equipment for physical and gymnastic exercises.

I would suggest that the Night-watchman be an all-year position, during the five months in Winter, as night-watchman, and be a general help, during the other seven Months, with special attention given to the boys.

Trusting that the above remarks will be of some service,

I beg to remain sir,

Your Obedient Servant

A. Fraser
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of the 9th inst. #128-1-1, re improvements in the staff at the Mackay Indian Residential School, and in reply beg to state that our Commission have already notified Miss Payne, the Junior Teacher, that her services will not be required after the end of this month, and have appointed Miss Anne Wright to take her place from the 1st of January next. She also holds the Oxford Senior certificate from England where she received special training in Kindergarten work. She is also a Girl Guide. They are not convinced that these ladies are unable to control the girls, and to dismiss them at short notice, at a time like this when there is so much unemployment throughout this country, and they would both be obliged to return to England, would be to inflict a great hardship upon them, and one which existing conditions do not appear to justify. The Principal has already been notified that our Commission expect him and his staff to maintain the discipline of the school, and to operate it in such a way as to place it above criticism. They believe that by substituting Miss Wright for Miss Payne in the Junior class-room, that the existing staff will be able to achieve this result. At any rate, our
Commission consider it but common justice to give them a fair trial, and you may rest assured that if the desired results are not obtained, steps will be taken promptly to obtain them.

I arrived at the school shortly before noon and was in the dining room while the children were having lunch. I found that the food, both in quantity and quality was just as good as at the average boarding school, and the school authorities had no chance to change the menu for that day as preparations would be well under way when I arrived. For this noon meal they had meat, potatoes, and carrots, with thick gravy, bread, bread-pudding and tea. The food was served in ample quantities to satisfy the needs of the children. On enquiring into the other meals, I came to the conclusion that there was no room for complaint as far as the food was concerned, and the children presented a healthy appearance.

As to the children eating with their fingers instead of
instead of using knives and forks, this is true. It can be explained, however, by the fact that the children are in the habit of taking their knives, forks and spoons away from the table and breaking them, and the matron informed me that it was practically impossible to keep them supplied with these articles.

After going through the school and talking to the different members of the staff, I came to the conclusion that considerable friction exists between the members of the staff and principal. The Rev. Mr. Fraser, the Principal, is a man of whom I have a very high opinion. He has been in his present position for two years, and has been in the North country practically all his life, and is considered to be one of the most outstanding missionaries in that part of the country. I feel quite confident that he is putting forth his best efforts to manage the school properly, and has succeeded in bringing about a great many changes in the outside work by raising stock and seeing that a good garden is maintained for the school. However, I came to the conclusion that with the present staff the school will never function properly. In the first place some of the members of the staff have been at the school too long and I do not think they are even loyal to Mr. Fraser. The members referred to are the Matron, Miss Warner and Miss Northwood. They have been in the Indian work for a great number of years, and may be splendid women, but they are getting too old to look after the work at this school, and from my observations, have absolutely no authority over the children. Mr. Turner the engineer does not appear to be very helpful to the Principal.

As you will recall Mr. Turner was in charge of the school for a couple of years and I do not think there was very much discipline during that time. His successor, who preceded Mr. Fraser, was no better, and during these three years the children

Dear Sir:

I have received from the Rev. A. Fraser, Principal of our Mackay Indian Residential School, copies of your letters of March 11th and March 23rd, #128-1-1, addressed to him and have submitted the same to our Commission for their consideration.

In connection with the direction you gave to the Rev. Principal Fraser with regard to the teaching of the older girls how to milk cows, I beg to state that I addressed a circular to the Principals of all of our Society's Schools, and requested them to give this matter careful consideration and attention.

From the replies which have been received to this circular letter, it is apparent that a very considerable difference of opinion exists amongst the Principals as to the value of this branch of instruction. For your information I should like to quote the following comments which have been made in this connection.

The Rev. Principal Grant of our Carcross School writes, in part, as follows:

"With regard to the girls of this school learning to milk, all of us feel that such instruction would have no value at all, for no Indian that I know of in the Yukon goes in for dairying. Even though the boys here do what milking there is to do, and this practice has been followed for some years, yet we cannot recall a single case in which such instruction has helped them to earn their livelihood after leaving school. Owing to climatic conditions it is not likely..."
"that the Yukon will ever be suitable for farming activities. Gardening on a small scale is resorted to, but not with any success by the natives, especially in the southern part."

The Rev. Principal Middleton of our Blood School writes, in part, as follows:

"The aim of St. Paul's' has always been; that any girl on graduation can speak good English and is well versed in the Provincial Curriculum; make a bed; care for a sick patient; prepare a good meal and set a table properly; make, mend and sew their own clothes; keep a house clean and look after children; wash clothes, and conduct herself properly.

To add milking to this is simply a work of super-erogation. On the Reserve there are literally dozens and dozens of old school boys who have no cows to milk and again there are dozens of farmers who from sheer indifference and lack of interest will not keep a milk cow on their farms.

I consider with many years of experience that the time spent in teaching Blood Indian girls to milk cows could be more profitably spent in other branches of education."

The Rev. Principal Vale of our Chapleau School writes, in part, as follows:

"Replying to your letter with regard to the girls being taught to milk cows, I beg to state it would be very awkward to carry out this suggestion for several reasons ............ My experience covers very nearly twenty-five years, and in all that time I have found very few cases where Indian girls had to milk cows on their return to their homes. I have actually heard of three and those only. In each case they were soon able to learn it, and so no real lack was felt. Some girls are far too nervous to approach a cow and it would require a great deal of time to accomplish the task, if ever."
In the light of the above statements, our Commission are of the opinion that the amount of stress to be laid on this branch of education might safely be left in the hands of the Principals of the respective schools. In the schools which are located in farming districts, this branch of education may have some value, but it can hardly have sufficient value in the schools which are located in the remoter parts of the country to necessitate its inclusion in the curriculum of instruction for the girl pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Principal Fraser of the Mackay School, reported to our Commission that Mr. White the Farm Instructor had struck one of the boys (Peter Lathlin) and that the boy had run away from the school. Immediately after receiving this letter I wrote to the Principal for a fuller statement in connection with the same, and enclosed herewith you will find a copy of the statement received, signed by Mr. White the Farm Instructor, by Mr. Turner the Engineer, and by Mr. Fraser the Principal. According to this statement it would appear that the boy was wilfully disobedient, his disobedience amounting practically to defiance, but even with the undoubted provocation this gave, Mr. White was not justified in striking the boy, as the instructions he received, at the time of his appointment, clearly insisted that corporal punishment or chastisement, when considered necessary, must be administered by the Principal only, as he is the official guardian of the children during the time they are in residence at the school.

Last month this school was visited by Col. Mermagen, the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission, and he reported very highly the diligence and efficiency of Mr. White's services. As I have already written to the Principal instructing him to inform Mr. White and the other staff agents that the ruling of the Commission with regard to the punishment of children must be strictly observed, and in view of the fact that Mr. White has
rendered such excellent service over a period of many years, I trust that your Department may agree to allow him to remain at the Mackay School, until the Commission are able to arrange for him to be transferred to some other school. Our Commission will meet on the 13th instant, when all the correspondence bearing on the matter will be considered. At that meeting I will recommend that Mr. White be transferred as soon as a suitable vacancy is available.

Trusting that this may meet with the approval of the Department.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,
