Dear Sir:-

Re - Farm Instructor Mackay School.

In reply to your letter of Sept. 12th, #128-1-1, I beg to state that at a meeting of our Commission held on the 13th instant, it was decided to terminate the appointment of Mr. White who holds the position of Farm Instructor at the Mackay Indian Residential School, at the end of October next. Our Commission have not yet offered this position to another man, but they fully expect to be able to secure one with all the qualifications required before the end of October. I note from the closing paragraph of your letter that you desire to receive particulars as to the qualifications and experience of the man who receives the appointment to the position in question, and in due course will furnish you with the same. I have no recollection of receiving a similar request in the past from your Department, except in the case of Principals and Engineers, and as all our agents are selected with the greatest care, I should like you to feel assured that every effort will be made on our part to secure a man who will measure up to the full standard of your Department and of our Society.

With regard to Mr. White who is being dismissed, I beg to state that few staff agents have given our Commission better service. He is an indefatigable and efficient worker, and it is only during recent months that he had allowed himself to get out of patience with some of the bigger boys. Some of the bigger Indian boys, and especially those recruited from the districts around the Mackay School, are not easily managed, and while Mr. White is being dismissed, for violating one of the rules of the Commission which forbids any staff agent, except the Principal, to administer corporal punishment, our Commission feel that in view of the excellent services he has rendered, he should be given another chance next year at some other school,
should he desire to return to the Indian School work after a period of about six months enforced absence, which is about to be imposed upon him. Mr. White is the son of Canon White of High Prairie, Alberta, one of the veteran missionaries of our Society, and a younger brother has been working very satisfactorily for some time on the staff of our Shingwauk Home. Our Commission feel that it would not be quite fair to Mr. White to completely debar him from further service of the kind in which he has been engaged, simply on account of one transgression, and they trust that your Department, after receiving the information set forth in this letter, may take the same view of the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

I beg to submit the following report on the McKay Indian Residential School, The Pas Agency, inspected on Monday, September 12th, 1932.

The junior room is in charge of Miss Wright who is a new teacher on the staff since my last visit. Miss Wright is a qualified teacher with several years experience and her services to date are very satisfactory. The roll calls for 33 pupils, who are arranged in the following grades:

| 1     | 18     |

The discipline is the best I have ever found it in the junior room, and the children are brighter and more alert. I think if Miss Wright remains in charge, a big change will be noticeable by the end of the year. The room was well aired, tidy, and clean. The children were neatly dressed and clean in appearance.

The senior room is in charge of Miss Farrow who has been on the staff for a number of years. Miss Farrow is a qualified teacher, uses good methods in her work, but finds difficulty in the administration of discipline. The roll calls for 47 pupils, the grades being arranged as follows:

The children appear fairly well along in their grades, but there is little, if any, improvement in the way in which they read or answer oral questions. Miss Farrow has had no success in having the children speak out, and it is almost impossible to hear them when standing only a few feet away.

The boys were dressed in overalls and shirts, some of which were rather ragged and untidy. The girls were neatly dressed and clean.

The burlap around the lower part of the classroom is broken in places and the plaster has been knocked off. This part of the wall has been repaired from time to time, but I think the only way to permanently fix it would be to put V-Joint on to the height of the burlap, which is about four feet.

Although Miss Farrow, the teacher, is conscientious, I do not feel that any outstanding progress is being made by the pupils.

The kitchen work is in charge of Miss Spaulding who I have before reported on as being incapable of handling this position. Miss Spaulding is certainly not a cook, and this fact is realized by the girls over whom she has charge. I consider that much of the food is wasted, because of the fact that it is not properly prepared. These remarks apply to the staff meals as well as those supplied to the children. The following is the general menu served to the children:

- **Breakfast** - Porridge with milk, Bread, Lard, Tea.
- **Recess** - Slice of bread.
- **Dinner** - Stew with vegetables or meat pie, roast or fish. Potatoes, Bread, Water.
- **Supper** - Milk Pudding or stewed fruit or jam, Bread, Lard, either bannock or cake, Tea.
McKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

It will be noted that for the noon meal no butter or lard is served, and the children receive only water to drink. Desserts of any kind are not served at this meal. The supper meal appears rather light in view of what they receive for dinner, namely, a dessert with bread, cake or bannock and tea to drink.

Miss Fraser is in charge of the sewing room and acts as girls' supervisor. There is only one sewing machine in working condition, and Mr. Fraser pointed out that it was practically impossible to do the necessary sewing on the one machine. A new sewing machine should be provided in order that the work may be kept up to date.

I would point out that during a recent visit of the T.B. Clinic, on which a report was submitted to Mr. Lovell of their findings, Miss Fraser was reported as having active tuberculosis of the lungs. This was brought to the attention of Mr. Fraser, her father, but I understand he considered she could quite well look after herself and also carry on her duties as girls' supervisor. Personally, I do not agree with Mr. Fraser in this respect, and for the sake of his own daughter, I do not think she should be allowed to remain on the staff of the school.

Miss Vincent is in charge of the laundry and bake ovens. Her work in the laundry appears quite satisfactory, but she is certainly unable to handle the other Department.

Miss Griffiths acts as boys' matron and looks after their clothing as well as the boys' dormitories. I found the dormitories clean and tidy. A number of the bed springs are entirely useless and should be discarded as they are past any further repairing. I might say these beds and springs are some which
McKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

Some which were brought down from the old Battleford Industrial School and have served in an institution for many years.

The toilets, especially in the girls' dormitories, were very offensive and certainly have not been properly looked after. I pointed this out to both Mr. Fraser and the Matron as there is no reason why these cannot be kept clean, and the ones in the dormitories should certainly receive special attention. The bathtubs were also dirty and had not been looked after since last being in use.

The hospital room is equipped with a homemade bed. A proper hospital bed should be provided. I found that one of the pupils from this school had been placed in St. Anthony Hospital to receive treatment because of some infectious skin disease. I took this up with the Principal, and pointed out that I felt the child could quite well have been cared for at school and isolated in the hospital ward. At times such as these, I am afraid the school authorities are only too willing to place the children in the hospital for treatment.

The fire escapes are all in good condition, and there is one fire extinguisher on each floor. I think it would be well if three new fire extinguishers were supplied in order that there might be one in each wing of the building. The Principal complained about being unable to keep a water pressure sufficient to be of much use in case of fire, but I am inclined to think that sufficient pressure could be obtained if this matter was carefully looked after. The pressure tanks are new and there is no reason why they will not stand the required pressure.

The boys'
McKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The boys' playroom is in the basement, and although there are steam pipes for heating purposes, this place is too cold during the winter months. Mr. Fraser intimated that it would be necessary to place a stove in the room in order to make it comfortable for the boys. This arrangement will add greatly to the risk of fire unless a chimney is erected on the outside of the school and this would entail considerable expense. It might be possible to add sufficient sections to the radiators to supply more heat.

Since my last inspection Miss Schennells has been appointed Matron of the school. She is a graduate nurse and should render good service.

Mr. Turner, who for many years has acted as engineer and gardener, retired on the 30th of September. He has rendered excellent service all through the nineteen years he has been employed at the school, and the Department should see that a proper engineer and mechanic is placed in charge of the building at once. There is a lot of machinery in connection with the plant and only a competent man should be placed in charge. A chlorinating plant has been installed since my last inspection, costing over $1500.00, and new batteries and switchboard are now being installed, which will cost in the neighbourhood of $900.00. Mr. Fraser intimated that he would like to have his son take charge of this Department, but frankly I do not consider that he is capable of the task, and trust the Department will not sanction any such appointment. This is a matter which should receive immediate attention before some serious break occurs which might run into several hundred dollars.

The Farmer.
McKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The Farmer, Mr. White, was away with some of the boys cutting hay at the time of my visit. Mr. Fraser assured me there would be no shortage of feed as there is abundance of hay to be secured. I found the yards more tidy than at any other time I have visited this school, and the barns were clean. The cattle have greatly improved during the past two years, and with continued care, a fair herd of milk cows will be obtained.

Splendid returns were obtained from the garden which contained all kinds of vegetables. The potato crop will not meet their requirements, but these can be purchased locally for around 50¢ per bushel. The vegetables will be stored in a homemade storehouse, which was erected last year, and I received no complaints in regard to it not being satisfactory.

I am glad to be able to report an improvement in connection with the staff at this school, and with a proper cook in charge of the kitchen, conditions should be much better.

Mr. Fraser, the Principal, I think, realizes the weak places in connection with his staff and administration. He is, however, inclined to want too many of his own family on the staff which policy I do not consider good, and it certainly does not always tend to render efficient service.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of October 15th. #128-1-1 and the reply despatched to you from this office on October 17th., I beg to state that at the request of our Commission I visited the Mackay School on the 15th. and 16th. of this month in order that I might secure on the spot further information about the matters touched on in your letter. In this connection I beg to report as follows:

(1) With regard to the services of Miss Farrow, the Teacher of the Senior room, I beg to state that I directed her attention to the Inspector's Report with regard to the difficulty in maintaining discipline, and lack of success in having the children speak out distinctly. So far as the question of discipline is concerned, neither the Principal nor Miss Farrow herself had any recollection of any serious difficulty. Miss Farrow is rather small of stature, but she is an experienced and very competent teacher, and her past record appears to me to fully justify her continuance in her present office.

With regard to lack of success in having the children speak out, I can only say that when I asked them to read, they read quite distinctly and they answered my questions sufficiently audibly to be heard from any part of the classroom. The teacher admitted that when the Inspector was there, the children disappointed her in this matter, but after she had explained to them how their conduct would reflect adversely on her ability, they showed a marked improvement.

(2) With regard to Miss Fraser, the Girls' Supervisor, I beg to state that during my visit I gave special attention to the report you had received that she had active tuberculosis of the lungs, and reached the conclusion that the
report you received was drafted and despatched to you before the ultimate findings of the T.B. Clinic were known. These findings are set forth in the following letter written by Dr. D. A. Stewart, Medical Superintendent of the Sanatorium at Ninette, Manitoba, who was in charge of the Clinic, and who wrote to Dr. Stephenson of The Pas, Man., on October 28th, 1932:

"Many thanks for your plates of Lillian Fraser. It seems to us from a comparison of these two plates that there is a little improvement. We found something last winter in both sides. The new plate shows very little on the right side, but not far from the same on the left. I rather think that whatever trouble there is is receding, and likely will go on improving.

Last March when she was examined there were no symptoms, and I presume there are none now. I think she should carry on with her present work. I don't think there is any great danger of her infecting others. She should have a plate again in six months or so, and we may possibly be there to do it. An Indian reserve and an Indian school are so full of infection that one with no symptoms and as little in the plate as Miss Fraser has should be all right - indeed I think I would be inclined, if she was without symptoms, to let her teach even in an ordinary school which has not got so much infection in it. We would be glad to know how she gets on. In the meantime if you don't mind, perhaps we will hold the plate you sent with the one we have and when future plates are taken, we will have both of these for comparison."

In the light of the information set forth in the above letter, I could see no reason why Miss Fraser should not continue to discharge the duties of the office to which she had been appointed by our Commission, and I authorized her to do so, subject to the approval of our Commission, and subject to the result of another X-Ray examination at the time indicated. Miss Fraser appeared to me to be in very good health, and she herself and her father who is the Principal, assured me that she had not been absent from duty on account of ill health, and that she had never found her duties beyond her strength.

With regard to the Engineership, I beg to inform you that this position is filled by a man who is fully competent to look after all the equipment in that department. He filled the engineership for over a year at the Indian School at Brandon. I am not certain as to whether he will remain in the work permanently, but should he sever his connection with the same, you
may rest assured that our Commission will secure a fully competent man to take his place.

I regret that I was unable to see the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. Lovell, but when I called at the Agency I met his assistant, and took up with him certain matters relating to repairs and equipment which seemed to me to require immediate attention. As the Indian Agent will, no doubt, communicate with you direct with regard to these, I feel that I need not do more than tabulate the principal items which are as follows:

1. re-shingling of the roof of the main school building.
2. plastering and painting of the interior,
3. building of a porch over the boys' entrance, as the prevailing winds strike on that part, and I know of no other means of helping to keep out the severe cold.
4. the building of a partition at the head of the stairs on the boys' side of the building.
5. improving the steps installed to take the place of the pole fire escape.
6. some new bed springs.

The following new buildings are also greatly needed at this institution:

- stock barn - cattle shed - ice house - root house.

The school management have made a temporary root house which they are using this winter, but it is not satisfactory as a permanent structure. The ice house now in use might be altered so as to make it serviceable which it certainly is not at present.

For some years past the attention of your Department has been directed in the comprehensive list submitted of the requirements at all of our Society's Schools, to the necessity of having a recreation room for the girls. At this school they have none at present, and are obliged to use the Junior class-room for this purpose. The lack of a recreation room imposes an additional strain upon the school management which is not fair either to them or to the children. Our Society has been asking for some time that, at this and other schools, a detached class-room be built, with space and equipment for manual training in
the basement of the same. If your Department will carefully consider this need, and take steps to supply the same, you will confer a great benefit on the school, and relieve the school management of one of the heaviest handicaps under which the work at this institution is being carried on at present.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

MEMORANDUM:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

I have to inform you that the MacKay Indian Residential School building at The Pas, Man., was totally destroyed by fire on the 19th instant. There was no loss of life. No report has been received as to the cause of the fire, but the local Agent wired that he was forwarding, by mail, a full report in detail.

This building was of frame construction, erected in 1913-14, at a cost of $76,575.

There were 61 pupils in residence. Grant being provided for 50 pupils only at $170 per capita. This school was conducted under the auspices of the Anglican Church.

Arrangements have been made for the transfer of 40 pupils to the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, where there is accommodation for them. The Agent was instructed, in making the transfer of the above number, to see that orphans, neglected and younger children have the preference. It may be possible to place a number of the children in other Anglican Indian residential schools, and this is receiving consideration.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

Further to my telegram of the 19th instant, regarding the burning of the MacKay Indian Residential School, The Pas, I wish to report as follows:

At 15 minutes after one o'clock on the afternoon of March 19th, I received official notice from Mr. Fraser, Principal of the above school, that the school had burned down. I immediately left for the school accompanied by Constable Anderson R.C.M.P., to investigate the fire. On arriving I found the school to be a total loss, so we took statements from those directly connected with the fire which I enclose. There seemed to be a certain amount of carelessness on the part of the Engineer and Night-watchman in having this wood piled so close to the jacket heater mentioned in their statements, also a certain amount of carelessness in not making positively sure that the fire was out in the first place, by either tearing down the ceiling, or taking up the floor in the next storey, also in not sounding the fire alarm immediately which would have notified the whole staff of the fire. The hose pipes in the school were inspected by me in the presence of Mr. Fraser, Principal, on October 25th, 1932 and were found satisfactory, but there seemed to be a lack of pressure during the fire. A considerable amount of goods were salvaged, such as blankets, mattresses, piano, furniture etc., The pump house, barn and warehouse were not damaged to any extent during the fire. The roof of the ice-house was partly burned, but the walls are in good condition. Mr. Fraser and I arranged to billet possibly 50 children with the Indians of The Pas Reserve who at the present time have lots of food. About 30 of the smallest children are staying in the church which is being used for a dormitory at the time. Most of the staff are staying in Mr. Fraser's residence with the exception of those needed to supervise the church.

Trusting this will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

Samuel Lovell,
Acting Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Report from Mr. Fraser, Principal.

March 19th, 1933.

It was about five minutes to eight when I went to the school on the morning of March 19th, everything seemed alright. I was going into the children's dining-room when I met Mr. Wilson and he did not say anything. Then I went to the staff dining-room. Mr. Wilson came in, the matron came in after him and said we had a fire this morning, in the basement. I said "What" and no alarm. Mr. Wilson said I was going to report to Mr. Fraser myself. Then Miss Favell came in and said there was a lot of smoke in the children's dining-room and kitchen and she looked alarming, so I went into my study and got my fire extinguisher and was rushing to the basement when Leonard was passing, so I gave it to him. I rushed back through the boy's play-room to look at the stove. The room was clear of smoke, but smoke was coming up under the boy's stairway. Mr. Wilson was there and I told him here is more fire. I then told him to ring the alarm. The fire was already breaking through the ventilator. I then went to the top floor and it was worse, I tore down the hose on the top floor but it did not work, no pressure. I yelled to get the pumps going. I went down to my office again to get some Pyrene and met Leonard on the stairs and he cut the can open with an axe. The hose on the second floor was working a little by this time. I told the boy's to save all they could, it was all over then. The boy's were wonderful. I went downstairs to the office to make sure that everybody was out.
Report from Leonard Fraser, Night Watchman. March 19th, 1933.

I came on duty at 9 P.M. March 18th, and everything was alright. I was in the basement at 6.30 A.M. the morning of the 19th March, then went out to the power house. I came back and woke Mr. Wilson at 6.35 A.M., everything was alright. After I woke Mr. Wilson I went out to the power house again. When I came in from the power-house I went in the kitchen and Mr. Wilson was having tea and we smelled smoke. Mr. Wilson went upstairs with tea for the ladies. When he came down we had our tea, then we noticed smoke, so we went down to the basement and found the wood at the jacket heater burning. We rushed back to the kitchen and got water, the fire was under the jacket heater, it was blazing. We threw the water on the fire and put the fire out. We made two or three trips to the kitchen for water, I went up and got more water to leave in the basement in case we needed it. Mr. Wilson went to get some boys to move the wood to the centre of the floor. I noticed a crack about 2 inch in width between the cement wall and the ceiling which was smouldering, but I could not get water to the fire on account of steam pipes being in the way. Mr. Wilson came down and I told him I could not get the water to the fire, so he rushed out and got a small fire extinguisher and it did not work, so he went back and got a big one. I climbed up on the wood pile and used the fire extinguisher in the crack and to the best of my knowledge I put the fire out, so when that was over Mr. Wilson and the boys moved the wood and we went out on the back stairways and felt the walls to see if they were warm, but there was no sign of fire. I mentioned to Mr. Wilson that we should get an axe and make sure but he seemed sure the fire was out, so we did not bother but went upstairs and finished our tea. I went down again and the boys had taken the wood away and I looked up at the crack again and I could not see any fire at all. While I was down Mr. Wilson came down, things looked alright. I went upstairs to get ready for breakfast. I don't know whether the wood at the jacket heater started the fire or not but the wood was very dry. While at breakfast Miss Favell came into the staff dining-room and told us the fire had started again. Mr. Fraser rushed and got a fire extinguisher and I put it on the same crack where the fire was burning again but it did not put the fire out so then I rushed upstairs to see if I could do anything there but the fire seemed to be in the air ventilator. The hose on the second floor was working a little, the hose on the first floor was working good but there did not seem enough pressure at the time to put water all through the school. Mr. Wilson was at the pumps, we were too busy carrying water from the kitchen to the basement for the first fire, and did not have time to ring the fire bell. I do not remember any iron being tore from the ceiling.
Report from William H. Wilson, Engineer. March 19th, 1933.

I went on duty at 7 A.M. March 19th, relieving Leonard Fraser, night-watchman. I was drinking a cup of tea in the kitchen when I smelled smoke. I asked Leonard Fraser what was smoking and he said I have just put on a fire but the smoke got worse so I went down in the basement followed by Fraser and found a pile of wood burning. The wood was in behind the hot water jacket, the wood was blazing. I ran back to the kitchen and got water. Fraser did the same, we carried water until the fire was out, then we discovered that the metallic covering on the ceiling was red hot. Fraser got a pail of water and a dipper and threw the water on the ceiling. I went out and got a small fire extinguisher but it was no good. I rushed to the second floor and got a big extinguisher from just outside Miss Fraser's room and took it down the basement and gave it to Leonard Fraser who was stood on the wood pile close to the ceiling, he used it and put the fire out. When we were through we could see no sign of fire, then I got boys and moved all the wood to be sure that the fire was out. I was sure there was no more fire. I then washed and went to breakfast. I only just sat down when someone came to the dining-room and reported smoke coming through the floor in beneath the back stairs. I then went out to start the pumps. I had 45 pounds of pressure but the hose was leaking. By this time the fire was in the air ventilator, in flames beyond control. We then tried to get out as much goods as possible. The alarm was sounded at once but not for the first fire which I thought was out. The matron went down in the basement and she was sure the first fire was out. We tore the metallic covering off the ceiling but could see no more fire. Fire was coming out of the roof when I went to start the pumps. Wood must have fallen against the fire door of the jacket heater to start the fire in the first place and the fire could easily start if that had happened.
Report from Olive Wiatt, Matron March 19th, 1933.

I am matron of the school. I was called at 6.45 A.M. March 19th, and did not notice any smoke until I opened the basement door, then I thought it was the furnace smoke, but the smoke got worse so Miss Neals and I went down to see, and I asked when the fire had started and was told it was the wood from the jacket heater that started the fire. I was sure the fire was out when I left the basement. I spoke to Mr. Wilson and he told me he thought the fire had started six or seven hours earlier than this, so we went back to breakfast, and I met Mr. Fraser and he did not know anything about the fire. Miss Favell came in the dining-room and told us heavy smoke was coming through again. Mr. Fraser rushed right out and got a fire extinguisher. Mr Rollings went out to help them. I went to the children's dining-room, then I went upstairs to dormitory and got the children out. The first I knew of the fire was when I opened the basement door, when I went upstairs I saw flames in the air ventilator. The first real warning the staff had was when Miss Favell came into the dining-room about five minutes past eight.

March 27th, 1933

Dear Doctor McGill:

I visited the MacKay Indian Residential School on February 24th and again on March 6th. On both occasions I made a thorough inspection of the building, but was only able to visit the classroom on the latter date as the school was not in session on the occasion of my first visit, due to the fact that the furnace was being repaired and the classrooms were too cold to be opened.

Since returning to Winnipeg I received word of the fire which occurred on March 19th, totally destroying this building. This is to be greatly regretted, and as the staff will not be retained, it hardly seems necessary to make as exhaustive a report as one might otherwise do.

Miss L. Farrow, the senior teacher, is qualified and if proper discipline had been maintained throughout the school, there is no doubt that she would have obtained better results in her classroom.

Miss Wright, who was in charge of the junior room on my previous visit, had left. Her resignation was brought about as a result of lax discipline throughout the school, she having attempted to punish one of the older girls who, I understand, would not take the punishment and turned on Miss Wright, resulting in a nervous breakdown.

After Miss Wright's retirement, Mr. Fraser's son took over the classroom until Miss M. Neales was appointed. This Harold W. McGill, M.D., Deputy Superintendent General, Dept. of Indian Affairs, OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6267, file 580-1, part 2)
teacher intimated that she had no intentions of remaining longer than the end of June.

Since my last visit Miss Schennells, the matron at that time, has been transferred to the Elkhorn School and Miss Lindsay was appointed matron at MacKay. She only carried on for a month or two and resigned, and Miss Wyatt, a graduate nurse, was appointed. Miss Wyatt is new to the Indian work and to her duties as a matron of such an institution. She appeared quite willing to co-operate in every way, but with the unrest quite evident among the staff, she was finding the work difficult.

Miss Fraser is the sewing teacher and girls' supervisor. During my inspection Nurse Pears made a careful check of the condition of all the boys and girls in regard to their bodies and clothing. This examination was carried out in the presence of Miss Wyatt, the matron, who agreed that the condition of the girls was disgraceful. Almost 90% of the girls had nits in their hair, many of them being very bad, and over 50% were dirty in person. Both nurses agreed that in many cases the girls' underclothing was dirty. Miss Wyatt was surprised to find this condition as she naturally expected Miss Fraser, the girls' matron, to attend to all matters of this nature relating to the girls. Miss Fraser was certainly not fulfilling her duties as girls' supervisor.

Miss Griffiths is boys' supervisor, and although conditions were none too good, we found the boys much better than the girls. Out of a total of 40, only 9 had nits, while 24 were dirty in person. The dormitories
The dormitories were in fair condition, but I found a number of cases in connection with the girls where no nightdresses appeared under their pillows. However, I learned later that the girls were wearing these in the daytime, which fact was discovered during their examination.

The boys' washroom and toilets were in good condition. The girls' were far from satisfactory, and this was pointed out both to the matron and Mr. Fraser. This work again was the duty of the girls' matron.

Mr. Fraser's son was acting as nightwatchman, and in view of the fact that I was not satisfied that his duties were being carried out as they should, it was my intention to ask that a clock be installed.

Mr. H. Bicknell, referred to in Department letter of February 15th, No.128-1-1, had left, having resigned after serving a couple of months. Mr. Wilson, the new appointment as engineer, had only been on the staff a short time, but I understand had his third class engineer's certificate.

I am informed that during the past fifteen months, twelve or thirteen changes have taken place on the staff at this school which, to say the least, is a very unfortunate situation and certainly does not tend to the promotion of efficiency. There was a general lack of discipline throughout the whole institution, and the Principal certainly cannot be altogether excused on this ground. There are many other details which, had not the unfortunate disaster occurred on March 19th, could well have been reported, but as nothing is to be gained now by so doing.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th instant, requesting a further advance of $35 to complete the transportation expenses of a number of the pupils of the MacKay Indian Residential School to their homes.

In this connection I have to say that it will not be possible to send this advance, as our funds for the fiscal year ending today are exhausted and the new Appropriation is not yet available. You should forward certified accounts, in triplicate, covering the above amount, when, by the time they reach the Department, funds will be available.

I would request that you account as soon as possible for the expenditure of the $500 which was wired you to the Canadian Bank of Commerce. You should prepare a statement, in triplicate, accounting for the disbursement of this amount, and receipts, etc., should be attached.

You should, as requested by telegram of the 24th instant, forward a list of the names of the pupils who were sent to Elkhorn and their MacKay school register number, also the list of pupils who have returned to their homes.

Your communication of the 20th instant, reporting on the burning of the school, together with statements from the Principal and members of the staff, was received. Mr. Inspector Hamilton was requested by wire to visit The Pas to make a thorough investigation into the cause of the fire and to advise regarding the disposal of any Government owned equipment and stock.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to reply to your telegram of the 24th instant, regarding additional MacKay School pupils for Elkhorn I.R. School.

The forty children sent to Elkhorn were all destitute cases and were children from the furthest northern points, as it would have been practically impossible to get these children home until open water, which would not be until sometime in May. The eight pupils questioned in your telegram were not as destitute as the forty sent south, also they belong to reserves nearer The Pas. All the rest of the pupils from outside reserves are being sent home as soon as possible. All the children at the MacKay School of The Pas Reserve, with the exception of one, are attending Day Schools on The Pas Reserve.

I attach herewith the required list of the children sent to Elkhorn, with their numbers, where they are from and their approximate ages, which I trust will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

1. Reference the above I have to report that at 1.00 p.m. on March 19th;1933, information was received at this office to the effect that the McKay Indian Boarding School at Big Eddy, near The Pas, Manitoba had been destroyed by fire at about 8.00 a.m. that morning.

2. Acting on instructions received from Sgt.P.Rose, I/c., The Pas Detachment, I left in company with Mr.S.Lovell, Acting Indian Agent for the Pas District, per horse team and proceeded to the school, arriving at 2.15 p.m.

3. The building had been burned to the ground, only the two brick chimneys and cement foundations being left standing. The ruins were still burning strongly and the heat too great to allow a close investigation of the remains.

4. A considerable quantity of bedding, furniture and personal property was saved, this being principally from the first and second floors, practically nothing was saved from the upper floor.

I interviewed William H.Wilson, engineer at the school and he gave me the following statement:

"I was called at 6.40 a.m. Sunday March 19th;1933. At 7.00 a.m. I took over at 7.00 a.m. from Leo Fraser, night watchman. I was sitting in the kitchen drinking tea when Fraser came up from the basement and spoke and asked what was burning. He said he had smelled smoke. I sat there for a few minutes more and then went upstairs. I went into the basement and Fraser told me there was a pile of wood in below the hot water boiler. I ran up to the kitchen and grabbed a big pan of water and did the same and we threw the water on the fire. We continued to carry water until it was put out. We discovered that the ceiling was smouldering. I got a pail of water and a dipper and tried to put more water on it. I went upstairs and got a bucket but it wouldn't work, it was useless. I went to the second floor and got the big fire extinguisher Miss Fraser's room and we emptied that. We were through we could see no sign of fire. I called boys and got them to move the wood from the boiler to see if it was properly out and satisfied there was no further danger. I washed breakfast. We had just sat down to breakfast when I was asked when someone came to the window and reported that smoke was coming through the boys playroom. I ran out to the pump and turned the pump figuring we should need the sounds pressure of water on but the hose was leaking. Water ran all over the floor but..."
but nothing came out of the nozzle. By this time the flames were in the air shaft and the fire had then got beyond control. I then went over to help get furniture and stuff out. No alarm was given during the first fire as it was only a small one and I did not consider it necessary. The fire went into the basement after the first fire and she was also satisfied that everything was alright. We have a regular system of fire alarms and the last fire drill was held about 4 days ago. During the first fire we pulled the tin roofing down to make sure the fire was out. There was absolutely no sign of fire after we finished. The only way I can think the fire started again was that it went further back under the metallic roofing. The first fire apparently started by some of the wood for the heater falling down against the cast iron door of the heater. This door at times gets practically red hot and a fire would easily start if that did happen."

W.H.Wilson.

6. I next interviewed Miss Olive Wyatt, matron at the school and obtained the following statement from her:

STATEMENT GIVEN BY MISS O.WYATT:

a) "I am matron of the McKay Indian School at Big Eddy. When I went downstairs at about 7.00 a.m. on Sunday March 19th; 1933 into the kitchen I smelled smoke. I met Miss Griffiths on the stairs and she told me there had been a fire in the furnace room. I took Miss Hemmings into the basement. The fire to all appearances was out and there seemed no danger. I asked the origin of the fire and was told that a piece of small wood by the jacket heater had caught fire. There were several boys moving the wood away from where it had been piled. Several of the pieces were badly charred, but were absolutely out. I asked Mr. Wilson when it started and he told me he thought it must have started six or seven hours before, but I do not think this was possible. We went up to breakfast and Mr. Fraser came in and I asked him about it, but he had not heard anything about it. I had barely spoken to Mr. Fraser when Miss Flavelle came tearing into the dining room and said there was heavy smoke coming through - I didn't hear where. Mr. Fraser went out with an extinguisher with Mr. Rawlings. After that I went into the dining room to see if the children were alright. Then I went upstairs to see if the several sick children were alright. I told them to get dressed. Whilst upstairs I saw flames coming out of the cold air register. Up to the time Miss Flavelle came into the dining room this was the first real warning we had had of fire. This was about 8.05 a.m. The rest of the time I helped at saving things!"

Olive Wyatt.

7. Leonard Fraser, night watchman, was then interviewed and gave the following statement:

STATEMENT GIVEN BY L.FRASER:

"I came on duty at 9.00 p.m. March 18th; 1933. Everything was alright when I went on. I was down in the basement about 6.30 a.m. on the 20th; and everything was alright then, no signs of any smoke. About 6.40 a.m. I woke Mr. Wilson and then went over to the powerhouse. When I came back Wilson was in the kitchen having some tea, he went upstairs and when he came down we had some more tea, and he then smelled smoke, he opened the door leading to the furnace room and went down and we saw a..."
McKays Indian Boarding School, Big Eddy, The Pas, Man:

DESTROYED BY FIRE.

Assistance to Department of Indian Affairs.

A pile of small wood under the jacket heater blazing. We both went upstairs and got pans of water and threw that on it and that put it out. We made two or three trips with water. Wilson went upstairs to get some boys to move the wood away. I noticed a crack between the cement wall and the ceiling that was smouldering. I tried to throw water on it but there were too many pipes in the way for me to do so. Mr. Wilson came down while I was doing this and he rushed upstairs to get a fire extinguisher. I asked him if it would work and he said he didn't know and tried it, but it wouldn't work. He went upstairs to get another one. This one worked and I turned it on the crack. After I had emptied it I looked all along the crack and couldn't see anything at all. It was all black and appeared to be out. We went upstairs by the boys stair railing the wood to see if it was hot, everything seemed alright and we thought the fire was out. I mentioned getting an axe to take up the flooring to see if it was alright. We felt the floor and as it wasn't hot we thought it was alright and so didn't worry about taking up the floor. Mr. Wilson went into the basement to see that the boys removed the wood from the heater and went into the kitchen. I later went downstairs and the wood had all been moved. I looked all along the crack and everything seemed alright. Mr. Wilson also came down while I was there. This fire started though the wood by the heater catching alight. I did not tear any of the metallic ceiling off, it did not seem necessary as the crack was about 1 inch wide and I could see right inside. Just after breakfast was started, the alarm was given. I immediately went into the furnace room. The crack was blazing again. Someone handed me an extinguisher and I turned it on. It worked alright but did not seem to have any effect on the flames. I went upstairs and the flames were shooting right up the air shaft. I then helped at saving furniture and so on. I went down to the second floor. The hose was working alright but there was not enough pressure on to do very much good. The hose on the first floor was also working alright. The hose was leaking badly. No alarm was given at the first fire all I thought of was of getting water at that time."

Leonard Fraser.

8. Mr. Albert Fraser, Principal of the McKays School was next interviewed and gave the following statement:

a) "I always have breakfast with the staff and rose at 6.40 a.m. this morning and went over to the school at 7.55. I met Wilson at the door of the dining room. He did not say anything to me. No smell of smoke at that time. I said 'Grace' in the children's dining room and then went into the staff dining room. Miss Wyatt told me there had been a fire in the basement that morning. I asked why no alarm had been given. Wilson said he had been going to report it to me himself. Miss Favelle then came into the room and said there was a lot of smoke in the kitchen and dining room. I went into my study and got the fire extinguisher and went to the basement and Leonard (Fraser) passed me and I handed him the extinguisher. I then went into the boys playroom - it was alright there. There was heavy smoke on the boys staircase and the fire was already breaking through the air shaft ventilators. Wilson was with me then. I called for the alarm to be given. I went up to the top floor and it was worse up there. I got out the hose on the top floor but it didn't work, there not being enough pressure. I went downstairs and the hose on the second floor was working but did not have..."
have very much pressure. I went down to my study and got a can of Pyrex and poured this on the flames upstairs, but it did not have any effect on the flames. I then saw that it was impossible to save the building and helped to save the furniture and to see that all the children were safe."

Albert Fraser.

9. With reference to the statement by Wm.H.Wilson, engineer at the school, given in paragraph 5 it will be noted that he stated that though he had the pumps working the hoses were not good, that they were leaking. In the statements by Leonard Fraser, nightwatchman, paragraph 7 and that of Albert Fraser, principal, paragraph 8 it is stated by both that the hoses were working alright but there was not sufficient pressure of water.

10. Wilson also stated that part of the metallic roofing was torn down to make sure that the fire had not gone further back. Leonard Fraser states that no roofing was torn down and further, that he suggested getting an axe and taking up the flooring on the first floor to make sure it was out, but after feeling the woodwork and finding that it wasn't hot, both he and Wilson decided it would not be necessary.

11. It is apparent that the first fire started from the pile of small wood by the hot water jacket catching fire. And the second fire came from the ceiling under the metallic roofing, which had been alight during the first fire and which had not been properly put out. There being nearly 20 years accumulation of dust, etc., in between the flooring and the metallic ceiling there would be plenty for the fire to travel on and once it reached the air shaft it jumped right to the top floor and would have so many outlets that it would be impossible to combat it.

12. Negligence on the part of Leonard Fraser and Wm. Wilson to give the alarm during the first fire and also in not tearing down the metallic ceiling or taking up the flooring on the first floor seems to have resulted in the fire gaining a fresh hold with the consequent loss of the entire building.

13. I returned to The Pas the same pm arriving at 6.30. No expenses incurred.

Mileage....(Horse livery...(gratis)...14 miles.

Dear Sir:-

Re: MACKEY SCHOOL FIRE

With further reference to my telegram to you on the 19th. inst. re the loss of the Mackay School through fire that day, I beg to state that our Commission have received from the Rev. A. Fraser, Principal of this school, a statement setting forth what he believes "to be the cause of the fire based on reports given by night watchman and engineer."

Our Commission have also received a report from their Assistant Secretary-Treasurer, Colonel E. W. Mernagen who was instructed to proceed to The Pas as soon as possible after the fire, to investigate the cause, and to deal with any matters pertaining to the remaining property, the staff and the pupils, etc. requiring immediate action.

THE PRINCIPAL'S STATEMENT, dated March 22nd., dealing with the cause of the fire, reads, in part, as follows:-

"No doubt it started in the furnace room near the jacket heater. The night watchman (Leonard Fraser) gives information that he was in the furnace room at 6.30 A.M. There was absolutely no sign of smoke or fire around the jacket heater at that time. He then went out to the power house and started the pump engine. On his return he went upstairs to awaken the engineer (Mr. Wilson); this would be about 6.40 A.M. After this he went down to the kitchen and made a cup of tea as usual. Mr. Wilson came downstairs shortly after 7 A.M. After the night watchman had awakened the engineer and a number of others he claimed he went out to the power house a second time and was in the power house when the rising bell sounded. He returned to the kitchen, detected no smoke from the furnace room and proceeded to have his morning cup of tea with the engineer. At this juncture they both simultaneously detected smoke. They both went down immediately into the furnace room and saw..."
"the wood on fire under the jacket heater. They rushed back to the kitchen Mr. Wilson seizing a dishpan of water and the night watchman a cauldron of the children's tea with which they managed to extinguish the flames.

"The flames were leaping as high as the ceiling when they went down to investigate the first time they detected any sign of smoke. After extinguishing the flames they detected a red glow on the metallic ceiling near the cement wall. They got two pails of water with which the night watchman tried to cope with what he thought was fire in the ceiling. He used a dipper throwing the water upwards. Not being satisfied he called for a fire extinguisher to be brought in. Mr. Wilson brought a small one which was useless. Mr. Wilson ran up to the first flat and brought down a large one from Miss Fraser's station. This extinguisher worked shooting the liquid into the crack of the ceiling which the night watchman thought had a smoldering appearance. Both the engineer and the night watchman were satisfied that the fire was extinguished thoroughly and all danger over. The matron left her room about 7.15 A.M. having received no intimation whatever of what was going on until going down the stairway she met Miss Griffith ascending to the top flat and noticed a great volume of smoke when the door was opened leading to the stairway. Miss Griffith informed the matron the smoke was coming from the furnace room and had gone down to the kitchen to ask concerning it and had been informed that Mr. Wilson and the night watchman were down in the furnace room working with it then and she reasoned, therefore, that there was no need for alarm. The matron informed me she went down into the furnace room, meeting the night watchman coming through the door leading into the kitchen who informed her that there had been a fire in the jacket heater fuel pile but that it was then extinguished. She went down then and personally investigated and found everything seemingly all right. Before going down she had also seen the engineer who informed her also that the fire was absolutely out. After this she requested Miss Neales to come down with her a second time to investigate - this would be about 7.55 A.M. They did go down and thoroughly examined the woodpile and found three or four boys throwing it out of the corner into the middle of the basement. They noticed that a great many pieces were badly charred but no sign of sparks were to be seen."
"I came over from the residence as usual about 7:55 A.M. but did not detect any smoke whatever or anything unusual. After removing my coat I went in to the children's dining room met Mr. Wilson at the door of the dining room (children's), the boys were already in and the girls were just beginning to march in. I took my place near the centre of the floor as usual and after the usual procedure returned to the staff dining room for breakfast. I did not detect anything unusual at all and the place was quite free from smoke. I had no intimation whatever that there had been a fire until at the breakfast table the matron mentioned that there had been an exciting time fighting a fire. This was the very first intimation I had had of what had been going on and was filled with horror - this would be about 8:05 A.M. ........ While at breakfast the kitchen matron came in and excitedly informed me that she had detected smoke. I immediately jumped to my feet, rushed into the office, seized a fire extinguisher and ran in to the children's dining room towards the furnace room. The night watchman met me taking my extinguisher. I rushed back to the boys' stairway and was met by a huge volume of smoke. Mr. Wilson was with me. I told him that the fire must be under the stairway and to get in to it. I ran upstairs then to the first flat, already smoke was coming through around the air shaft. I yelled for the alarm to be sounded immediately, which was done. The matron followed closely in my wake and I at once ordered her to see that all the sick were out of the dormitories which she did. I then proceeded to the top flat, even there the flames were coming through around the air ventilator. I immediately took down the fire hose but it wouldn't function properly. I then went down to the first flat, the pressure of water there was somewhat better but not sufficient to fight the fire with. Seeing the advance the fire was making I was convinced that we were beaten by the fire. I gave orders to save as much of the movable property as possible, which was done. The children were all out of the building at the time the alarm was sounded - they being all together in their own dining room. I gave orders for a close check to be made of both boys and girls which was carried out. I have no hesitation in claiming that the fire originated in the furnace room over the jacket heater. The smoke being all drawn up through an opening leading from the basement to the cupola in the roof, through which opening the air shaft had been placed. The building proved itself..."
a regular fire trap and had it occurred during the night season I am much afraid that certain of our staff members would have been trapped in their rooms. Half an hour after we got the first real warning of fire from the kitchen matron at about 8:05 A.M., it was unsafe to go across through the halls on first and second flat. Less than three hours the whole structure was demolished. I will give full verbal particulars to Colonel Mermagen on his arrival, and no doubt the staff members will do likewise to the best of their knowledge.

"The lady members of the staff were simply wonderful, keeping cool during the most trying experience that we have ever passed through. The senior boys and girls were splendid. My own boys worked unsparingly rendering every assistance possible to the last. The Indians were also wonderful in helping to rescue the storerooms where flour and fodder were stored and the children were practically taken off our hands for the time being by Indians asking that they might look after them for a day or so, seeing we had no proper place to house them. We kept eleven small ones that the matron felt we could not safely allow to go on account of their recent sickness - they having only been out of bed two days from an attack of 'flu. People from town sent word of their willingness to house staff members and even children if need be, for which we are very grateful but the staff members preferred to stay together on the premises and rough it for a few days rather than disperse to more comfortable quarters. I can only say that we have been very fortunate in having the type of staff we had as they have certainly proved themselves to be, even in the face of all they have recently passed through, loyal and most devoted .........."

THE REPORT OF COLONEL MERMAGEN, Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission, confirms the above statement of the Principal in every detail, and furnishes the following additional particulars:

"At about 7 a.m. the Night Watchman and Engineer noticed smoke coming from the furnace room, but as this happened frequently when the fires had been freshly made up, they at first paid little attention. As the smoke did not decrease, however, they went down and found that some of the small wood used for the jacket heater had fallen and come in contact with a cleanout door, in the furnace, which got very hot when a big fire was on, and ignited. This had started the whole pile of kindling, and there was a blaze in the corner under the boys' side of the dining room. Both men rushed to the kitchen, the Engineer taking a dish pan of water and the Night Watchman a boiler which was heating for
the children's tea. The dish pan extinguished the burning wood, and the Night Watchman climbing on a pipe and using a dipper, threw the contents of the boiler on to the metal ceiling which was red hot, and cooled that off. The Engineer in the meantime ran for one of the hand extinguishers in the kitchen, which refused to work. He then went to the hall on the second floor and brought down a large extinguisher which was in good working order, and together he and the Night Watchman thoroughly drenched the ceiling and the pile of kindling until no vestige of fire or smoke was visible. They stayed down for a time, but as no sign of fire was apparent when the breakfast bell rang, they went upstairs to the staff dining room and sat down.

Whilst the Night Watchman and Engineer were thus engaged, the usual school routine was going forward. The Kitchen Matron came down about 7 a.m. and being informed that there was a slight fire in the basement, filled several pails of water for use. Miss Neales who was on table duty noticed smoke after she came down and went to the stairs leading to the furnace room, where she met the Engineer who informed her that the fire was out and all danger over. Shortly before 8 the Principal came over to the school for breakfast, and having visited the pupils' dining room, went to the staff dining room. Before breakfast was started the Head Matron came in and in apology for not being strictly on time, mentioned the morning's excitement. The Principal asked for an explanation, and on receiving it demanded to be informed why he had not been notified, and calling to the men to follow him, made for the furnace room. On his way through he met the Boys' Supervisor who reported a considerable volume of smoke coming up from the furnace room. The Principal immediately ordered the alarm bell sounded, and the children marched out, and himself went to the fire hose. The hose although recently inspected by the Principal and the Indian Agent, proved faulty in places, and the stream was inadequate. The Principal then went to the office and seized a large extinguisher which was taken from him by the Night Watchman for use in the furnace room. The Principal was then informed that smoke and flame was bursting from the large ventilator which ended in a cupola at the top of the building, and having ascertained this report to be true, he gave up hope of saving the building, and as the children were safely outside, devoted his energies to saving as much of the equipment as possible. In this work he was aided by members of the staff and spoke in the highest terms of the courage and devotion to duty of every one of them. The Indian men from the reserve also came flocking over and by their help the large supply of flour and feed was taken from the store house and placed in safety. Afterwards they kept
the roof of this building covered with snow to prevent sparks from setting fire to it.

"The wind was from the South East, so that the engine house, although nearest the main building, was out of danger. The ice house, some twenty yards further away had the south side of its roof badly charred in spite of repeated applications of snow. Had the ice house caught, the fate of the store house would have been sealed. Actually, the main building was the only one destroyed.

"During the early stages of the fire the salvage work went rapidly forward. 71 mattresses, 117 quilts, 47 flannel-ette sheets and 72 pillows were saved, as well as many bed spreads, pillow slips, etc. The office files were rescued as well as furniture from the staff sitting room, including the piano. The stock rooms where the spare clothing was kept were unfortunately attached to the ventilator shaft, and when efforts were made by the Supervisors to get at the contents they were driven back by clouds of smoke.

"The fire starting just at breakfast time, all the pupils were completely clad, and after the alarm, many secured their overcoats. There were at the time only two convalescent children to be looked after - a girl who was being retained until Monday, merely as a precaution, and a boy recovering from 'flu. The former walked over to the Residence herself, and the boy having been brought down by his Supervisor, was carried to the Residence by some of the bigger boys of the school, and later transferred to hospital. It is a magnificent tribute to the entire staff that their first thoughts were for the children, their second for bedding and the subsequent comfort of their charges, and only the third for their personal belongings. All suffered considerable loss, several practically everything. The Head Matron would at first appear to have been most fortunate, as owing to her recent arrival and the fact that her predecessor had occupied her quarters for a fortnight, Miss Wyatt had not unpacked her trunk which was rescued intact. Unfortunately the few things she had unpacked were her chief treasures, and most of all a Belgian war decoration, conferred by King Albert upon her deceased uncle for distinguished war services. Miss Farrow and Miss Neales, the two Teachers, both saved their certificates, but lost other valuable books, pictures, etc. Miss Fraser and Miss Griffiths, Supervisors, by looking after their charges, both lost heavily in personal effects, particularly the latter who was in attendance upon the sick boy until he was adequately cared for, lost more than..."
any other agent. Miss Favelle, Kitchen Matron, and Miss Vincent, Laundry Matron, both lost much of their belongings. Fortunately all saved their winter coats. Mr. Wilson, Engineer, lost his personal tools which he kept in his room as the school equipment was complete. He also lost a sum of money and clothing. Mr. Rawlings, Farmer, saved a portion of his effects, as did Mr. Leonard Fraser, the Night Watchman.

"The Principal commented most favourably upon the conduct of the Indians upon the reserve - the men as has been stated, gave valuable assistance in saving supplies, and both men and women when the disposal of the children was under consideration, offered to take in one or two additional, to their own homes until arrangements could be made. These offers were made entirely without ulterior motive, but in a subsequent conversation, Mr. Fraser asked if the Commission would be inclined to favourably consider a grant of some 25 lbs. of flour to the families who had undertaken this duty. I took it upon myself to promise this, and trust my action may be approved ...........................................

"I saw the Agent's report to Inspector Himilton, and noted that he had imputed carelessness to the Engineer and Night Watchman. With this opinion I disagree. An error in judgment, certainly, but not carelessness. Both men worked hard and were convinced that they had extinguished the fire. The error was in not tearing up part of the floor, and fighting the fire from above instead of below. I questioned every member of the staff, and from their replies am convinced that the cause of the fire was entirely accidental. I had the Engineer and Night Watchman in at the same time, and had them check each other's story. Replying to my query why had the Principal not been notified, the Engineer stated that they felt it was a simple job to put out the fire, but was distinctly a two-man job. At the time of the first outbreak, none of the other members of the staff or the children were up, and there was no one to send. Similarly as to ringing the alarm bell. If they extinguished the small blaze in time, of which they were quite confident, there was no necessity for raising the alarm. The reports from all members of the staff were substantially the same.

"My conclusion is, therefore, that the fire started accidentally. When it was discovered to be serious, the conduct of all concerned from the Principal to the youngest child in the school was above reproach, and that much valuable equipment was saved at considerable personal risk."
I beg once more to direct attention to the fact, that from start to finish of this unfortunate occurrence, the entire staff of the MacKay School, displayed a devotion to duty of which the Commission may well be proud."

The Principal's statement and the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer's Report were presented to our Commission at a meeting held here on the 28th. inst. when the following decisions, inter alia, were reached:

"(1) The Commission decided to record their sincere regret over the loss of this school building, and their equally sincere gratitude to Almighty God for preserving the lives of the staff and pupils.

(2) They accepted the finding of the Asst. Secy-Treas. as set forth in his report, and the statement of the Principal, that the fire was accidental in origin, and that the school management did their utmost to extinguish the same. The members present also accepted the Asst. Secy-Treasurer's statement that the Engineer and Night Watchman erred in their judgment when they were convinced that the fire had been extinguished and did not take the further action he suggests, in order that their conviction might be established by certainty.

(3) The Commission approved the action of the Department in sending 40 children to the Elkhorn School and decided to record their regret that for reasons given in the Departmental telegrams, the remaining pupils could not be sent to other schools.

(4) They instructed the Field Secretary to convey to the Principal and staff agents, an expression of the Commission's high appreciation of their conduct during the critical situation created by the fire, and approved the action of those who decided to return to their homes until other appointments might be available for any who desire to receive them."

The Principal, the Rev. A. Fraser, has been informed by our Commission that they will continue his salary until the end of June, and they trust that the Department may permit him and his family to occupy the Principal's residence until that date. As the Commission have no other appointment to offer Mr. Fraser, he will endeavour to secure ministerial work in one of our Church's Missionary Dioceses, where his splendid knowledge of the Cree language will be of special service. While remaining on the school premises he will exercise careful supervision of the remaining school property and equipment, and carry out any
instructions our Commission may give him with regard to the disposal of the supplies, wood fuel, live stock, implements, etc.

The services of a Farm Instructor will also be retained to look after the live stock, and assist in any way required either by Mr. Fraser or by our Commission.

It is the understanding of our Commission that the 71 mattresses and all the buildings except the Church, and all the land, including the hay land mentioned in your letter of March 12th, 1928, No.126-1-9 (and gazetted April 7th, 1928, page 3263) will pass under your Department's care as soon as our Commission have been able to dispose of the year's supply of hay, wood-fuel, flour, etc., and other items mentioned above.

The local Indian Agent will receive the study and exercise books which were rescued from the fire, and our Commission has addressed an inquiry to Mr. Fraser, the Principal, with regard to the possibility of disposing of the other items referred to.

In order that this matter may be handled in a way that will be satisfactory to both your Department and our Commission, it is recommended that power be given to Mr. Fraser as representing our Commission, and to Mr. Lovell, the local Indian Agent, as representing your Department, to deal with this important matter.

Sir:

As instructed by Department telegram dated March 24th, 1933, I left on the 26th for The Pas and investigated thoroughly conditions relating to the recent fire at the MacKay Indian Residential School. I herewith present my report.

The members of the staff and the pupils had all left the school - only the Fraser family remained. I investigated thoroughly the burned ruins, giving special attention to the furnace, jacket heater, and stove situated in the boys' playroom. The furnace was in good condition and in view of the pit in front of the furnace door, which is cemented on all sides and the bottom, a fire could scarcely occur, even though one might be somewhat careless.

The brick wall of the boiler is 18 ft. long and from this wall to the cement basement wall is 6 ft. The jacket heater is situated in this space and would be located about 10 ft. back from a line continuing past the front of the furnace and about 4 ft. away from the furnace wall. Attached is a sketch showing the exact location of boiler and jacket heater.

Dry jackpine had been thrown in a pile beyond the jacket heater in section on sketch marked "A". The wood had not been piled and no doubt some of it was on the floor around the heater. There is a further possibility.
