OTTAWA.
possibility that small pieces of bark and other dirt had accumulated around the wood and about the jacket heater. In view of the carelessness displayed by those in charge, this condition could easily have existed, making a most suitable setting for a fire.

The children bath on Friday and Saturday nights and plenty of hot water is needed. The jacket heater is usually brought into use on these occasions. The boys finished bathing at 9 p.m. Saturday, the 18th, and no doubt a fire was still on in the heater. The night watchman, Leonard Fraser, states he did not check conditions around the heater on taking over at 9 p.m., as he was not aware it had been in use. This statement appears too absurd to be credible, and personally I am sure he did know, but I am also sure that his sense of responsibility would not cause him to check up and see if everything was safe and in satisfactory condition.

A coal or spark from the heater, and all will agree that jackpine gives off frequent sparks, dropping on the wood and accumulated dirt, could easily smoulder along for some time and gradually work into a fire - especially under such favourable conditions.

The night watchman stated he fixed the furnace at 6 A.M., leaving the room at 6.30. At 7.15, only three quarters of an hour later, he and Mr. Wilson, the engineer, smelled smoke in the kitchen where they were enjoying tea, and going to the furnace room, found the jacket heater wood a mass of fire - the flames reaching to the ceiling. There is no way to prove that Mr. Fraser did attend the fire between 6 and 6.30 a.m., but if he did, it seems strange that such a fire could start.
start in thirty to forty minutes. This fire was presumably put out and the wood moved. The watchman stated he detected sparks along the top of the cement wall marked "B". The tin ceiling did not fit tight against this wall, allowing the flames to light the dust and dirt which undoubtedly had accumulated. He put out the sparks, but his responsibility did not prompt him to remove any of the tin ceiling, nor to open the floor above. He states he suggested doing this, but Mr. Wilson thought it unnecessary. It will be noted that this fire was detected at 7.15 a.m., and no doubt twenty or thirty minutes at least was required in extinguishing it, and yet no one remained on guard—all were seated in the dining room at 8 a.m. Some of the children claim they detected smoke coming through the floor shortly after being seated for breakfast, and as the alarm was actually given about 8.10 a.m., one can only conclude the first fire had never been extinguished and that the disaster occurred as a result of gross carelessness and lack of responsibility both on the part of Mr. Wilson and Mr. L. Fraser; in fact, both failed to notify the Principal that the first blaze had occurred and this fact only came to his attention as he sat down to breakfast, when the Matron remarked that a fire had existed. Rev. Mr. Fraser stated that he was astounded and rebuked them for not informing him, and yet he went on serving breakfast instead of immediately checking up to see if all was well. Four or five minutes later the kitchen matron rushed in with news of smoke appearing in the kitchen. A hasty examination was made. The Principal stated there was no water pressure on the third floor.
third floor and he ordered the pumps started. The rumour is that Mr. Wilson started the engine, but it stopped almost immediately as there was no gasoline in the tank.

There was some pressure on the second floor, but too weak to be of any assistance. The fire hose did leak, as do all fabric hose, but they did not have any splits or punctures, and as soon as they had become soaked, the leaking or oozing through would have stopped. I feel that the reference by Mr. Wilson that the hose leaked was made to cover up the fact that when he came on duty at 7 a.m., he was busy making tea and carrying trays to the lady members of the staff, instead of starting the pump and attending to the furnace.

It will be noted by the sketch that a stove was kept in the boys' basement (this room is marked "C") and I was informed by Mr. Wilson and different Indian boys that a fire was burning in it on Saturday night. The sketch also shows the stovepipe connections. At point "D" the pipe passed through a door into the unused hallway and turned through an opening in the cement wall connecting by a "T" with the jacket heater. The door at "D", through which the pipe passed, was not in use. A foot of cement wall ran above the door frame and on top of this cement wall rested the wood frame of the school. At the side opposite the furnace room, a ventilating shaft ran to the dormitories. I am pointing out these facts because, had the door at "D" caught fire, it might have lighted the sill above the door, or again, the stovepipes at "F" may have been disconnected enough to let a spark drop into the wood directly below. This theory might be discarded by some as Rev. Mr. Fraser declares that
declares that he went into the boys' playroom immediately after the warning of fire and that there was no smoke. I was unable to locate any boys who had visited the playroom prior to breakfast. I asked the night watchman if he had visited this room when coming on duty or during the night, and he replied "No!" One would at least expect a night watchman to visit all points where a fire was kept or where a fire had been in use during the day.

One other theory was presented by Rev. Mr. Fraser and his son, the watchman, and although practically impossible, I present same as it throws another light on the situation.

The boiler has a clean-out door marked "C", which is almost opposite the jacket heater. Rev. Mr. Fraser stated this door got hot and that perhaps wood rolled against it. The night man stated he had seen it red hot at times and that as there was no fire in the jacket heater, the fire must have started from the clean-out door. Prior to this, the impression given by both the Frasers was that the fire started from wood around the jacket heater - the story here changed to the boiler door.

However, if the floor had been as clean about the jacket heater as these men claimed, it would also, of necessity, need to be in front of the clean-out door of the furnace as it is almost directly opposite and only twenty to thirty inches away. The men agreed that to start a fire, the wood, of necessity, would need to be against the door, which is four to five inches above the floor level. This condition would necessitate more than one small stick of wood lying around and would indicate,

as I have
as I have already intimated, that no check had been made on the condition existing about this heater. They went even further and stated that Mr. Wilson never meant to convey the impression that the fire started from the jacket heater as no fire had been lit in this heater for ten or twelve days. However, Wilson, in his statement to the R.C.M.Police closed the statement with the following sentence: "Wood must have fallen against the door of the jacket heater and if it did a fire could easily have started." Undoubtedly, this indicates that he believed or knew a fire had been kept in the heater. I cannot help but ask how the Rev. Fraser or his son knew that Mr. Wilson did not intend to convey the impression that there was fire in the heater, nor can I understand why they now state that no fire had been there for ten or twelve days. I have a wire from Mr. Wilson and in spite of his statement to the R.C.M.Police, he writes, "No fire in jacket heater for ten days previous to Saturday eighteenth". It will be noted the first statements, all of which were forwarded by Mr. Lovell, The Agent, would lead one to believe that the jacket heater was the likely source of the fire. Now the scene changes, and all state that the heater had not been in use.

Rev. Mr. Fraser admits that he was last in the furnace room Saturday morning around 10 a.m. He states there was no fire in the heater then, although he does not admit opening the heater door.

Leonard Fraser, night man, admits he did not examine the heater when he came on duty at 9 p.m. He stated there was no use to go near it as it had not been alight for
alight for ten or twelve days.

Saturday night is bath night, and the boys finished at 9 p.m., and several stated that they had lots of hot water. The jacket heater was usually in use on wash days and bath days.

My contention is that the Principal, Rev. Fraser, did not have close enough contact with school operations to know when the heater was in use. I am informed by certain boys and by one who actually attended to the fire, that the heater had been in use several times during the past ten days and was lit on Saturday, the 18th.

Further, if the night watchman paid no more attention to his work on other nights, than he did on the night in question, neither was he in a position to know whether it had been in use or not. When I informed him of my information relating to it, he was then not so sure and would not sign a declaration that the heater contained no fire. He further qualified his previous statement in reference to the smoke door in the boiler, and said he had only seen it red hot on one occasion and then the boiler had been fired heavily for some hours.

I have not been able to consult Mr. Wilson personally and am at a loss to know why he changed his story and how it now happens to coincide with the one told by the Frasers.

I am more prepared to accept the boys' statement and believe that the heater had been used. The other theory would perhaps have looked better, but is weak, in that an unusually hot and prolonged fire would be needed.

Mr. Wilson, in a remark to the Matron, Miss Wyatt, stated that he felt the fire had started six or seven hours earlier.
hours earlier, which statement may be true. A spark or coal from the heater may have rolled on the floor in the dirt and smouldered for some time before actually bursting into flames. There is also a possibility that the night man did not visit the furnace at the time stated, and even if he had, his indifference, as indicated on so many other occasions, makes it impossible to accept his statement that all was well at 6.30.

In closing, I wish to point out that from the first statements submitted by Mr. Lovell, contradictions appeared. Mr. Wilson stated the hose were not good and that he had 45 lbs. pressure. The Principal and night man state that pressure was low and hose were in working order.

Wilson states tin was removed from the ceiling to make sure the fire was out. Leonard Fraser contradicts this and states that he suggested getting an axe to break in the floor, but Wilson thought that unnecessary.

These first statements conveyed the impression that the fire started from the jacket heater - now this has been contradicted.

However, from my own observations, from the careful perusal of all statements, and from my check up on Rev. Mr. Fraser, his son, and the Indian boys, and communication from Mr. Wilson, I can only arrive at the following conclusions, namely:

1. The fire started as a result of wood and bark near the jacket heater, which no doubt became lighted by a spark or coal falling either from the draft opening or ash door of the heater.

2. The fire may have started from the pipes leading from the heater in the boys' playroom. This stove was attended to solely by the boys, and had the door through which it passed, caught fire or had the pipe become disconnected at the cement wall, a spark could easily drop on the wood piled in section marked "A".
To accept this theory one would need to disregard the Principal's statement that he visited this room first and found no smoke. Some statements must be disregarded or we have no cause for the fire.

I believe the fire could have been extinguished if proper action had been followed when first found, and can only attribute the disaster to carelessness and lack of responsibility on the part of Mr. Wilson, the engineer, and Mr. L. Fraser, the night watchman. The positions these two men held are of vital importance in a school such as this, and I feel that men holding these positions should be appointed by the Department. They would then receive closer supervision by the Principal and in every way would need to measure up to the Department's expectations.

I regret this report does not clear matters as it should, but I think the Department will agree that too much time had elapsed after the fire before I arrived. The staff and children had scattered, making it difficult to secure corroborative evidence in connection with the various statements. However, the actually starting of the fire may never be definitely known, but the investigation shows clearly the spirit of indifference, which undoubtedly existed - the lack of a strong guiding hand as Principal - the folly of allowing the employment of any but the best and most competent men to fill such responsible positions. We can all be very grateful that the disaster occurred in daytime and that the lives entrusted to the care of the institution all escaped injury.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa, April 24, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 31st ultimo, regarding the destruction by fire of the MacKay Indian Residential School, I have to say that the Department has received reports from Mr. Inspector Hamilton, the local Indian Agent and the R.C.M.P., relative to the matter.

The statements of the various members of the staff are somewhat conflicting. There is no doubt that there was great carelessness manifested on the part of Mr. L. Fraser, the night watchman, and Mr. Wilson, the engineer. If they had taken proper precautions after the first outbreak of fire around the jacket heater, there would have been no second outbreak which destroyed the building. The Principal, the Rev. A. Fraser, cannot be held entirely free from criticism and blame in the matter. It is considered the fire could have been extinguished if proper action had been followed when first found. The Department must attribute this disaster to carelessness and lack of responsibility on the part of the night watchman and the engineer. The Department could not approve of the re-appointment of either of these men to any of the other Indian residential schools under the auspices of your Commission.

The Principal will be allowed to occupy the principal's residence until approximately the end of June, next, as he should assist the local Agent with regard to the disposal of the supplies and equipment on hand. Instructions have been forwarded to Mr. Inspector Hamilton to arrange with your Commission for the distribution of all supplies, etc., remaining on the premises.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your 205-11 of the 4th instant, reporting on your investigation relating to the destruction by fire of the Mackay Indian Residential School. Your report and the report of the investigation made by the church authorities, the local Indian Agent and the Mounted Police have been considered. It would appear that the statements of the members of the staff vary from each other to a more or less extent. There was evident carelessness on the part of Mr. L. Fraser, the night watchman, and Mr. Wilson, the engineer, in not taking every precaution to see that the fire which first occurred was thoroughly extinguished.

Dear Sir:

It seems futile under present circumstances to urge upon the Department the extension of Indian Residential Schools, but there is an urgent requirement which it is my bounden duty to keep before your notice.

Since the loss by fire of the McKay School at The Pas, our Indians in the Hudson Bay area have pleaded for a school somewhere adjacent to the Hudson Bay Railway within the Diocese of Keewatin. Their nearest residential school is at Elkhorn 750 to 1000 miles away. A number of children from our Cree missions have been sent to Elkhorn, with the result that parents are unable to see their children for several years. On my visit to these people they begged that something be done to provide a school in their own area.

I am aware that the late Canon Gould, formerly secretary of M.S.C.C., had such a proposed school in his estimates for several years, and in his last report to the Board of Management M.S.C.C. he referred to the need as urgent.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee, M.S.C.C., held in Winnipeg last November, I was given authority to make personal appeal to the Department of Indian Affairs for such a school. I have refrained from pressing the matter because I am of the opinion that your Department may not on account of war conditions entertain any suggested extension of schools. In duty to my people, and being well advised of the need, I would plead that such a school, north of The Pas, within the Diocese of Keewatin, be given first consideration if, and when, the Department considers extension possible. I thus write at this time that the matter may be kept before your notice.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to refer again to your personal letter of October 10th and to my reply of the 21st.

Now that the authorized pupilage at Elkhorn has been reduced to 130 at our request we are experiencing continual difficulty through our inability to take children who are anxious to enter the school. After the report of Dr. Simes that the dormitories were overcrowded, we have been doing our best to restrict the attendance. Our Principal has been under continual pressure and even now the number is near 140. I have been in close contact with Inspector Hamilton and he has agreed with us that we should not receive any more pupils, so that we have been persuading various Anglican parents to send their children to Brandon, though they do this with reluctance as the children naturally prefer to be with their friends from the home reserve.

As I have heard from time to time that the Government is contemplating taking over the American Hospital north of The Pas, I beg to express again our Anglican desire for a residential school in the northern part of Manitoba in the hope that some of the present hospital buildings may be made available for this purpose. It is not only the fact that at the moment we have 60 children from the Northern part of the Province attending Elkhorn, and are being compelled to refuse admission to Southern children, but it is quite evident to us that some of the overcrowding at Prince Albert results from the lack of school facilities in Northern Manitoba. A number of the pupils now at Prince Albert could very readily go to The Pas if a school were established there.

I trust that the claim of our Church will be taken into consideration if the acquisition of the American Hospital is definitely concluded. The fact that since the loss of the Mackay School we have had only one Anglican institution in a province in which our Church has a larger number of Indian members than any other, and that we can now accommodate only 130 at Elkhorn against 355 for the United Church and 340 for the Roman Catholic is surely an evidence of real need. It is true that our request was for a number of years for a new school somewhere on the Hudson
Bay line between The Pas and Churchill. The Bishop of Keewatin has continually urged this need upon our Commission and believes that a school is urgently needed at Gillam or some point north of it. Certainly we have in that area a very large number of Indian members of our Church and they appear to have little educational opportunity. It is evident, however, that the hospital site north of The Pas has a most central location and could readily be reached by railway from the north.

Commending this matter to your usual kind attention,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Following out your kind suggestion I was able to visit the American Army Camp at Clearwater Lake last week in company with Dr. P.E. Moore and Mr. C. Buck. We thoroughly surveyed the buildings and examined some of them with special care to ascertain their construction. I have no doubt that the other gentlemen will be making their report as to the suitability of these buildings for residential school purposes, but I now beg to give you my personal conclusions.

Having in mind the splendid school erected at Carcross last year by the use of three large prefabricated buildings, I was clear about the possibility of repeating this method at Clearwater Lake. It would, of course, be regarded as something for a limited number of years only but I have no doubt that a school could be put into operation on this site with a minimum cost as compared with new construction. We found the buildings well-made and a number of them insulated. All would require to be protected in this way and probably some additional material on the exterior would make them warmer. The standard type has an inside measurement of $5\frac{1}{2}$' x $19\frac{3}{4}$' with ceiling a little less than $8$'. As to the suitability of such buildings for school purposes, I have already expressed my conviction that for Northern bush pupils there is positive advantage in housing them in simple surroundings not too far removed from their natural habitations. I selected a group of buildings which seemed to me to be most suitable for the purpose by reason of their location. They are situated on the main road entering the Camp and are as far away as possible, both from the Hospital and the Airfield. By moving some buildings across the road and connecting them with others I believe a workable institution could readily be obtained. This would allow us to work with only three or four units so that there would be as little need as possible of going out of doors when passing from one part of the school to another. I enclose a rough plan which suggests what I have in mind. This is, of course, purely tentative as I have not yet been able to work out the total floor space thus provided in comparison with other schools. I have had in mind a school of about 100 pupils and believe these could be easily accommodated.

Photograph attached.
Some of the Camp buildings are already splendidly equipped for institutional purposes and especially the dining rooms, kitchen and washrooms. The whole Camp offers many advantages as compared with a new site which might be chosen for school purposes. It is on a splendid gravelled road, running to the Pas 18 miles away, and is also on the railway with a spur line running within a short distance of the buildings. Electric light is laid on to the Camp and it is possible that the water supply might also be used and the Camp arrangements for sewage disposal. The question of heating the buildings would have to be faced. There are a number of Duo-Therm heaters in use in the Camp which burn fuel oil. This method might be costly and a central heating plan might have to be installed, but these are details which the experts of the Department would doubtless work out. A great amount of work has been done in constructing gravelled roads in the Camp and in levelling the ground. Immediately behind the buildings suggested there is a large area of level ground which would be quite suitable for recreational purposes. It seemed to me that the soil would readily lend itself to the purpose of a school garden. Other points in favour of the site seemed to me to be the proximity of medical and hospital care; the fuller social life for staff members by reason of the number of hospital employees; and the possible openings for graduate pupils as wardmaids in the hospital.

I was glad to have the opportunity of meeting both Indian Agent Lovell and Dr. Yule. I found both of them in favour of the general proposal and confident that a real need existed for an Anglican school of at least 100 in this area. Bearing in mind that the Mackay School has never been replaced and that 60 or more children from The Pas and north of it have continued to go to Elkhorn, I found general agreement that much of the feeling of unrest of both parents and children arose from the fact of taking children so far away from home. From missionary workers I received assurance that there would be no difficulty whatever in obtaining a large number of pupils, as in several areas there are numbers of children without school facilities at the present time.

After hearing my report our Commission on April 10th went on record as warmly endorsing the proposal and I am directed to request that the Indian Affairs Branch will take over a sufficient number of these buildings to enable a workable institution to be put in operation in the near future.

I shall await your further word with interest and meanwhile, remain,

Yours sincerely,

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON THE PAS INDIAN AGENCY

Educational

The day schools are making as much progress as they have ever done. On most of the Northern Reserves the Day Schools are not an outstanding success. This is due to the fact that it is impossible to get regular attendance. The Indians, who get their living by hunting, fishing and trapping, do not live in large groups, but rather in small groups and communities where they think the hunting, trapping and fishing is good. The day schools are generally situated where the main group live and where the trading post and Church are. It is only the comparatively small number of children who live at the main settlement all the year round can possibly attend the school regularly.

After the children have been away from school five or six months, speaking nothing but Cree, it is practically the same as making a complete new start every time they come back to School. It is little wonder therefore that few progress very far.

The only solution I see, is for the children of the northern reserves, where the parents engage in hunting and trapping, be sent to a boarding school.

The new Anglican Boarding School, the Department proposes establishing north of the Pas in the buildings now used by the U.S. forces, will fill a much needed want. I trust the Department will get it into operation as soon as possible.

Samuel Lovell,

Dear Sir:

If I may first introduce myself:
I have been a missionary to the Indians about The Pas, Man., for the past 20 years, have taught in four Indian day schools, and was a frequent visitor at the residential school at The Pas (the Mackay School) before its destruction by fire in 1933.

It happened that I had an opportunity 3 days ago to visit the American army air post near The Pas, where, I understand, you have plans to take over the hospital building for an Indian sanatorium and other buildings for a residential school.

May I thank you first, on behalf of all of us who have the Indians' welfare at heart, for the promise of the sanatorium, so very tragically needed.

But I have for years been a determined opponent of the residential schools. I have shared the opinion of scores of my fellow missionaries, of traders, of Indian Agents, and others who are in contact with Indians, that the boarding school Indian is a spoiled Indian. And now I have changed my ideas; at least, I see a wonderful opportunity for you and for the Indians.

My two principal objections to the residential schools were, (1) that they bring the child up in surroundings and atmosphere so utterly different from the simple Indian dwelling that he cannot apply to his own home the techniques of living that he learned at school; and (2) that in too many cases the trades he learns in the far-off school he has no slightest opportunity to practice on his return to the Reserve... e.g. our children from this bush country have been going to Elkhorn and learning tractor-farming. There never will be tractor-farming on these northern reserves: the land is all wrong for it.

But now you have a different situation. You have at present to your hand a group of small buildings, at least comparable in size to the Indians' homes, and they are in surroundings like those of the northern reserves.

I venture to suggest, then, that you do not spoil these two admirable features by bringing the little buildings together under one roof, and laying out the land to field crops; but rather that you aim to demonstrate and teach right there what a northern reserve could and should be like.

Concretely, I suggest that 15 to 20 children be housed in each separate building, which would be their home, under a member of the staff, who would be house-mother and also live there. The class rooms would become day-schools, and when the day's work was done there the children would go "home" just as on the Reserves, away from the atmosphere of chalk and geometry. As far as possible each household would consist of children from the same reserve, so that they would be among friends and the newcomer would not be afraid.
Each house would have its home-size garden, tended by its own family, who would there learn something of the quantities of seed a normal family would require instead of how many bushels of potatoes to the acre.

Inside each house the older girls would have a share in the decorating, choosing colors, making curtains, studying different kinds of floor coverings, all on a set budget per house per year... the houses are uniform to start with.

The boys would learn to make small improvements, fences, garden walks, pantry shelves, etc., and one house might keep chickens, another pigs, and a third goats, or cows, the produce of each establishment being pooled and a fair price credited to that house for improvements.

In short, the whole place would be a model community, or junior reserve. Chief and councillors should be chosen among the children to introduce them to the processes of democratic government (which is an alien thing to the Cree), and would have powers similar to those of a student council in a city school, under the guidance of the principal or his deputy.

Trophies, in the form of flags to be displayed on a staff in the front garden, would be awarded to the best-kept house and perhaps the best-kept garden; and in general a spirit of friendly rivalry between the houses should be fostered.

And when the children returned at last to their own reserves, they would be able to practice all the skills they learned at school: the girls would be able to accumulate, little by little, the same simple equipment they had in their school home; and the boys would be able to garden in the way they had there, instead of coming down from diesel tractors to grub-hoes.

Another point: this site is on the shore of Clearwater Lake ("Atikameg Lake" on the maps) which is fairly well stocked with fish. I believe that commercial fishing has been closed on this lake for two seasons past, or very strictly limited in quantity. It might be possible to arrange with the Province of Manitoba for net fishing to be allowed only to the school, for its own use. (Since there are two small summer resorts on the lake, angling would probably have to be allowed the summer visitors).

I hope very much that these suggestions will not reach you too late. I believe you have here an opportunity to change the residential schools from a positive evil, such as they appear to many of us to be now, into a wonderfully helpful device towards the education of the Indians in the art of living a healthy, happy and self-supporting rural life.

If anything in the above is not clear, please feel free, should you so desire, to refer it back to me, and

Believe me, yours for Indian welfare,

[Signature]

I am writing in similar terms to Dr Alderwood in Winnipeg, and to the field secretary of our missionary society at 604 Jarvis St., Toronto.

Dear Mr. Allan,

When you were up here last fall the Indians and the halfbreeds talked to you about a proposed "improved day school" to accommodate the Indian and halfbreed children of the district. They pointed out that the educational facilities are inadequate here to properly take care of the native children. The drawbacks of sending their children out to mission schools etc., were pointed out.

The suggestion was, and still is, that the Department of Indian Affairs, in cooperation with the Manitoba Department of Education, build an up-to-date school to house the children of Big Eddy, some from The Pas, and the Indian Reserve. This school, it is suggested, should be of the "consolidated" type, providing transportation and lunches at noon.

At the present time there are approximately 45 Indian children in Elkhorn, and the parents are not satisfied with the arrangements. There are about the same number here at home, which is more than the present school can accommodate.

I understand from the Department of Education that arrangements had been made to use the present school for this type of operation, but there are too many children.

The number of children should never be an excuse for failing to provide educational facilities. In fact, a large number of children in one place should be enough in itself to guarantee the provision of more modern and adequate educational services.

The only answer it seems is the building of a school jointly by the two departments concerned. I am sending a copy of this letter to the provincial department, sincerely hoping that you will reopen your negotiations with respect to the education of these children.

Yours very truly,

H.R. Richards.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: PROPOSED SCHOOL, The Pas area, Manitoba

I regret that so long a time has elapsed since the receipt of your letter Reference 128-1-1, of May 18th. I had to leave the city shortly after it came to hand and have since been absent from the office or greatly burdened by reason of lack of help.

I now beg to refer to our previous correspondence and to my detailed report after visiting the American Army buildings at Clear Water Lake in company with Dr. Moore. This matter has also been placed before the Missionary Society of our Church and I am now able to make a definite request.

(1) It is our conviction that a residential school for Anglican Indians has really been needed in The Pas area ever since the MacKay School was destroyed by fire twelve years ago. We have been caring for as many as 60 children at Elkhorn who came from The Pas and points further north. This has always been considered an unsatisfactory arrangement and has caused much discontent both among parents and children. We believe firmly that wherever possible all of our pupils should return home for the summer months but the cost of transportation between Elkhorn and these northern points is exceedingly high. Furthermore, we have just been asked if we can increase the number of pupils from the Pas area for the coming school year, as the payment of family allowances in the area will provide far more pupils than the Day Schools in the area will be able to handle. Missionaries of our Church in this northern area have asserted that many children will be served by the proposed school who are without educational facilities at the present time.

(2) The Clear Water Lake site appears to us to be eminently suitable for such a school. It is directly linked with the railway and has a good road to The Pas. The large lake and the heavy bush around suggest healthy living conditions and the fact that hospital and full medical care are available gives the site an enormous advantage over anything else that might be suggested in the area. The opportunity of having electric light, the possibility of having a supply of tested water and the many advantages accruing from the presence of the hospital staff, all make the site desirable. The buildings will require to be improved and made warmer for winter conditions, and at first sight did not appear to be very suitable for the purpose. However, I am glad to have had my conviction of their suitability reinforced by the verdict of such an experienced Indian missionary as the Rev. R.B.Horsefield.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6267, file 580-1, part 3)
After visiting the camp he became very enthusiastic as to the possibilities for establishing a residential school of a new kind. In brief, he would aim to retain something of the simplicity in which many of these children have lived. He would endeavour to keep children drawn from the different reserves together, so that instead of a large institution under one roof there would be a number of large families doing a great deal of their own work, and providing their own recreation and other activities. It has been my own conclusion that a large modern building is not really suitable for our purpose in northern areas, and that a school should consist of a number of smaller buildings, preferably of log construction, so that our children might feel at home and receive training of a type suited to the life they will probably lead. Mr. Horsefield's plan might be a little idealistic but I believe it offers a valuable suggestion. My conclusion, when visiting the camp, was that a number of the buildings should be moved a short distance and connected up and that this would greatly reduce the work of the staff.

We, therefore, urge that the Department take over a sufficient number of these camp buildings to provide accommodation for 125 or 150 pupils. From a comparison with other schools we believe that a fair per capita grant would be $170.00. It would be our aim to follow the Manitoba Provincial curriculum as far as possible, especially stressing English, simple Arithmetic and such studies as tend towards intelligent citizenship. We believe that the group system suggested would increase the possibilities of giving real training in gardening and that the environment would make it possible for the boys to acquire skill in fishing and trapping while at the school. We understand that the R.C.A.F. intend to maintain a small staff at the Airport, and it occurs to us that from their personnel we might be able to secure help in giving the boys that simple mechanical training which is demanded by modern needs. The Sanatorium already established has been asking for Indian girls as helpers, and we believe the school might find an outlet for many of its graduates in this institution.

I trust that this matter may soon be brought to a conclusion and that we may be enabled to plan for something different in education for northern Indian children on the site suggested.

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM:

MR. HOEK.

Re: Survey of Air Force Buildings at The Pas Airport.

In conformity with instructions received on August 2nd from Mr. Phelan, I proceeded, at the close of the summer course at Lebret, to Winnipeg to meet Inspector Hamilton and Reverend Dr. Alderwood. Dr. Alderwood explained what he had in mind in reference to the buildings at The Pas Airport. I then proceeded to The Pas in order to check over the buildings in question and endeavour to decide the feasibility of utilizing some of these buildings for a Residential school. As a result of this survey, I wish to submit the following:

BUILDINGS:

1. With the exception of the washroom and mess hall these buildings are all 52 ft. long x 20 ft. wide. Natural lighting is from both sides. The ceilings are approximately 8 ft. high.

2. These buildings have not been completed according to specifications. None of those which could be taken over are insulated. There is but one row of sheeting at the outside composed of tongue and groove lumber. This sheeting is covered with heavy paper. The inside of the buildings are not sheeted. A one-half inch wallboard (somewhat similar to Ten-Test) is nailed to the studding. This finish, of course would be unsatisfactory for children. A slight blow would break through the sheeting - in fact, it is already broken in, in several places although most of the buildings have not been occupied.

3. The proposal was to move one of these buildings between two others in order to join them into one unit. The accompanying sketch will indicate what Dr. Alderwood had in mind. This, I believe, would be impractical and for the following reasons:

(a) They are of a very weak construction, there being no bracing. They would have to be thoroughly braced before attempting to move them.

(b) The buildings are not evenly spaced, hence a building will not join these unless considerable alterations are made. As stated above, the buildings are 52 ft. long and the space between the buildings vary from 49 ft. 10 inches to 82 ft. 8 inches.

4. These buildings would be very difficult to heat. At present they have two oil heaters in each - one at each end. Each unit (three buildings reunited) would require at least five heaters. It would, therefore, be a question of approximately two dozen heaters to supply sufficient heat to make these units comfortable. This would prove very expensive and moreover would multiply the fire hazards.
5. It is obvious that the suggested arrangement would make supervision and administration very difficult. I doubt that any personnel would stick to a job that would require such supervision any length of time. It would also require more personnel to adequately supervise this set-up and would, therefore, prove very uneconomical.

6. These buildings are not in any way connected to water supply. This might be done but would prove rather expensive as the water tank is approximately 500 yards away. Moreover, as these buildings have no foundations, continuous trouble by freezing would be experienced if the water piping were joined to them. It would, therefore, entail the problem of hauling water to the various units.

7. The lavatories are of the chemical type. It is doubtful if this system would prove satisfactory for a boarding school. It must be remembered that these installations were intended as a temporary arrangement. These toilets, moreover, are in a separate building. Two of these buildings are provided in the proposed section, but one is on the wrong side of the road. Children using these would have to cross the main road. To move it would mean a new installation. Toilets would have to be installed in the dormitories.

8. I believe, that it would take approximately $20,000.00 to bring about the changes necessary. This would include repair of the buildings, inside and outside, the moving of some buildings, the installation of water, preparing quarters for the personnel. This would not include a residence for the Principal. And in the end, what would we have?

LOCATION:

This area is an ideal place for a school. Medical care would be available. A certain amount of social life would be possible for the personnel of the hospital as well as for the personnel of the school. There is an adequate water supply and good means of transportation. Electrical power would be plentiful. A good deal of the material might be used in the erection of a school, although, I doubt whether the use of this material would be really economical. The time and labour it would take to tear down these buildings, salvage the materials, would really wipe out any savings that would be accomplished.

TYPE OF BUILDING:

Much may be said in favour of smaller building units for Residential Schools such as special dormitories, special classrooms. However, in our present set-up such an organization would give rise to many difficulties:

1. Supervision would be rather difficult.
2. Such supervision would necessarily have to be by trained personnel in this particular kind of work.
3. The heating proposition would add a number of difficulties.
4. The number of personnel would have to be greatly increased.
5. The Per Capita Grants available would be inadequate to take care of the extra cost. It is obvious that in a great number of cases the present grant does not permit the obtaining of properly trained teachers and instructors, for the kind of education that our Residential Schools should be giving. Such a small group of buildings should be especially designed for this kind of work in order to be effective.
I do not think that the buildings at The Pas would lend themselves efficiently to smaller grouping. The up-keep of these buildings would, I believe, be very expensive.

It may be contended that the school buildings in Residential Schools are not conducive to the development of Indians. It will never be possible to bring the school to the level of Indian life. In my opinion, it is not so much the buildings that will affect the Indian as the kind of training that will be given in these schools. A great deal of the criticism of our Indian education in Residential Schools may be traced to the unpreparedness of the personnel to carry out the important work of Indian education. No matter what kind of schools we may have the training results will be in proportion to the quality of the educator.

EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES OF THE PAS AGENCY:

The 1939 Census tells us that the population of this Agency is 2478 for the Manitoba section and 1194 for Saskatchewan, a total then of 3672. It is generally accepted that about 25% of the population is composed of children of school age. This means that the student population would be about 900. There are nine day schools with an enrolment of 245, 3 combined schools with an enrolment of 36 and one Roman Catholic Residential School with an enrolment of 113. This means that the schools could accommodate about 400 children. It is readily seen that more educational facilities are necessary. A part of the population of this Reserve are nomadic, being hunters. Apparently to provide education for these children the Residential School is the answer. It must be kept in mind, however, that the school must adopt itself to the necessities of the child and the community.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

K.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Ottawa, August 28th, 1945.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of July 28 to me about the education of the Indian children in conjunction with the Halfbreeds in the area is entirely unsatisfactory.

I have been told by the Department of Education of the province of Manitoba that talks have been held about this proposal, and a lot of progress has been made. Now you dismiss it with a reference to the post war program. This is not a post war program. Don't we need a war and then a post war to ensure that Canadian citizens receive decent educational facilities?

I insist that this matter be referred to the minister, and that it not be waived because of not having made "an appropriation." I am not so naive as to believe that it is necessary for the government of Canada to make an appropriation for a school on the Indian Reserve in The Pas before one can be built.

Please let us have some definite commitment on this matter. It is urgent.

Yours very truly,

B.R. Richards, MLA The Pas.
Ottawa, September 8, 1945.

Dear Sir:

I enclose, for your information, copies of two letters received from Mr. E. R. Richards, M.L.A. These letters explain themselves.

It occurred to me that it might be possible to have one of the provincial school inspectors make a survey of the educational requirements in the district mentioned in Mr. Richards' letters. Such a survey would show whether it is practicable to operate a combined school by the Federal and Provincial Governments or whether each of these Governments should erect its own school.

I would also like to have some idea of the expenditure that would be involved in providing for the building and its subsequent operation. We have no specific appropriation available at the present time, and if it was decided to proceed, we would have to prepare a supplementary estimate for the consideration of Parliament.

A certain amount of social life would be possible for the personnel of the hospital as well as for the personnel of the school. There is an adequate water supply and good means of transportation. Electrical power would be plentiful. A good deal of the material might be used in the erection of a school, although, I doubt whether the use of this material would be really economical. The time and labour it would take to tear down these buildings, salvage the materials, would really wipe out any savings that would be accomplished.

TYPE OF BUILDINGS:

Much may be said in favour of smaller building units for Residential Schools such as special dormitories, special classrooms. However, in our present set-up such an organization would give rise to many difficulties:

1. Supervision would be rather difficult.
2. Such supervision would necessarily have to be by trained personnel in this particular kind of work.
3. The heating proposition would add a number of difficulties.
4. The number of personnel would have to be greatly increased.
5. The Per Capita Grants available would be inadequate to take care of the extra cost. It is obvious that in a great number of cases the present grant does not permit the obtaining of properly trained teachers and instructors, for the kind of education that our Residential Schools should be giving. Such a small group of buildings should be especially designed for this kind of work in order to be effective.

I do not think that the buildings at The Pas would lend themselves efficiently to smaller grouping. The upkeep of these buildings would, I believe, be very expensive.
It may be contended that the school buildings in Residential Schools are not conducive to the development of Indians. It will never be possible to bring the school to the level of Indian life. In my opinion, it is not so much the buildings that will affect the Indian as the kind of training that will be given in these schools. A great deal of the criticism of our Indian education in Residential Schools may be traced to the unpreparedness of the personnel to carry out the important work of Indian education. No matter what kind of schools we may have the training results will be in proportion to the quality of the educator.

EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES OF THE PAS AGENCY:

The 1939 Census tells us that the population of this Agency is, 2478 for the Manitoba section and 1194 for Saskatchewan, a total then of 3672. It is generally accepted that about 25% of the population is composed of children of school age. This means that the student population would be about 900. There are nine day schools with an enrolment of 245, 3 combined schools with an enrolment of 36 and one Roman Catholic Residential School with an enrolment of 113. This means that the schools could accommodate about 400 children. It is readily seen that more educational facilities are necessary. A part of the population of this Reserve are nomadic, being hunters. Apparently to provide education for these children the Residential School is the answer. It must be kept in mind, however, that the school must adopt itself to the necessities of the child and the community.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Ottawa, August 28th, 1945.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Proposed School for the Pas Area.

Your letter—reference 128-1-1—of September 17th has been given careful consideration by our Commission. The report of Mr. A. J. Boucet has received our close attention and we note the objections to the use of the present camp buildings and the estimate of the high cost of putting them in fit state for school use. We are prepared to agree with Mr. Boucet's conclusion in view of the careful examination he has made as to the construction of the buildings and the fuller information he was able to obtain in regard to the possibility of water and heating systems. When the writer visited the camp the weather was too cold to permit this kind of survey and the points raised by Mr. Boucet could not be settled.

I am glad, however, to note that the report fully agrees that additional educational facilities are needed in Northern Manitoba and that your representative declares the location to be ideal for a residential school. In view of the fact that the Mackay school has never been replaced and that we are assured there are a large number of Anglican children in the district whose parents are still nomadic, I am authorized by our Commission and by the Executive Committee of our Missionary Society to urge that provision be made for the erection of a new school on this site.

We believe that much use can be made of some of the existing buildings and that the work already done in preparing the site would make it possible to provide a school for approximately 125 children at a very reasonable cost. May I refer to the plan suggested for Wabasca as a basis for discussion? It was suggested that there should be a large central building with several smaller units. The main building would have a full basement of cement and stone, a complete first floor using local logs for walls, and an attic for certain staff and storage purposes. One heating plant would suffice for this building and fire risk thus be reduced to a
minimum. This plan was for 50 pupils only but additional dormitory accommodation could be provided at The Pas by using one of the excellent mess halls for kitchen and dining-room purposes. Some of the other camp buildings could certainly be used for storage, workshop, and recreational purposes. The estimate we received from a reliable lumber company in Edmonton for the Wabasca building was $15,000 including materials, labor, freighting by team over the 100 mile bush trail from Slave Lake and a lighting plant. Costs would be considerably lower at The Pas and I believe that $20,000 should go a long way to provide this type of building.

May I, therefore, express the hope that the conclusion of the Department that the proposed conversion of the camp buildings is inadvisable may not set aside the positive advantages of the site, and that further consideration be given to the matter along the lines outlined above.

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood

In some way which I cannot explain, this letter was not acknowledged, but was sent forward to our Inspector at The Pas, Mr. Scott Bateman, who is Official Trustee of the Big Eddy School District and who has been making a study of the problem of Indian and Half-Breed education in this and other similar districts. This letter was just returned to me this week.

Mr. Bateman has now completed the survey of these districts and he estimates that it would cost about $4,200.00 to repair and enlarge the Indian School at Big Eddy to enable it to take care of both Indian and Half-Breed children. I understand that there has been some correspondence between our Ministers on this subject, but that any specific action here has been held up pending some agreement on the old problem of Indian and Half-Breed education in the Northern part of this Province.

Dear Doctor MacFarlane:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 2nd, in which you refer to a letter dated September 8, 1945, sent forward by me to your department.

I must, in fairness, state that the delay in replying to this communication has not proved at all embarrassing. As a matter of fact, we were not in a position until now to secure the funds necessary for the remodelling of the Big Eddy Indian Day School. I have, however, following an interview with Mr. Dryden yesterday, asked the officials of the Welfare and Training Division to put in the estimates of next year, which are now in course of preparation, the sum of $500.00 for the construction of an additional class-room in the Big Eddy School. This work will be undertaken on the understanding that the school will be operated jointly by the Indian Affairs Branch and your department. Mr. Dryden suggested that the school might be operated effectively under the supervision of a local advisory board made up of the public school inspectors for the district, the Indian Agent and the missionary in the district. This is a matter, however, to which we can give additional thought during the months immediately ahead of us.

This arrangement is largely experimental. It is my earnest hope that it will prove a success. There are a number of districts in the northern sections of the three prairie provinces where it will be necessary to operate the schools jointly, and there is no valid reason in my mind why such schools should not be operated efficiently and economically, and to the satisfaction of all parties concerned. There are questions relating to the operation of such schools, however, which we should keep in mind, such as the right of the provincial authorities to compel the attendance of Indians at such schools, and the right of the Dominion to insist upon attendance in the case of white or half-breed children. My own feeling is...
own feeling is that all these matters should be adjusted by mutual consent. This will be comparatively easy if we keep the educational needs of the Indians and of the half-breeds and their general advancement constantly to the forefront.

I have the honor to report that the Principal of the McKay Boarding School, The Pas, has asked if the Department will supply the following items:

1. 1 ironing stove, 4' long and 2'6" high, made by Adam Hall, Peterborough, Ontario, as the old one is burnt out.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, regarding the request of the Principal of the MacKay Indian Residential School to be supplied with an ironing stove, lumber for the installing of a combination seat and locker in the boys' playroom, 200' - 1/2" hose and 65 mattresses.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of an ironing stove of the dimensions required, also for the supplying of sufficient lumber to build a combination seat and locker in the boys' playroom. The Department will also approve of the supplying of 200' of fire hose, 1/2" in diameter, with the necessary couplings, if required. The stove of the dimensions required may be purchased from the manufacturer. The lumber and fire hose may be purchased locally, competitive prices, if possible, being obtained. When the above supplies have been received, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Regarding the mattresses, I have to request that you will state whether it would not be possible for the school authorities to purchase the quantity required from the per capita grant or other revenue of the school. Our funds for the present fiscal year are limited, and we are unable to provide the expenditure required for the purpose.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that I visited the Mackay Boarding School on the 28th inst., in company with the Medical Officer.

The health of the pupils was fair, some of them have been suffering from the whooping cough lately, but it seems to be about over now. The pupils were warmly clad, well fed and tidy. The food they get at present consists mainly of fresh fish, moose meat, beef, plenty of fresh vegetables, milk and porridge.

In the class rooms there is a big change since the elder children were transferred to Elkhorn. The ones in the two primary grades far outnumber those in higher grades, and this overcrowds the junior classroom, but this situation will right itself after Easter holidays.

The staff has been undermanned for past month, due to the resignation of the teacher in the senior classroom; this lady and her husband have taken up farm, and left the school before a new teacher could be arranged for. The matron in the kitchen also left this month on account of sickness in her family at home. The present staff are helped out by Mrs Bird, the wife of the Principal, and have got along very well. A new Senior teacher, Junior teacher, and kitchen Matron will start work after Easter. The present Junior teacher is taking up duties at the Big Eddy Day School at that time.

The appearance of the school outside is fairly shabby, I hope the estimates are large enough to allow us to get the place painted. If this is allowed it will be necessary to have this office supplied with specifications of the class of paint to be used, as the local painters will use gasoline to thin the paint every time if they are not held down with specifications.

The Principal asks for the sum of $120.00 to be spent on paint for some inside work, such as boys wash room, hospital rooms etc.; he will have the work done by the staff. I think this should be allowed.

I am, Sir,

36" and 40" Diameter

Size
The inner cylinder shall be inches in diameter by inches in length and shall have doors and partitions, hinges, catches and hoops, geared.

Cylinder
Shall have heads and staves of Fir, with ribs of Maple. Staves cut from 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inch stock shall be nailed to heads cut from 2-inch stock. Shall be three large lifting ribs, 2\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inches thick by 4 inches deep also a 2\(\frac{1}{2}\) x 2\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch rib at front and back of door opening rabbeded to receive door. Door shall be 15\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches wide. Door battens shall be of brass. Hinges shall be wide and heavy, and shall rest on bottom of door opening and on brass plates on front door rib. Catches shall have wide lips. Cylinders shall be banded with wide and heavy hoops, fastened to the staves by means of brass screws.

Tub
Shall be constructed of Fir, with staves cut from 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inch stock tongued and grooved and gained to fit over heads cut from 2-inch stock, to which they shall be nailed. A galvanized iron sliding door shall operate in grooves provided on adjustable encircling bands or hoops. Brass apron shall be fitted at bottom of door opening to protect the staves.

Iron Frames
The entire weight of cylinder and tub shall rest on cast-iron frames of neat design, to which the driving mechanism shall be attached. Frames shall be solid one-piece castings, and be bolted to tub heads.

Inlet and Outlet
Located in the center bottom of tub shall be a combination cast-iron flange tee, through which the steam and water shall enter and waste water be discharged. Steam shall enter washer through an annular steam passage cored in the tee without coming in direct contact with the wood or linen. Connected with the flange tee shall be an outlet pipe, on the end of which a 3-inch quick opening valve of the hollow taper plug type shall be fitted.

Trunnions and Bearings
Cast-iron trunnions shall be attached to cylinder heads by means of brass-covered bolts and inside of cylinder heads shall be fitted with two brass trunnion rings. The journals of trunnions shall operate in babbitted bearings on the cast-iron frames.

I discussed this matter with the Principal and he is of the opinion that it would cost too much to put the hospital in shape to use as a warehouse, the roofing is gone, and the walls are stripped of the outer covering of paper.

In place of the repairs and painting he asks that $600.00 be spent in putting up a new warehouse, he has had estimates of the material which will come to about this sum, and the work would be done by the staff of the school.

I still am of the opinion that the school should be painted immediately, as it is in bad shape, but the school authorities have a new system of putting in their supplies in lots to last a year and it is imperative that these supplies be looked after; at present there is no storehouse.

This still leaves the old hospital building to be considered. As I have mentioned before the place is a ruin and an eyesore, the roofing is blown off and the wall covering is going, the only good material in it is a good cellar wall, and the hardwood floors, with doors etc. Even the floors are going rotten now as the roof leaks everyplace.

The whole question hinges now on whether the Department wishes to protect their own property, the school building, or whether the supplies are the most important. If the funds were sufficient both matters should be attended to.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the plumbing recently done at the Mackay Boarding School:

The Agent at The Pas allowed me to read a letter, in which it appears, that the need of the new plumbing fixtures was due to the negligence of the Principal or of the Staff, apparently a wrong impression has been given to the Department, and I beg to supply the following particulars:

With reference to the closet basins, these were corroded so that there was only a small passage for the matter to pass through. This corrosion was caused by the action of the acid in the urine and the very hard water, and first of all takes place in the trap, showing a brown, and as years pass by this stain thickens and eventually prevents proper flushing, and becomes as hard as the porcelain itself, is inside the trap and cannot be prevented, chemicals such as Sani-Flush may be used to lengthen the life of the basin but after some years service fails to have any great effect, and then the basins have to be renewed, as in the case here, many such cases are found daily in the cities where the water is not so hard.

According to the Engineer, the Agent knew that we often had to use plungers two or three years ago, as these cleared the basins for the time, it was considered satisfactory, but owing to the dormitories having to be turned into isolation wards during the recent epidemic of Measles, and the basins being in constant use during the day, the plungers were not enough to keep the closets basins clear.

With reference to the down-pipes being blocked, this is wrong, there was a certain amount of matter attached to the side of the down pipe, but there was a passage through the pipe, and this matter was quickly cleared with a proper cleaning brush.

There would have been nothing attached to the inside of the down pipe if the basins had flushed properly, as the matter in the basins only ran away slowly instead of with a rapid flush, this would allow the sediment to adhere to the side of the pipe.

I served five years at the practical side of plumbing, and passed most of the theoretical work for Sanitary Engineer ere leaving for this country many years ago, so feel that I know something about the plumbing.

The only solution that I can arrive at, (and the plumber is of the same opinion) that to avoid having to replace so many basins at a time, is when one shows signs of becoming corroded.
to have it replaced.

The W.C. Basins that were taken out had been in use for seven years, and the corrosion was so hard that one could not operate it from the trap when the trap was broken open to inspect it.

I would like to add that both the Matron daily see that all closets are in proper order, and if any of the staff find one in bad order it is at once reported to me.

Trusting that the above explanation is satisfactory and proves that it was not due to negligence on the part of any member of the school,

I remain Yours faithfully

EXPLANATORY NOTES ON REQUIREMENTS.

XII. MACKAY (THE PAS.)
(a) LAUNDRY
(b) ENLARGEMENT OF PIGGERY
(c) ENLARGEMENT OF POULTRY HOUSE
(d) INSTALLATION OF TELEPHONE

(a) With a School of 80 children and a large staff, the obsolete laundry system now in use makes it quite impossible to keep the clothing as clean as it should be to assist in maintaining healthy conditions.

(b) & (c) With regard to (b) and (c) it may be stated that small buildings do exist, but neither are sufficiently commodious for the purpose for which it exists.

(d) The Society through its staff at the School will be prepared to provide the telephone poles, if the Department will procure the wire and instruments and make a grant of about $100, to assist in placing the poles in position. The distance from The Pas will be from 5 to 6 miles.

XIV. SHINGWAUK HOME
(a) COMPLETION OF REPAIRS TO THE DRILL HALL.
(b) BAKERY

(a) The Department very kindly made a grant for repairs to the roof of this building, and these have already been completed. The interior of the building however requires a great deal of attention, particularly the two floors, both of which will have to be very largely renewed. It is requested that a sum of not less than $700 be included in the estimates for 1925 for this purpose.

(b) The necessity for the Bakery is well known to the Superintendent of Indian Education.

XV. CHARLEAU.
(a) IMPLEMENT SHED ETC.
(b) COMPLETION OF STOCK-BARN WITH SILO ATTACHED

(a) Implement Shed. No building suitable for this purpose exists at present and in consequence proper care can not be taken of machinery and implements.

(b) Completion of stock-barn and building of silo. The barn was never completed, an addition of some 2 or 3 feet having to be made to the height of the walls. For this reason only temporary roof was supplied and this leaking as it does, cannot but injure the whole of the interior. The building of the silo which is a great necessity, may best be done at the time when the barn is being completed.

Dear Sir:

At different times in the past I have directed the attention of your Department to the dilapidated condition of the hospital building at the Mackay School at The Pas, and have recommended that some action should be taken to rescue from complete ruin some of the very good building material and equipment, such as the hardwood floors, doors, etc. At the time of my last visit I gave further consideration to this matter and came to the conclusion that prompt action was really more imperative than ever, and that as the main school building contains no provision whatever in the way of a recreation room for the girls, your Department would be well advised to utilize the material contained in the hospital building in making a large room for this purpose. I enclose for your information a rough sketch of the basement of the hospital, and another of the ground floor. As the ground floor, if the isolation wards, kitchen, etc., were eliminated, would be sufficient for the recreation room which could also be used as a drill hall, auditorium, etc., the basement, seeing that it has already two furnaces, might very well be adapted for a root cellar.

This school stands urgently in need of modern laundry equipment, but as this could be accommodated in the main school building I am not of the opinion that it would be advisable to adapt any part of the hospital building for this purpose, chiefly for the reason that as it is situated about 75 yards away from the main school building it would be inconvenient.

As your Department has recently very kindly provided this school with an electric lighting system, and a new store-room, I was instructed by our Commission to convey to you an expression of their appreciation of the real benefit you have conferred on this institution in the above action, and to express
express the hope that you may be able in the near future not only to furnish the laundry equipment, but to take action in connection with the hospital building along the lines suggested above.

Sir,

In further reference to my telegram of the 12th inst and your reply of same date, regards fire at the Mackay Boarding School, which destroyed the pump house, I beg to report as follows:

The fire started when the staff of the school were at church on Jan 11th, and flames were seen coming from the pump house when the church service was over. The fire had got such a start that it was practically impossible to save anything. Two members of the staff had been in the building at 9 A.M., at which time everything appeared to be alright. It is thought that the fire started in the chimney.

The building was composed of a pump house 18' X 21' attached to the store house and Work shop 16' X 43', the whole place was destroyed. Contents were as follows:
- 6 H.P. Fairbanks Engine.
- Hoosier deep well pump and jack.
- Curtis #163 single cylinder double wheel air compressor with check valve and stop cock.
- All necessary belting and pipes to connect above.
- Two stoves and pipes.
- Pressure gauge.
- Electric light fittings.

All the above should be replaced immediately and on instructions received in your telegram I have already started to get the lumber delivered for the pump house. I will have the carpenters on the job to-morrow I expect.

The matter of construction of the 16' X 43' store house and work shop can be left over for the present. I have had the plumber at the school for past three days and expect he will get things in shape to supply water to the building to-day, he has patched up the pump and put in an old engine to do until we get the new machinery. The fire took the life out of the machinery, it is just junk now, and we are in doubt if the old pump will stand up for the time being.

There was also lost all the supplies used in trading with the Indians for fish etc. Value 100.00
Moccasins $400.00. Private tools $200.00
Farm utensils and harness $200.00. TOTAL $900.00
And old time printing press.

I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant

Indian Agent

Dear Sir;

I very much regret to have to report to you that the Engine House at the Mackay Boarding School, The Pas, Manitoba, was destroyed by fire on the morning of the 11th inst.

The Principal immediately informed me of this misfortune by telegram which read as follows -

"Engine House and Store burned down. Letter following. All safe."

As I thought it well to await the receipt of his letter, this will explain the delay in forwarding this information to you.

In reporting on the fire, the Principal states as follows:

"As we were coming from church this morning we observed smoke coming from the roof of the Engine House. On arrival there I rushed in but was glad to close the door again, as the inside was such a mass of flame as to be a veritable inferno. We managed to get only a few tools out before it became too hot to get more.

As the flames did not touch the printing house for a while, I was able to get out practically all the type, but in three quarters of an hour only half the walls were standing, and these were soon burned up."
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

"I sent Mr. Turner to town at 2 o'clock to notify the Agent.

A new Pump and Engine will have to be installed.

Mr. Turner and Mr. Grant were in the Engine House at 9.30 A.M., and everything was all right then. So far as we are able to tell the fire started at the bottom of the chimney where the bricks rested on the wooden support underneath.

A large stock of moccasins, tools supplies etc. were completely destroyed.

I am taking the liberty of purchasing a small galvanized Water Tank for melting ice by the kitchen fire until the water supply can be restored again."

While deeply regretting this misfortune, I am unable to detect any culpable negligence, either on the part of the Principal or the Engineer. They are both very reliable men and have the complete confidence of our Society.

As Mr. Waddy, your representative in that part kindly informed me of the action taken by him towards having the water system and the Engine House restored, it does not seem necessary for me to make any further statement in connection with this matter, except that, I trust that these may be affected with the least possible delay.

Believe me Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of letter 128-15 of the 12th inst regards Mackay School.

The principal work required is instalment of up to date laundry equipment. The present arrangements are entirely hand work. I do not know the cost of this machinery; a whole outfit is required if anything is done. A new laundry is not needed in my opinion, the present place appears suitable.

It would be well if the pig pen was made larger, and a hen house built on to it. This would leave the present hen house to be used as a carpenter shop and move the poultry further away from the school, it is too close now. I will advise of the probable cost after I measure up this place.

A plan of the old hospital building is being sent to the Department to-day, I would be obliged if it is returned to me later on. To make this place of use as a school room, with a large play room, the following is necessary.

Cover roof with shingles.
Paint whole place two coats, roof one coat.
Remove verandah to allow light into the room used as school room.
Remove all partitions downstairs.
Install partition down centre of place with large sliding doors.
Paint inside walls two coats light color paint.
Repair floors which have bulged with moisture.
Cut off stairs to top floor, and put in flooring to avoid having to heat up-stairs.
Put in new window glass where required.
Repair heating system.

There is no way of draining this place so outside closets will have to be built. The place looks like a wreck as the paper on outside walls and roof is in such bad shape, but with outlay of about $3000.00 it could be fixed up; however a place like this eats up money when repair work is undertaken.

I have not mentioned equipment for this place as I do not quite know what is intended to be installed.

The matter of telephone will be taken up in separate letter. I am enquiring from the forest officials as to cost to them of putting in phone system in bush, and will advise the Department when I get their answer.

I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant,
