Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor

Angle Countershaft

Size
Inside basket shall be inches in diameter. Countershaft shall be angle type.

Basket
Shall be constructed with sides perforated with sufficient number of holes to permit free discharge of extracted water, heavily galvanized inside and out, and riveted to top and bottom of basket. Bottom shall be of cast iron, cored to make a double web, truly machined, and inside surface covered with sheet copper, heavily tinned. Top shall be reinforced with a steel ring spun into place. A series of steel bands shall be fitted to basket sides to reinforce same. Basket shall be tested for running balance at rated speed.

Curb and Base
Outside curb shall be an extra heavy one-piece casting and standard or base shall also be cast in one piece. Curb and base shall be securely bolted together, becoming in effect one solid, rigid casting. Curb shall be equipped with drain openings in bottom and fitted with detachable cast-iron top ring.

Safety Cover
Shall be equipped with hinged safety cover.

Safety Bumper and Spindle
Rubber safety ring shall be fitted on bottom of basket and so arranged that when basket is unevenly loaded the rubber shall engage with curb bottom, thus preventing basket from striking outer curb when finding its balance. Basket shall be supported on spindle-steel spindle, equipped with driving pulley. Spindle shall be turned and ground to size and taper fit in basket bottom. Shall be fitted with bronze lock nut. Lower end of spindle shall have a syphon arrangement, consisting of a hollow chamber, forming an oil reservoir for circulation of oil around the spindle. See sectional view on reverse side.

Balancing Device
Base casting shall be constructed with a detachable well casting for receiving the balancing device. In said casting shall be located a phosphor-bronze sleeve bearing for receiving spindle.
Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor—Continued

Angle Countershaft

provided with flange above and below which shall be located rubber spring cushions, engaging flanges on well casting, and held in place by a spanner nut threaded in well casting. Shall be provided with three hardened, double convex, tool-steel buttons at bottom of bearing, on which spindle shall operate. Oil nuts shall be fitted on top of bearing in such a manner as to feed oil to spindle and furnish a tight joint, to prevent oil from coming in contact with rubbers.

Brake

Extractor shall be fitted with a friction foot brake attached to base, working on spindle pulley. Shall be equipped with locking device, to prevent sudden shock and hold brake in position until basket stops revolving.

Countershaft and Idlers

Shall have countershaft bolted to curb and base, forming a self-contained part of the machine. Shall consist of a cast-iron bracket supporting the shaft with its tight and loose pulleys and friction driving pulley, and also guide or idler pulleys. One of the idler pulleys shall be equipped with an adjustable device for taking up slack in belt.

Globe Wood Washer
36" and 40" Diameter—End Header

Size
The inner cylinder shall be inches diameter by inches in length, and shall have doors and partitions, and hinges, latches and hoops.
Shall be single geared.

Cylinder
Shall have heads and staves of Crown Prime Long Leaf Yellow Pine, air dried, with ribs of hard Maple. Staves cut from 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inch stock shall be nailed to heads cut from 2-inch stock. There shall be three large lifting ribs each cut from stock 2\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inches thick by 4 inches deep; also a rib cut from 3-inch by 5-inch stock placed at front and back of door opening rabbetted to receive door. Door shall be 15\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inches wide. Door battens shall be of brass. Hinges shall be wide and heavy, and shall rest on bottom of door opening and on brass plates on front door rib. Latches shall have wide lips. Cylinder shall be banded with wide and heavy hoops, fastened to the staves by means of brass screws.

Tub
Shall be constructed of clear and better Fir, with staves cut from 2-inch stock, tongued and grooved and gained to fit over heads cut from 2-inch stock, to which they shall be nailed. A galvanized-iron sliding door shall operate in grooves provided on adjustable encircling bands or hoops. Brass apron shall be fitted at bottom of door opening to protect the staves.
A gauge glass shall be mounted on left tub head.

Iron Frames
Cast-iron frames of heavy design, rigidly bolted to the tub heads, shall support the weight of the inside cylinder and outside tub and the driving mechanism shall be bolted to these frames. Frames shall be bolted to the tub heads and shall be absolutely rigid.
Globe Wood Washer—Continued
36" and 40" Diameter—End Header

Inlet and Outlet
Located in the center bottom of the tub shall be a combination cast-iron flange tee through which the steam and water shall enter and waste water be discharged. Steam shall enter washer through an annular steam passage cored in the tee without coming in direct contact with the wood or linen. Connected with the flange tee shall be an outlet pipe, on the end of which a 3-inch quick-opening valve of the hollow taper plug type shall be fitted.

Provision shall be made for 2-inch water and 1/2-inch steam connections.

Trunnions and Bearings
Cast-iron trunnions shall be attached to cylinder heads by means of brass covered bolts and inside of cylinder heads shall be fitted with two brass trunnion rings. The journals of trunnions shall operate in babbitted bearings equipped with easily accessible lubricators. Journal bearings shall be supported by the cast-iron frames.

Gearing
Shall be machine cut from solid blanks and provided with solid gear guards for the protection of the operator. The main gear shall be of the split hub type, bolted and keyed to trunnion shaft. A gear lock shall be provided for holding cylinder door in position while loading and unloading.

Automatic Reverse Mechanism
Shall consist of three 16-inch diameter pulleys and a worm and cam movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder. Entire shifting mechanism shall be mounted on heavy cast-iron swiveling arm, adjustable to belt at various angles. Header shall be supported by bracket arm bolted to cast-iron frame and shall embody strength, simplicity and reliability and be arranged for 1 1/4 and 2-inch belts.

Dear Sir;

In reply to your letter of the 2nd inst., NO.128-1-5, requesting an expression of my views, relative to the installation of better laundry facilities at the Mackay School, The Pas, Man., I beg to state that I carefully examined, at the time of my last visit, that part of the basement of the Main Building, which is at present being utilized as a laundry, and came to the conclusion, that it could be very well adapted to accommodate modern laundry equipment.

In this connection I beg to enclose herewith -
(1) the ground plan of the rooms in question.
(2) illustrated pages from the Stanley Brock Company, showing the kind of washer and extractor desired.

With regard to the installation of these, the above firm in their letter of January 12th make the following statements: -

"We would suggest the following: -

1 - Only 36" X 54" Globe Wood Washer (1) door in cylinder, (1) door in tub, end header.

1 - Only 26" Angle Attached Solid Curb Extractor.

The list price of the Washer is $400.00 at the factory, and the list price of the Extractor is $500.00 at the factory. However, we give the Department of Indian Affairs
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

"a little better price, and this would possibly amount to 10% off these prices.

We are making a note on your plan how these could be installed, and they can be driven easily by a 5 horse power engine. We supplied the belting for the Indian Schools also, and it takes about $30.00 or $35.00 worth of belting for this installation.

The 36" X 54" Washer is possibly the standard size, and we believe that you will find this size O.K. for your School.

We are trying to make up a carload of laundry machinery for Winnipeg, and if successful we can give the head of your department, carload rate of freight from Toronto to Winnipeg, which is a very large saving; in fact we brought the last two orders we received from Mr. Bunn into Winnipeg in a carload of machinery, then we shipped from here."

Trusting that the above information may be satisfactory to you, and that you may be able to furnish this school with this very necessary requirement.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary M.S.O.C.

Tub

A gauge glass shall be mounted on left tub head.

Iron Frames

Cast-iron frames of heavy design, rigidly bolted to the tub heads, shall support the weight of the inside cylinder and outside tub and the driving mechanism shall be bolted to these frames. Frames shall be bolted to the tub heads.

Inlet and Outlet

Sir:-

I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Waddy in which he informs me that you have instructed him to make an estimate of the cost of a workshop required at the McKay Boarding School and submit it to me. The Agent goes on to say that the Principal prepared a plan which includes a store in the end of the workshop.

It seems to me a most extraordinary way for the Department to do business after the repeated instructions I have had from the Minister that work of this kind was to be taken up through my office. I now get a plan of a building that was prepared by an impractical man, Mr. Bird. He is also asking for something, the necessity for which I am doubtful of. Why was Mr. Waddy written to direct on this matter? We cannot carry on business in this way. I am prepared to hand the whole building programme back to where it was if the Department are not prepared to assist me and carry out the instructions given by the Minister. Mr. Stewart is in the West now and I hope before he returns to Ottawa to have this matter threshed out once again.

I am enclosing herewith the plan which I received from Mr. Waddy, and I wish to make no comment on it. If you wish the work finished, carry it out with Mr. Waddy.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

October 10th, 1925.

Dear Sir,

I have your 205-11A of the 1st instant with reference to the proposed new workshop at the Mackay Indian Residential School. The church authorities pressed for immediate action in connection with this matter and solely in the interests of despatch, the Department telegraphed Mr. Indian Agent Waddy to make a recommendation to you. You will please note that the instructions of the Honourable, The Superintendent General were kept in mind when this telegram was directed. Our local representative's recommendation was to go to your office and not direct to the Department.

Rest assured that I am endeavouring to carry out Mr. Stewart's wishes and to this end I am returning the rough sketch and list of material for your criticism and recommendation. As the building season is rapidly drawing to a close, I should be grateful if you would let me have your report by telegram as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

J. D. McLean

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
